story:
The dust has settled and what remains? Can it be rebuilt? Is it worth rebuilding?

 
parthenon: an interactive and immersive environment. Part installation, part theatrical happening.  An in-depth exploration of art as a means of re-creation; an exploration of art as a means to rebuild post-catastrophe.


With seven unlikely undesirables at the helm, parthenon will rattle expectations with its endless inventivity and explore the raw power of creativity. It will not be afraid to make a scene, even when it means description by made-up words.


In fact, it will leave you without anything but.  


parthenon is a thesis project and a labor of love. Scheduled for November 2013 at the University of the Arts in Philadelphia, PA, it marks Director Lauren Tuvell's debut in the world of creation-based theatre.

 
Come see what happened.


Lend us a hand and we’ll lend you fourteen. (Plus super cool and custom-made thank you’s filled with love and appreciation.)

L, M, E
W, P, S, L, G, & E

story:
We are WHITMORE ECLECTIC 501 (c) 3

            The primary goal of The W.E. is to produce the highest caliber of theatrical productions that inspires our youth, seniors and all others to participate in the exploration of their unique, cultural identity and involve them in projects which will harness and give voice to their creative energies for the public good.  Our first work out the gate for this season is PROOF by David Auburn.

We will achieve this goal by using workshops, and out reach programs that work in conjunction with our full-length theatrical productions as a platform for education, social awareness and cultural-enrichment. The Whitmore Eclectic’s has created several workshop series that will be launched this December, such as, ‘Bring The Voice”, a workshop series designed to introduce children with life threatening illness to methods of directing, acting and production design and to help them produce their own show.  “Redesign the World” art and scenic design class that will teach the importance of and how to use reclaimed and recycled materials for set design and al types of art.  These are just two examples of The Whitmore Eclectic’s commitment to the community and the public good.

 Whitmore Eclectic is nearing the launch of our 2013/2014 season, “The Sight of the Story!”  This next creative chapter will include published and original works, that are sure to evoke thought, summon emotion and excite the senses.

            First on deck, we have PROOF by David Auburn, starring DANIELA RUAH and JAMES WHTMORE JR. Coming this April at The Hayworth Theatre. April 27- May25, Saturdays and Sunday's only.

            Please join us as we work together to positively influence the art community in Los Angeles by producing the highest quality of small stage production possible, sharing our tools as crafts people with the youth of our community, and help deepen the appreciation of the Living American Theater, which is the spirit of the American Democracy.

Whitmore Eclectic’s 2013/2014 Season Gift Opportunities

 

 

CREATIVE VOICES  $25.00 - $499.00:  Creative Voices provide funding for our theatre and outreach programs.  These donors receive two (2) tickets to Opening Night of our first 2013 production.

 

CREATIVE CITIZENS  $500.00 - $999.00:  Creative Citizens provide Whitmore Eclectic the funds to assist with production needs.  These donors receive two (2) tickets to Opening Night of our first 2013 production and two (2) tickets to all 2013 preview performances.

 

COMMUNITY PIONEERS $1,000.00 – $4,999.00:  Community Pioneers help Whitmore Eclectic to extend our hand to the community with our workshops and assistance with Coach Art.  These donors receive two (2) tickets to Opening Night of our first 2013 production, two (2) tickets to all 2013 previews as well as an invitation to attend a rehearsal of a 2013 production of the donor’s choice.

 

CREATIVE ARCHITECTS $5,000.00 - $9,999.99:  Creative Architects provide Whitmore Eclectic with resources on an operational level.  These donors receive two (2) tickets to Opening Night of all of our 2013 productions, unlimited number of tickets to all 2013 previews, an invitation to attend a rehearsal of a 2013 production of the donor’s choice as well as signed programs from all our 2013 productions.

 

CREATIVE AMBASSADORS- $10,000 - $24,000: Creative Ambassadors provide Whitmore Eclectic with the resources to address major production needs and elect to secure materials for community outreach programs.  These donors receive all of the above, as well as an invitation to attend the dress rehearsal of our special production with Coach Art, “Bring the Voice!”

 

FOUNDING FATHERS- $25,000.00 and beyond:  Founding Fathers provide Whitmore Eclectic with the resources to address major program priorities and develop program excellence and growth, including our theatrical productions and community outreach.  These donors are entitled to all of the above as well as an invitation to join the Whitmore Eclectic Advisory Board and participate in programming, directives and creative plans with Whitmore Eclectic.

 

* Donations can be made online at: whitmoreeclectic.com

 

PROOF

We are opening this season with PROOF a show that is at the heart of our mission. A story that speaks about personal struggle and about the right of every human being to be heard.  Helping us produce this show helps to bring voice to a part of the community that often is left unheard; those that are deemed, "mentally ill".  With this production we hope to create an experience for the audience that resembles the internal experience of someone with schizopherinia. This work is to help create a greater empathy for people struggling with mental illness.  There is beauty and power in all people and things and we hope to shed light on that fact with this production.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

WE need all the help we can muster! Like us on FACEBOOK and come see the show. Bring your friends and start talking. Our goal is to start more dialogue about PROOF's subject matter. Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

Help us to spread the word and tell the world that the human experience varies from person to person and each and every experience needs to be honored and respected.

This work is to help create a greater empathy for people struggling with mental illness.  There is beauty and power in all people and things and we hope to shed light on that fact with this production.
 


Other Ways You Can Help
WE need all the help we can muster! Like us on FACEBOOK and come see the show. Bring your friends and start talking. Our goal is to start more dialogue about PROOF's subject matter. Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:
Help us to spread the word and tell the world that the human experience varies from person to person and each and every experience needs to be honored and respected.

story:
Hello,

My name is John Anthony Gorman.

Just over three years ago, I moved from Scotland to New York City where I attended Atlantic Acting School. It was there that I learned the importance of "making your own work." With artists that I have met throughout my time here, we have formed The Savage Detectives Theatre company along with Just A Gentleman Productions.

The Savage Detectives Theatre Company thrives on telling multi-cultural narratives with actors from diverse and varied backgrounds. As America was built by many different people from all over the world, so too was our collective. We strive to tell contemporary stories that are emblematic of this spirit. We also encourage actors to play multiple roles in the production beyond just their onstage involvement, when the setting is fit for it. Our composers play music live during our show, because we want audiences to witness our collaborative spirit firsthand. Together, we make not just acting choices, but the entirety of the theater experience possible for an audience.

We have chosen THE LAST DAYS OF JUDAS ISCARIOT by Stephen Adly Guirgis as our first production. Guirgis' goal as this play's creator is to bring ancient stories into "the now". Figures from Biblical scripture enter the space dressed in contemporary clothing and spewing street slang obscenities. We want to bring audiences into the intensely alive version of human history--not the kind you find in your high school or college textbook. The whole point of this project is to show audiences that the past isn't as distant from the present as we think--and that the so-called villain of any story isn't necessarily driven by "evil", but by the chaos of the world around him. In Guirgis' version of the story, we are reminded that the human race betrayed Christ, not just Judas.

Your contributions will not only help us make this production a reality but it will also give 15 actors the chance to show their outstanding skills in the theatre capital of the world.

We hope you will support us by donating and helping us create a new group in the theatre world. Thank you and love to everyone. 


The $3000 dollars raised will allow us to:

.Book the Off-Broadway theatre at $2000

.Pay for the rights to the play $225

.Props and set $400

.Rehearsal space $375 


If our ultimate goal is not met, the money received will still go towards the play and the play will go ahead but on a smaller scale.


This production hopes to inspire more people to go out there and produce their own work. When people hear the word Broadway they automatically think "expensive"; we want to show that this is not the case and that with a minimal amount of money you can put on a great piece of theatre. Your contributions will help show that through hard work and dedication you can make your dreams and ambitions a reality. 


We totally understand that because of these financial times not everyone can contribute  but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

If you could please spread the word about this play and campaign. If you could send this link to any of your friends or relatives that you think would be interested or could help, that would be amazing.


Thank you so much for your time and contributions.

story:
Synthesis Dance Theater at UCLA is in its fifth year as a student-run dance group.  With the use of contemporary/modern foundations, the Synthesis Dance Theater produces numerous pieces of dance by combining and furnishing several genres of dance. We are a company of artists that enjoy sharing our passion for dance with others and accept and welcome all forms of dance to create something fresh and exciting. Most importantly, we love to have fun and perform for all kinds of audiences! 

We are reaching out to our supporters to help us put on our two shows of the year. Your support brings us one step closer to being able to share the love of what we do with the rest of the UCLA community, as well as our family and friends. 

The money you donate will go directly towards covering the costs of our Winter Showcase, as well as our Spring Showcase which will take place during spring quarter of 2015. Admission to our shows is totally free, which we see as an important part of being able to attract new audiences to dance. Every donation will help us be able to put on these two shows and keep admission free. 

We understand that everyone may not be able to donate, but anyone can contribute to our cause by sharing this campaign and helping spread the word. Thank you so much for your time and effort in helping us to achieve our goal.

story:
Our community in Portland, Oregon deserves no less than the best as we reach for the moon in the year 2015. You can help the Kemba Shannon Dance Center grow by giving your support, love and funding to our professional performance programing for children and adults. It's time to take it to the next level as we produce our first major dance production.

"MOONDANCE" A Concert of Contemporary Dance

What We Need & What You Get

Kemba Shannon Dance Center
As a community arts resource that provides professional services for students in underserved communities we are always on the lookout for financing student tuition. You
can help give financial aid and scholarships to very deserving students who simply cannot afford a professional training ground.
  • You can donate directly
  • You can sponsor a student for a term or a year.
  • you can by a perk from our list of wonderful items on this site.
  • Or you can feed two birds with one hand and make a donation to our "Hats to Homeless Project" (knitted by our Co-Artistic Director Mr. Bobby).
"MOONDANCE" A Concert of Dance on February 22, 2015 is in need of producers like you to help us create a basic budget to work from.
  • You can donate directly
  • You can purchase Tickets online at this site.
  • You can by a perk from our list of wonderful items on this site.
  • Or you can feed two birds with one hand and make a donation to our "Hats to Homeless Project" (knitted by our Co-Artistic Director Mr. Bobby)).

How we do what we do

As the first professional performance studio to move into the Kenton area of North Portland we are committed to developing and showcasing the vast amount of creative ability that is part of the Northwest legacy:

  • Affordable classes and workshops
  • World class and award winning instruction
  • Early childhood development classes
  • National and State arts based curriculum
  • Love and attention to creating the whole person
  • Year round performance opportunities

Risks & Challenges

In our 3rd year of providing artistic services and alternatives for young people and their families we are always in need of community support. Our wish list is ever changing and expanding. The reality of our spacial needs includes everything from grantwriting to washing the studio mirrors.

  • As professionals we would not have it any other way.
  • As artistic mentors we pass our experience and expertise on to our students by training them to accept the risks and challenges that life will bring.

Ways you can help us do what we do

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

If you would like to send your contribution directly to the studio please make your check out to Kemba Shannon and mail it to...

Kembe Shannon Dance Center

2017 N Kilpatrick

Portland, Oregon 97217

Thank you so much for your support KSDC

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Short Summary

The Village Hotel is a drama/comedy/crime story set in the lobby of a Newark, New Jersey hotel.  It is being produced as a part of the 2015 Pittsburgh Fringe Festival.

Here are some of the people involved in The Village Hotel:

  • Playwright Tyler Plosia is a graduate of The New School and recently had a production of his play The Happy Hour in New York City as a part of the Thespis Theater Festival.  The Village Hotel will be his first play performed in Pittsburgh.  
  • Director David Minniefield has directed theater in Pittsburgh for years, including productions at Prime Stage, New Horizon Theatre and Spotlight Musical Theatre.  For the past few years he has been the director at the Trinity Christian School.
  • Actor Natalie Spanner is a recent graduate of Seton Hill University.  She just finished the creative, well-received Prime Stage production of Animal Farm.
  • Actor Chuck Timbers is an established Pittsburgh actor.  He has appeared in Pittsburgh Playwrights productions of August Wilson's Fences and Ma Rainey's Black Bottom among many others.
  • Actor Michael Perrotta was a Theatre major at Cal U, where he performed in over thirty productions.  In addition to acting in a variety of shows, Michael founded New Modern Theatre.

What We Need & What You Get


  • Any funds raised for the production will all go to either rehearsal space, performance space or compensating the individuals involved in the production.
  • By contributing to The Village Hotel, you will be helping a group of dedicated theater artists put on new work in an emerging Fringe festival (the Pittsburgh Fringe is only in its second year).

story:
Tampa Shakespeare Festival

Tampa Shakespeare Festival strives to bring the works of William Shakespeare and other classical playwrights to Tampa communities in a fun and accessible way. Our goal is to create productions that are fast paced and enjoyable for the whole family.  Tampa Shakespeare Festival's shows are performed outdoors and are free to the entire community. 

Your donations will help us off-set production costs including the cost of renting the venue and paying our actors. More  importantly your donations help bring free theatre to our community.

________________________________________________________________________

What it Costs

We are currently hoping to raise $5,000 to help us produce this show. Last year thanks to the donations of 33 patrons in our first season we were able to serve 1,427 community members two free Shakespeare plays in the park.  Only 33 people brought these productions to our community, that’s less than 3 percent of the attendees. 

If the same number of patrons join us, and if every one of the 1427 people gives only $5, we will raise $2,134 over our goal. 

Below is a breakdown of how your donations will be spent. 

$1,600 will be use to pay for the costs of the Venue. 

$750 will be used to pay 10 actors a $75 stipend.

$150 will be used to pay a costume designer and a stage manager a stipend of $75 each.

$2,000 will be designated for costume and prop purchases.

$575 will be designated for printing postcards, programs, and any additional costs.

If every person gave $10 we would be funded to the tune of 14,000 dollars, this would provide us with additional funds to develop a website, pay our actors a living wage, and increase our community outreach. A donation of $10 helps ensure our ability to continue to bring free theatrical productions to our Tampa communities.

Remember we provide 2 free shows, consider what you might pay as a ticket price for a show. 10$ per show? If so give at the friend level. 

We want to keep this free and we know not everyone can give, if you can give more to bring classical theatre to our community, please give more. Remember last year only 3 percent of our patrons and our generous artists made this happen. You could be one of those heroes. 

________________________________________________________________________

To Show Our Appreciation 

To show our appreciation for your donation you will receive:


$20 – Friends – (The cost of two tickets if this were at ticketed event.)

Tampa Shakespeare Festival Sticker


$50 - Player

One Pint Glass and a Tampa Shakespeare Festival Sticker

 

$75 - Shareholder

Tampa Shakespeare Festival T shirt or Pint Glass, and a TSF Sticker

 

$100 - Noble Guest

Tampa Shakespeare Festival T-Shirt or Pint Glass

TSF Sticker

And an Invitation (for you and a guest) to our opening night party on March 18th.

 

$500 - Lord and Lady 

Tampa Shakespeare Festival T-shirt, Pint Glass, & Sticker

Invitation (for you and a guest) to our Opening Night Party on March 18th.

Title of Show Sponsor 

 

$750 - Duke and Duchess 

Tampa Shakespeare Festival T-shirt, Pint Glass, & Sticker

Invitation (for you and a guest) to our Opening Night Party on March 18th.

A special viewing area for you and a guest to enjoy the production from in comfort and style. 

 

$1000 and above - King or Queen.

Tampa Shakespeare Festival T-shirt, Pint Glass, & Sticker

Invitation (for you and a guest) to our Opening Night Party on March 18th.

Title of Season Sponsor 

________________________________________________________________________

The Impact

We believe that through hard work, determination, and your help we will be able to build Tampa's very own annual Shakespeare festival. It is our desire to give our community fun and entertaining theatre at no cost to them. We believe theatre should be available to all members of our wonderful community without putting a hefty dent in their pocketbooks. 

It is our goal to have this Festival grow in future years to include more productions and educational opportunities. Currently our focus is on being able to provide two free shows to our community on an annual basis. 

Thanks to the donations of 33 patrons in our first season we were able to serve 1,427 community members two free Shakespeare plays in the park. 

________________________________________________________________________

Audience Reactions

“I just had this discussion with friends and pointed to your success as proof that there is a market for quality live theatre in the Tampa Bay Area - thank you to the entire cast and crew for a wonderful show and a unique experience! ”

“We had a fabulous time and were SO IMPRESSED by the talented actors & actresses! Congrats on your first season and we are so looking forward to many more! ”

“It is a huge testament to your cast (and to this timeless work) that even the youngest audience members were entranced for 2+ hours without a set, without a "guest star", without special effects or a soundtrack....There may be hope yet for the next generation.”

“So much better than TV.”

“Love this. We had kids come up to us in the audience and ask what was happening. Then they laid their towels down and watched for a bit.”

“Enjoyed the performance. Perfect afternoon in the park.”

“AMAZING performance!! We are so lucky to have such talent in Tampa! ”

________________________________________________________________________

Other Ways You Can Help

Looking for other ways to help? We are looking for people to help out in a multitude of ways including:

Ushers

Costume Run Crew

Promotional Support

Audience Members

Sharing this campaign with Friends or Family who may be interested in our project.

If you are interested in helping in one of these ways or have other skills to offer please contact us at TampaShakes@gmail.com and let us know how you would like to be involved.
story_txt: Tampa Shakespeare FestivalTampa Shakespeare Festival strives to bring the works of William Shakespeare and other classical playwrights to Tampa communities in a fun and accessible way. Our goal is to create productions that are fast paced and enjoyable for the whole family.  Tampa Shakespeare Festival's shows are performed outdoors and are free to the entire community. Your donations will help us off-set production costs including the cost of renting the venue and paying our actors. More  importantly your donations help bring free theatre to our community.________________________________________________________________________What it CostsWe are currently hoping to raise $5,000 to help us produce this show. Last year thanks to the donations of 33 patrons in our first season we were able to serve 1,427 community members two free Shakespeare plays in the park.  Only 33 people brought these productions to our community, that’s less than 3 percent of the attendees. If the same number of patrons join us, and if every one of the 1427 people gives only $5, we will raise $2,134 over our goal. Below is a breakdown of how your donations will be spent. $1,600 will be use to pay for the costs of the Venue. $750 will be used to pay 10 actors a $75 stipend.$150 will be used to pay a costume designer and a stage manager a stipend of $75 each.$2,000 will be designated for costume and prop purchases.$575 will be designated for printing postcards, programs, and any additional costs.If every person gave $10 we would be funded to the tune of 14,000 dollars, this would provide us with additional funds to develop a website, pay our actors a living wage, and increase our community outreach. A donation of $10 helps ensure our ability to continue to bring free theatrical productions to our Tampa communities.Remember we provide 2 free shows, consider what you might pay as a ticket price for a show. 10$ per show? If so give at the friend level. We want to keep this free and we know not everyone can give, if you can give more to bring classical theatre to our community, please give more. Remember last year only 3 percent of our patrons and our generous artists made this happen. You could be one of those heroes. ________________________________________________________________________To Show Our Appreciation To show our appreciation for your donation you will receive:$20 – Friends – (The cost of two tickets if this were at ticketed event.)Tampa Shakespeare Festival Sticker$50 - PlayerOne Pint Glass and a Tampa Shakespeare Festival Sticker $75 - ShareholderTampa Shakespeare Festival T shirt or Pint Glass, and a TSF Sticker $100 - Noble GuestTampa Shakespeare Festival T-Shirt or Pint GlassTSF StickerAnd an Invitation (for you and a guest) to our opening night party on March 18th. $500 - Lord and Lady Tampa Shakespeare Festival T-shirt, Pint Glass, & StickerInvitation (for you and a guest) to our Opening Night Party on March 18th.Title of Show Sponsor  $750 - Duke and Duchess Tampa Shakespeare Festival T-shirt, Pint Glass, & StickerInvitation (for you and a guest) to our Opening Night Party on March 18th.A special viewing area for you and a guest to enjoy the production from in comfort and style.  $1000 and above - King or Queen.Tampa Shakespeare Festival T-shirt, Pint Glass, & StickerInvitation (for you and a guest) to our Opening Night Party on March 18th.Title of Season Sponsor ________________________________________________________________________The ImpactWe believe that through hard work, determination, and your help we will be able to build Tampa's very own annual Shakespeare festival. We believe theatre should be available to all members of our wonderful community without putting a hefty dent in their pocketbooks. It is our goal to have this Festival grow in future years to include more productions and educational opportunities. story:
ON MAY 20th WE REACHED OUR GOAL! 

THANKY YOU to all of our supporters who have donated thus far. We are forever thankful for your donations this early in the process. Your generosity will be remembered by SpeakEasy Theatre forever. 

LETS KEEP GOING! 

STRETCH GOAL

With one week remaining in the campaign we wanted to further our financial mission. Additional funding will go towards Advertising and promotional materials to get our name out there! We also would like to apply for our charitable status this summer! There are fees that come with that too. With $7000 we can pay for all that on top of our original budgeting. That would be pretty cool. THANK YOU! 

Speakin' Easy

Picture the 1920s and it’s hard to imagine it without the image of a SpeakEasy; a roaring establishment where people went to escape, celebrate, and converse. The nature of the conversation being blunt and honest. Our goal is to bring the freedom to speak anything to the stage.

We are Markian Tarasiuk and Mike Gill and our goal is to raise $6000 to fund the beginnings of our new theatre company as well as our first production, "3...2...1" by Chris Craddock and Nathan Cuckow. 

Who Are We?

SpeakEasy Theatre Company Society is an emerging theatre company based out of Vancouver, BC with deep roots in Winnipeg and the prairies. We are seeking support today to stage our first produced play and to get our feet off the ground to produce future productions! Our team comprises of Markian Tarasiuk (Artistic Director), Mike Gill (Associate Artistic Director), Tom Krushkowski (Technical Director) and Olivia Hutt (Managing Director). All of us met while training at Studio 58 Theatre School where we worked together on many school productions - now we want to take our creativity into the professional world!
 

Whattaya Havin?

At our current stage, we are a registered incorporated society. We are currently in the middle of applying for our Charitable Non For Profit Status. We've lined up a kick ass number of  generous event and season sponsors that includes Canadian Club Rye Whiskey and Miller Genuine Draft. Our media sponsor is Vancouver Presents. We've got a creative team assembled for our first show and venues booked. What we're trying to say is - we have put our time and money into this endeavour, and the next step is YOU: our future audience.  

ABOUT THE PLAY 

3...2...1 is a riveting play about Clint and Kyle, two young men from Wetaskiwin, Alberta, who skip their best friend Danny’s funeral and lock themselves in a garage with several cases of beer, Jack Daniels, a cornucopia of pharmaceuticals and broken dreams…and they’re not coming out until everything’s been drunk, popped, shot up and smoked - with an ending that will blow you away. 3...2...1 is a raw, violent and sometimes funny examination of life, religion, love, friendship and homophobia. Imagine a bender that just won’t end. 3...2...1 is Trailer Park Boys meets Long Day’s Journey into Night. Extremely coarse language. Adult situations. Gunshots. Violence. References to drugs, alcohol and Wetaskiwin. WARNING: “3…2…1 makes you laugh until your stomach hurts and then punches you in it.” What we need from you to bring this play to the Winnipeg Fringe and then back here to Vancouver is the following:


Who's our creative team??

One of our biggest mandate principals is to pay our artists for their hard work and creativity. By donating today you won't just be supporting SpeakEasy Theatre - but these talented emerging artists!

Director of "3...2...1" : Kayvon Kelly   

Stage Manager/ Desinger (Vancouver Production): Sarah Mabberley 

Designer (Winnipeg Production): Sofia Lukie

What are the costs? 

       Here is the breakdown of what our $6000 will go towards:

  • $1500 - Travel costs for the two actors and the stage manager to the Winnipeg Fringe.
  • $1900 - Wages for the Creative Team (Director, Stage Manager, Designer - estimation does not include actors)
  • $350 - Materials and build cost of the set
  • $750 - Winnipeg Fringe Festival Fee
  • $1500 - Put towards our future Production in Vancouver 
As of now, to save money, we are not paying ourselves as actors as part of our fundraising campaign. All the funding goes towards our hires and artistic costs related with designs and fees! 

Paying the tab

We believe in paying our artists. We feel that we’re living in the prohibition era of paid work for young artists and one of our most important goals as a company is to pay amounts that recognize the value of the work created. "3...2...1" is the first of hopefully many productions from our company, and also the first of many shows we produce where the actors, designers, directors, stage managers and everyone else actually get paid. As a new company, we can't apply for grants yet which severely hinders our financial possibilities. Grant application rules state a company must be in operation for one year before applying. In the future we plan to find other means to make the money for our productions, but right now we need your help to get off the ground.

The Perks we're providing are both valued and fun. We wanted to play with the theme of a SpeakEasy and the bar world as well as provide actual tangible goods involved with the shows. Markian's a good bartender, and Mike just pretends he is, so combined they should create some real gems (crap) (okay really good drinks actually)

WANT TO SUPPORT US EVEN MORE? COME TO OUR FUNDRAISER TO MEET THE TEAM, DRINK AND CELEBRATE!  

SPEAKEASY LAUNCH EVENT

Join SpeakEasy Theatre Company for an evening of music, booze and friends! SpeakEasy Theatre Company Society is a brand new emerging theatre company based out of Vancouver, BC. This year marks their inaugural season as they open their programming with "3...2...1" by Nathan Cuckow and Chris Craddock. This event is a fundraiser for SpeakEasy Theatre and the upcoming productions that are being produced. Sponsoring this event will be Canadian Club Whiskey and Miller Genuine Draft.

Join us at 7pm for tickets to the "Capo Party" that includes canapes, a prohibition style signature Whiskey cocktail and a free Canadian Club 100% Rye tasting within the ticket price of $25.

Why "Capo Party"? . A caporegime or capodecina usually shortened to just a capo, is a term used in the Mafia for a high-ranking made member of a crime – er - theatre family who has major social status and influence in the organization. 

At 8:30 the doors will be open for general admission - with a cocktail included just for $15! 

TICKETS AVAILABLE AT:  http://www.speakeasytheatre.ca/#!purchase/c4x5

Closing time

First off, thanks for reading this far. Secondly, we want to reiterate the point that we're pushing the boundaries of a startup theatre company. We're not striving to stage a show in our parents backyard, we're hungry for quality in all aspects, and the only thing holding us back is a little bit of scratch. We've assembled a team of strong willed, creative, and hard working individuals that are committed to this project and this company. 3...2...1 is a phenomenal show that deserves to see the stage both at the Winnipeg Fringe and here in Vancouver and we think you want to see it too.

Thanks for reading!

VISIT US ONLINE! 

WWW.SPEAKEASYTHEATRE.CA

TWITTER: @SETHEATRECO 

FACEBOOK: WWW.FACEBOOK.COM/SPEAKEASYTHEATRECOMPANY

INSTAGRAM: @SPEAKEASYTHEATRE

story:
Who We Are

For almost 40 years, the Canadian Improv Games (CIG) has taught kids, all across the country, the skills of improvisation and provided them with a stage to hone these skills. For a lot of youth it's the most important part of their high school experience, and teaches them skills they use their entire lives, such as teamwork, confidence, decisiveness and empathy. In the Sudbury and Northern Ontario region (SNO), we face some special challenges providing teens the same quality of experience as other regions. The SNO Region is geographically one of Canada’s largest, meaning participants and volunteers often must travel quite a distance to get to a workshop or a night of play. Your Donations directly impact the student experience.

What We Need & What You Get

To keep the cost of participation down for schools, we’re splitting our immense region into two zones, in which there will nights of play, workshops. While this reduces travel costs for many teams, it increases production and travel costs for Canadian Improv Games. Running two zones also creates new opportunities for schools that couldn’t participate previously, and allows us to grow our volunteer trainer base in those areas. Once established, these two new zones will be financially sustainable, however we need your help in these early stages. Your donations will support this initial outreach push, offset venue costs, and subsidise trainer and volunteer travel.
Yes, also we have perks. We have t-shirts and pins and other stuff for individuals, as well as advertising-based perks aimed at businesses (though technically nothing stops businesses from buying t-shirts, or individuals from buying advertising). Some of them are pretty cool, so check them out!

The Impact

The only way to understand the impact that the CIG has on a person is to speak to somebody who has been affected by improv. So let me tell you about how it's changed my life. My name is AJ Comeau, and the launch of this campaign coincides with my tenth year doing improv. There are lots of ways it has affected me, but here's one: I started in grade 9 playing games in an after-school club. It was fun, social, creative, and the weekly shows we did for other students did wonders for my fragile, teenage confidence. It gave me a sense of community with my school, and close camaraderie with my friends. We started competing in the CIG when I was in grade 11, and the skills I learned competing were more than just about having fun, being social, or my creativity, they taught me how to listen. Listening is one of the core skills we focus on teaching. In a nutshell it's the awareness of the people around you and a sense of direction that comes from it. All that gained from the things you see and hear, and in hindsight it seems silly to admit, but I was a bad listener and didn't know it until then. Learning how to listen has made me a better student, a better employee, and a better person than I was. Would I have learned it eventually? Maybe, but I'm thankful I'll never have to know.

I volunteer because there's probably a kid in every high school class who needs what I needed then, and improv delivers on that. Your contributions will help us deliver improv to them.

Other Ways You Can Help

And it's not just financial contributions that matter. Tell people about us, and about our campaign. Like us on Facebook and share our Indiegogo page. Tweet about us on Twitter. Get in touch, volunteer, share your story. Improv and the CIG have made their mark on youth all over Canada, and you can make your mark on a piece of it. And while you're at it, remember the Improv Oath, that is pledged at the beginning of every CIG show:

We have come together,
In the spirit of loving competition,
To celebrate the Canadian Improv Games,
We promise:
To uphold the ideals of improvisation,
To cooperate with one another,
To learn from each other,
To commit ourselves to the moment
And, above all, to have a good time!

story:
ANDTheater Company is producing a showcase of a new play to be performed in NYC in November. The play, Basement is a drama that deals with racial tension under extreme conditions. It is particularly relevant in today's climate, though sadly it seems it has and always will be.

The first reading of this play was in October of 2016, hosted by ANDTheater Company who has been a major supporter of my play. Naturally rewrites were in order after November 8th! I am asking for your support of this production so that we may realize this staged showcase as the next step in developing the play.

The Cast includes: Jared Wilder, Lussi Samela, James Michael Armstrong, Jen Taher, Gilda Mercado, SJ Hannah, Anuj Parikh, Satya Shaw and Bilgin Turker.

The showcase will have public performances that will include industry professional who can bring the play to the widest audiences.

This stage is so important in the life of a piece. The showcase, which will be performed at Shetler Studios in New York in November will be seen by the public as well as many industry professionals. It will give the show the proper space it needs to grow and develop, Audience response will help gauge the readiness of the show and hopefully will attract the participants who will help take the show to the next stage.

Under the direction of Joan Kane, with sets by Wesley Cornwell, costumes by Cat Fisher and sound by Carl Welden, we are looking at the highest level of production value on a small budget. Our expenses include theater rental, cast and crew, sets, costume, sound and lighting, as well as promotional material. The full budget is $7000 with the remainder coming from ticket sales and already committed donations. ANDTheater Company is a 501(c)3 company, so all your donation are tax deductable to the extent of the law.

Now more than ever, theater with a message is so important. Federal funding for the arts is being swiftly eliminated. So it is up to us to keep theater alive. I am asking for your support in this endeavor to bring a new and exciting piece to the public!

Thank you for your support. I look forward to seeing you at the show!

It will give the show the proper space it needs to grow and develop, Audience response will help gauge the readiness of the show and hopefully will attract the participants who will help take the show to the next stage.Under the direction of Joan Kane, with sets by Wesley Cornwell, costumes by Cat Fisher and sound by Carl Welden, we are looking at the highest level of production value on a small budget. Our expenses include theater rental, cast and crew, sets, costume, sound and lighting, as well as promotional material. The full budget is $7000 with the remainder coming from ticket sales and already committed donations. ANDTheater Company is a 501(c)3 company, so all your donation are tax deductable to the extent of the law.Now more than ever, theater with a message is so important. Federal funding for the arts is being swiftly eliminated. So it is up to us to keep theater alive. I am asking for your support in this endeavor to bring a new and exciting piece to the public!Thank you for your support. I look forward to seeing you at the show!

story:
Bittersweet Arts Co.

Bittersweet Arts Co. is a collective of multi-talented artists whose unique ambitions and spirits are brought together through their love of experimentation and creative expression. 

Meet the Production Team

Ross Krakow (Playwright, Assistant Director) 

Mary Lumley (Director) 

Alec Silver (Movement Director)

Lesley Keller (Featured Choreographer of Wildflower Waltz and Starlight Sonata)

Freddy-May AbiSamra (Production Stage Manager)

Bo Kinney (Rehearsal Stage Manager)

Sami Hyman (Costume and Makeup Design)

Leah Silver (Artist)

Meet the Cast

Henry Weisel (Adam)

Alexis Allotta (Bear)

Moriah Martel (Frog)

Molly Madden (Honeybee/Sacred Spirit)

Madi Tozier (Honeybee/Sacred Spirit)

Ariel Triunfo (Honeybee/Sacred Spirit)

Sarah Cohen (Moth/Sacred Spirit)

Lara Garay (First Raven)

Rebecca Whittenhall (The Other Raven)

Addison Lewis (Salmon/Woman)

Kate Lass (Wolf)

Alicia Kraft (Snake)

Stranger on the River

About the Play

Stranger on the River is a new play written by Ross Krakow, brought to you by Bittersweet Arts Co. It tells the story of a man who has traveled far from home in search of holy wisdom. This is an idea play which closely examines the relationship between our culture and the greater community of life, and asks what it truly means to be human. Help us bring this full-length play to the Den Theatre.

Donate Today!

This is our first full-length production at an outside venue, and we could use your help. We are producing Stranger on the River on a minimal budget. Most of the money we are raising will be used to rent the 3A space at the Den Theatre. Additional costs come from practical needs, such as set, props, costumes, lighting, as well as printing posters and programs.

Your contribution will be directly supporting the creation of a new play, bringing audiences two weekends of innovative theatre in an intimate setting.

What Else Can I Do?

Can't make a donation! No problem! There are other ways to help!

  • Share this page with your family, friends, and on Facebook!
  • Come see us! Stranger on the River runs May 24 - June 3rd at the Den Theatre!

story:
My name is Nadia Hagen and I am the Artistic Director for Flam Chen. We are very excited about building our new show with your help!!

It is inspired by an old folk tale we are calling THE FISHERS WISH, It’s a fantastical fish tale  of desire and ambition told through new circus spectacle.

The characters all live in their own worlds, with their own definitions of happiness and success, which intersect each other through their journey.

The Wife propels the narrative through her force of will- she is clear and determined- she, like many controversial leaders in history believes very strongly in certain ideals and we inserted actual quotes from Hitler, Stalin and Mussolini, that she uses to justify her course of action.

We are grateful to have To Ree nee Wolf join our Flam Chen cast as the lead character.

Costume and Make-up/ design and production Budget: $1000

The Fisherman- played by Michael Larriva is the embodiment of the ocean- He is the liason for his wife’s desires but has no will of his own. He is also a quite a bad dancer.The fisherman engages in hIgh-flying acrobatics while reeling in his custom fire fishing pole.

Custom Fire Props and Pyro supplies: $1000

The Fish is the gift- giver. The omnipotent force of the universe that can manifest anything into being- Ruben Palma, Paul Weir and Zane Nichols are designing and building a 5X to scale, Angler puppet that will be operated live for the show.  A 4ft X 6ft clay model is being sculpted that will be cast in lightweight plastic and decorated with handcarved scales, glowing LED eyes and an enticing lure.

Larger than Life Bunraku style Angler Puppet: $3000

The Mermaids are the magical companions of the FISH. They embody forces of nature and the laws of attraction and desire. Paul Weir is the technical Director and Rigging Master for Flam Chen and The All Souls Procession, his inventive aerial apparatus, such as rope lyra and human operated block and tackle are some of the novel rigging effects we will employ to give our sea creatures weightlessness.

 Custom Counterweight fly system and aerial rigging; $1000

 Sound and lightscapes will be created through a collaboration with Adam Cooper-Terán, Heather Grey and DJ DirtyVerbs of Verbobala, known for their unique and provocative multi- disciplinary work. Ocean Scenes and backdrops will be large scale projected on a custom video scrim. Found footage and original illustrations will be animated using  Modul8 and Mad Mapper to create the  worlds of the wife the fisherman and the Fish and VJ'd Live.

Video Render and Presentation : $3000

The soundscape is a montage of electronica featuring Noisia, Amon Tobin, re- mixed with original recordings from Logan Phillips and live recordings of  actor’s narration. Backing tracks are then mixed live for the show.

Soundscape Mix : $1000

CAST and CREW: Fire performers, Directors, Aerialists, Designers, Riggers, Technical Directors, Lighting Directors and Stage hands are the Super Crew that makes theater happen. For every minute you see on stage, at least 4 hours of production, sweat and imagination have gone into that moment for it’s creation. We believe in honoring that commitment and fairly compensating every performer and producer for the time and equity they give to the project.

Rehearsal stipends and crew fees: $2000

Promotions: We need to get the word out!! We hope to sell out 4 nights in Tucson in early April so we will need handbills, FB boosted posts, ads in print mags and radio spots and YOU.

Marketing and Promotion Budget:$1000

We need you to help us raise 11K to build all the props, costumes, video backdrops, rigging components and take care of our cast and crew, as well as get the word out.

We hope you are as inspired as we are and you will help us bring 

THE FISHERS WISH to life!!

Please tell your friends and share our project on social media.

Live, Ensemble Theater needs your support.

"Fish, Fish, Answer our wish !"

story:
Le Théâtre de La Bourde est une nouvelle compagnie fondée par Pascale Marineau et Yann Aspirot. Elle s'engage à traiter de sujets d'actualités qui les touchent, les font réagir. Pour leur première production SEX(E), ils travailleront avec trois autres comédiens (Maxime Isabelle, Lilie-Rachel Morin et Jade Barshee) ainsi que deux collaborateurs au niveau de la production (Marie-Hélène Grisé et Olivia Watson). Cette première création collective est chapeautée par Pascale Marineau au texte et Yann Aspirot à la mise en scène. 

Qui dit spectacle, dit beaucoup de sous pour les coûts de la production. C'est pourquoi nous faisons appel à vous et à votre générosité afin de nous aider à donner vie à cette belle production. Tous les donateurs auront droit à une récompense! Visitez la page pour en savoir plus sur ces petites surprises. 

Tous les fonds amassés serviront à assurer les coûts de production (location de salle de répétition, location de la salle de spectacle, location d'éclairage, création de costumes, création du décor, publicité...etc).

Nous vous remercions d'avoir pris le temps de nous lire et de contribuer à ce projet qui nous tient beaucoup à coeur. Si l'envie vous prend de partager notre page, nous vous en serions très reconnaissants! Un énorme merci! 

Nous avons hâte de vous voir le 7-8-9-14-15-16 décembre, à l'Espace la Risée!

Les Bourdeux, du Théâtre de La Bourde.

xx

story:
Résumé du projet

Bonjour, 

Bienvenue sur notre campagne de socio-financement!

Studio 68 est une compagnie théâtrale indépendante émergente qui a pour but d'actualiser des oeuvres théâtrales par le biais de l’interdisciplinarité au travers de la danse, le théâtre et la musique.

Aidez-nous à donner un nouveau souffle au texte classique de La cantatrice chauve d'Eugène Ionesco dans une optique immersive et multidisciplinaire à travers laquelle se mêlent le rêve et la réalité.

 

Argument

Dans un hôpital psychiatrique, les patients M. et Mme Smith souffrent d'un trouble dissociatif de l'identité et se prennent pour des Anglais britanniques. À travers des tests cognitifs émis par des médecins, nous sommes projetés dans l'imaginaire des Smith dans lequel ils feront face à leurs alter egos: M. et Mme Martin.

 

Cette nouvelle adaptation de La cantatrice chauve explore le texte d'Eugène Ionesco en relation avec la maladie mentale et l'influence du subconscient sur la personne dans un monde réel dans lequel se mêle la fantaisie. 

 

Dates de représentations:

16 Avril 2020 (8h00 PM)

17 Avril 2020 (8h00 PM)

18 Avril 2020 (8h00 PM)

19 Avril 2020 (2h00 PM & 8h00 PM)

Lieu: Théâtre Mainline, 3997 Boul St-Laurent, Montréal, QC H2W 1Y4

 

Comment nous aider et ce que vous recevrez en retour

Pour réaliser le projet, nous avons besoin de votre participation à atteindre 3 610.00$ qui nous aidera à construire les décors, les costumes, louer les locaux de répétition ainsi qu'à diffuser la pièce. 

Budget: 

Diffusion: 720.00$

Costumes: 900.00$

Décors: 1 000.00$

Locaux de répétitions: 990.00$

 

En retour de vos dons, vous aurez droit à des prix tels qu'une copie numérique du journal de production, une mention dans le programme comme donateur, une invitation à la pièce et des affiches:

15.00 $ < 25.00$ = Mention dans le programme + billet

30.00 < 50.00$ = Mention dans le programme + billet + affiche

X > 50.00$ = Mention dans le programme + billet + affiche + journal de production (copie numérique) 

 

Votre impact sur le projet

En nous aidant à réaliser le projet, vous encouragez des artistes de la relève à développer leurs talents et vous contribuez à un enrichissement culturel de qualité. Vous soutenez aussi le développement artistique d'une compagnie en expansion avec des oeuvres théâtrales significatives. 

Avec votre support, nous espérons pouvoir présenter le projet à une plus grande démographie sur le plan et national et international et ainsi pouvoir contribuer au rayonnement de la société culturelle. 

 

Risques et défis

Cette adaptation de La cantatrice chauve est un grand défi à relevé par son envergure à grande échelle. Avec un texte comme celui-ci, il nous semblait important de démarquer notre esthétique des autres productions précédentes en allant chercher un univers fantastique et mystérieux tout en balançant l'aspect réaliste de la maladie mentale avec celui plus fantaisiste qu'offre le texte.

Pour ce faire, l'équipe est composée d'artistes professionnels et de jeunes professionnels pour aider à guider la structure au niveau de l'excellence artistique.  

 

Autres moyens de nous aider

Si vous n'êtes pas en mesure de nous aider, s'il vous plaît partagez notre campagne sur les réseaux sociaux pour que les gens soient mis au courant et pour que le projet puisse grandir!

story:
Who We Are

RAW is a process-based dance showcase of new solo work from five distinguished local dance-artists: Renay Aumiller, Murielle Elizéon, Megan Mazarick, Tommy Noonan, and Matthew Young. Gritty and unembellished, these dances take the audience on a journey through the topography of The Fruit to expose overlooked nooks and crannies, rooms which represent, visually and metaphorically, the unique minds of the artists inhabiting them.

Why Are We Doing This?

The idea for this shared performance came from the want and need for dialogue and conversation among dance artists who make interesting and varied work. How can we, as artists who are not necessarily emerging in the Durham dance community, grow and challenge how we make dance? Simultaneously, how can we support one another’s varying approaches to dance-making through dialogue, conversation, and community? And crucially, how can audiences authentically participate in the dance-making process?

Durham is such an appealing, engaged community that seeps into everything it offers its residents. But recently, with the rate of growth and change to the city, that aspect has felt threatened. This show is a response to the need to sustain that essence of our community – and that doesn’t necessarily mean growing in size or ambition. Sometimes community growth means nurturing the nuanced qualities of those who have been here all the while.

The Impact

We are needing to raise $1500, which is one third of the total amount needed to successfully launch RAW. So far, we have fundraised the remaining two-thirds through community workshops, master classes, and advanced ticket sales. This campaign will fund the venue rental and support a nominal wage for our production team.

We are a fiscally sponsored organization in which all of your donations are tax deductible. What a great time of year to Pay it Forward!

Risks & Challenges

RAD has an excellent track record of meeting our fundraising goals for the last 6 years. We are confident that with careful planning, incredible audience support for all of the involved artists, and the strong network of community support you provide, we will no doubt meet our financial and community-oriented goals for RAW.

Any self-produced creative project has some element of production, financial, or feasibility risk to it, but the beauty of RAW is that we are minimizing all of this! We want to present works that are low risk to the artists and audiences, yet exponentially fascinating to watch.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Volunteer as an usher for one of our shows.
  • Spread the word! Tell a friend!
  • Share our fundraising link on social media
  • Repost!
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to make it super easy!

story:
We are hoping for $6000.00 to help us get to Poland for the world premiere, June 30, 2016.  We are covering the costs of flying in 7 people to Poland, their accommodations, per diem and proper artist fees. We are very close to our goal, but need your help to make it to the finish line.


The Show

A mother and son, both descendants of Polish Holocaust survivors, decide to return to Poland in the hopes of finding their lost identity, and using their quest as a way to reconnect with each other. The plot, however, takes an unexpected turn when Michael and Mary discover a vibrant contemporary world of Jewish life in Poland. Unbeknownst to them, their journey will reveal a parallel narrative among Poles seeking a reconnection with lost Jewish identities. A new and unexpected story is born. We Keep Coming Back is performed by real-life mother and son, Mary Berchard and Michael Rubenfeld, as well as Katka Reszke, author of “Return of the Jew”. It is presented in a media rich environment, incorporating video footage, archival material, and music. Each performance will be followed by a short talk-back with the audience.

Co-created by: Michael Rubenfeld and Sarah Garton Stanley with Katka Reszke and Mary Berchard
Directed by: Sarah Garton Stanley
Associate direction by: Erika Batdorf
Performed by: Mary Berchard, Katka Reszke, Michael Rubenfeld
Scenography by: Trevor Schwellnus
Sound Design by: Lyon Smith
Associate Sound Designer: Nick di Gaetano
Produced by: : Sue Balint, Magda Rubenfeld Koralewska, Paweł Wojtalewski
Documentary Video Work by: Katka Reszke
Graphic design: Magda Rubenfeld Koralewska
Presented by: Selfconscious Theatre (CA), Nadaye Foundation (PL), Beit Krakow (PL) and the Suck and Blow Collective (CA/PL)

The team gratefully acknowledges the support of: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Poland, The Collaborations at Canada’s National Arts Centre English Theatre, The Canada Council for the Arts, The Ontario Arts Council, Kana Theatre, Consulate General of the Republic of Poland in Toronto, The Polish Culture Institute in New York, LOGTV, Ltd. Honoary patronage: The Canadian Embassy in Warsaw.

The Impact

This show has already begun to ignite a fascinating, essential series of conversations around contemporary Poland.  It is particularly unique to show this piece in Poland as "We Keep Coming Back" offers a complex diasporic Jewish perspective around contemporary Poland that goes well beyond some of the more traditional perspectives of Poland and Polish people as "the enemy".

We Keep Coming Back is a work that is seeking and advocating for a new, positive future for Judaism around the world -- and it does so by advocating for a more positive relationship for Jews in Poland.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you can't personally support us, but you think you know someone who might, please share this with them.  And If you value this conversation, or value the work, please consider making a contribution. 

    We Keep Coming Back is being spearheaded by a member of the Charles and Lynn Schusterman Family Foundation network and has been awarded a matching grant. Schusterman is a global organization that seeks to ignite the passion and unleash the power in young people to create positive change for themselves, the Jewish community and the broader world. Learn more about the Foundationhere.
story_txt:
We are hoping for $6000.00 to help us get to Poland for the world premiere, June 30, 2016.  We are covering the costs of flying in 7 people to Poland, their accommodations, per diem and proper artist fees. We are very close to our goal, but need your help to make it to the finish line.

  
The Show
 A mother and son, both descendants of Polish Holocaust survivors, decide
 to return to Poland in the hopes of finding their lost identity, and 
using their quest as a way to reconnect with each other. The plot, 
however, takes an unexpected turn when Michael and Mary discover a 
vibrant contemporary world of Jewish life in Poland. Unbeknownst to 
them, their journey will reveal a parallel narrative among Poles seeking
 a reconnection with lost Jewish identities. A new and unexpected story 
is born. We Keep Coming Back is performed by real-life mother and son, 
Mary Berchard and Michael Rubenfeld, as well as Katka Reszke, author of 
“Return of the Jew”. It is presented in a media rich environment, 
incorporating video footage, archival material, and music. Each 
performance will be followed by a short talk-back with the audience. 
Co-created by: Michael Rubenfeld and Sarah Garton Stanley with Katka Reszke and Mary Berchard
Directed by: Sarah Garton Stanley
Associate direction by: Erika Batdorf
Performed by: Mary Berchard, Katka Reszke, Michael Rubenfeld 
Scenography by: Trevor Schwellnus 
Sound Design by: Lyon Smith
Associate Sound Designer: Nick di Gaetano 
Produced by: : Sue Balint, Magda Rubenfeld Koralewska, Paweł Wojtalewski
Documentary Video Work by: Katka Reszke
Graphic design: Magda Rubenfeld Koralewska

English Theatre, The Canada Council for the Arts, The Ontario Arts 
Council, Kana Theatre, Consulate General of the Republic of Poland in 
Toronto, The Polish Culture Institute in New York, LOGTV, Ltd.

story:
ABOUT 'BIGGER THAN YOU, BIGGER THAN ME'

Beth, a public school teacher living in Washington DC, wants to connect with her troubled students and make a difference in their lives.  She strikes up an intimate friendship with Adele, a new teacher at school.   Adele reveals to Beth an alarming premonition that leaves Beth shaken.  Beth’s boyfriend Tucker, who works at Homeland Security, dismisses Adele as delusional.  The tension builds as Beth questions her friend’s motives and mental stability.  The play catapults to its chilling conclusion where everyday life is irreversibly altered.

WHAT THE CRITICS SAY ABOUT 'BIGGER THAN YOU, BIGGER THAN ME'

“If there is a post-9/11 theater in America…it just got bigger than before….Coughlin asks us to ask: Which is crazier, to foresee lurking and imminent danger or to be blinkered and inured to danger altogether? In so doing Coughlin puts her finger on our very pulse and diagnoses the collective psychosis with which we all now must cope.” – John Stoltenberg, DC Metro Theater Arts

THE CREATIVE TEAM

This theatrical enterprise brings together long-time collaborators Celia Pilkington and Adam Thorburn.  Pilkington and Thorburn studied together as theater students at Sarah Lawrence College.  Since graduating, they’ve joined forces on numerous theater projects, including STUYVESANT TOWN: THIS IS YOUR HOME, FREED SPEECH and the award-winning NOVEMBER SPAWNED A MONSTER.  This new undertaking is one of their most audacious and ambitious projects yet. 

BIOGRAPHIES

CELIA PILKINGTON (Actor) received her B.A. from Sarah Lawrence College.  She is a member of Actors Equity Association and SAG-AFTRA, and has studied at The Ensemble Studio Theatre, Primary Stages, T. Schreiber Studios and Studio 4 Acting School.  She has performed in numerous Off-Off Broadway productions including STUYVESANT TOWN: THIS IS YOUR HOME, which was presented at The Signature Theater in New York City. THE LOVE DEPARTMENT, an original radio play honoring the Golden Age of Radio.  FREED SPEECH portraying Linda Lovelace.  HIROSHIMA with music by Yoko Ono at Theater for the New City.  She has also appeared in numerous television shows and independent films.

ADAM THORBURN (Director) is an award-winning playwright and free-lance writer.  He received his MFA in Theater from Sarah Lawrence College.  Thorburn adapted and directed FREED SPEECH, a staged-reading of testimony taken from the first public hearings on pornography and civil rights.  FREED SPEECH, which commemorated the publication of the book In Harm’s Way: The Pornography Civil Rights Hearings edited by Andrea Dworkin and Catharine A. MacKinnon, was performed at the New School for Social Research in 1998.  Thorburn was commissioned by the Citizen’s Housing and Planning Council to create the play STUYVESANT TOWN: THIS IS YOUR HOME.  Using primary source documents, STUYVESANT TOWN told the story of the fight to desegregate the New York housing complex in the 1940s and 50s.  Thorburn was commissioned by the estate of feminist icon Andrea Dworkin to create a play based on one of Dworkin’s unpublished manuscripts.  The final piece, entitled AFTERMATH, was performed for six nights at the Jefferson Market Library in Greenwich Village in May 2014 and again as part of the United Solo Theater Festival on Theater Row in October 2014.  A production of AFTERMATH was staged in Montreal by the Waterworks Company in September 2015; this fall the Waterworks Company will be touring Canada with AFTERMATH, bringing the production to Toronto and Ottawa.  Thorburn’s critical essays have appeared in Gay Community News, The Humanist, and Polari Magazine.

KATHRYN COUGHLIN (Playwright) has had plays developed and produced by Field Trip Theater, Rorschach Theatre, Inkwell Theatre, 1MPF, DC-Page-to-Stage, St. Bonaventure University, The Disreputables and Meat and Bone Theatre Company.  Her plays include BIGGER THAN YOU, BIGGER THAN ME, MORE THAN BEFORE, SLIP, THEY SAY THERE'S A WAR GOING ON, SOUNDS OF ALARM and ALL WE HAVE.  As a dramaturg, Coughlin has worked with Taffety Punk Theatre Company, The DC Queer Theatre Festival, Young Playwrights’ Theater and served as the literary manager and producer of the Source Festival for five years.  

Studio 28 Productions is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Studio 28 Productions must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
We are so excited to announce that The Dirty Blondes are FRIGID @ Horse Trade Resident Artists

WHICH MEANS - we have a home to develop our work for the 2016/17 Season! Instead of spending time looking for theater space and resources in this crazy city, we get to spend our time being creative and making our next shows the best possible they can be! Not to mention The Kraine Theater and Under St. Mark's Theaters are two incredible places to get to perform in! This is an incredible next step for us - for stability for the company, and artistically freeing. If you weren't able to make Monday's show but want to support us - we have two more days left on our Indiegogo campaign and will be truly grateful for your support! All funds raised will go towards developing new work and supporting all the artists who make our work possible.


Who We Are

The Dirty Blondes was founded by us, Ashley J. Jacobson and Elizabeth Sarkady, in 2012 after we produced the first incarnation of The American Play at the 2012 Planet Connections Theatre Festivity - a play that takes  a dark  and sinister look at the consequences of stereotypical masculinity and issues of sexual violence. Even though the play was met with critical and audience acclaim (oh, hello Outstanding Production of a New Play - one of the festival's top honors!), we, personally, were often treated with varying degrees of skepticism. Responses ranged from a vague intimation of doubt to a straight-out insulting dismissal of our work. “YOU did that? But it’s so interesting/dark/arresting/sophisticated! …” was often the response. While we laughed off their incredulity, it became more and more obvious that because we were women, people’s expectations of our capabilities as artists, and especially as producers and leaders, were discouragingly low. People simply didn’t believe we were capable of creating and producing valuable work - especially when the content was dark, complex and arresting. It seemed that if people were to accept us as artists it was only if our work was easily categorized and therefore easily dismissed. Simply because of our femininity, some incorrectly assume us to be lesser artists.

We’ve taken to heart how much the identity and voice of the artist matters. There are so many incredible stories waiting to be told by artists who have been undervalued and who society has expected the least from.

We’ve developed an activist mission to focus on creating more opportunities for theater makers who are using their art to contribute to an important social dialogue and to celebrate their identity.  We’ve spent the last four years holding this idea close and keeping busy! We’ve produced four original works (to rave reviews and even more awards), four devised works, five Play-in-a-Day Festivals, three readings, a special partnership with Co-Op Theater East, and a short play festival featuring works by artists based in Detroit, Michigan.

We believe that artists, especially those who our society expects the least from, should let their bad-ass flag fly, and we need your help to make our 5th Season even more powerful!


The Bombshell Benefit - 8pm Monday, May 9 @ The Gene Frankel

Instead of making knick-knacks and printing posters, we're giving you, our devoted audience, something we know you'll love: a revue performance and roaring party!

The evening will feature live music and a scene from The Britney Project (a musical improv dramedy exploring  grand puppetry of pop culture with a certain pop star), a scene from The American Play (winner of Overall Excellence in Playwrighting and part of the SoHo Playhouse “Best of Fest: Fringe Encore Series") and a sneak preview of a new work by Ashley.

We’re also highlighting some of the relationships we’ve made with kickass playwrights through our Play-in-a-Day Festivals by asking a few alums to write a new play which will revive a prompt from one of our past five festivals:-

  • Alexis Roblan - seven deadly sins ('Sin in the City')

  • Stephanie Swirsky - a current newspaper headline ('Deadline')

  • Rebecca Jane Stokes - a crazy internet comment ('The Comments Section')

  • Hope Weiner - set on the subway ('F*ck the Summit')

On top of all of these great performances, we will have a silent auction, drinks, and snacks for you to enjoy!

Your Impact

This year, we’re really looking to step it up. Our top priority is to increase pay for all our artists - most of whom work 2-3 jobs in order to stay in New York and pursue their passions.  Ensuring that we can pay those who share their talents and passion with us is not only a measure of good faith - that each artist knows how much we truly value their time and hard work, and reaffirming one of our key values to never exploit someone’s passion - but paying artists is a necessary expense to keep our company growing and making the best possible new work. We have been lucky enough to work with some of the best designers, performers, and directors in the Off and Off-Off Broadway business and we can only keep doing that if we are able to increase our pay. Next year, this is where most of the money we make will go - TO THE ARTISTS’ THEMSELVES.


We’ll have an exciting 2016/2017 announcement for you on May 9! But here’s what we can tell you so far…

World Premiere of a NEW PLAY by Artistic Director Ashley J. Jacobson.

Relaunching THE BRITNEY PROJECT - an improvised full-length play with dance, live music, film/video centered on a certain infamous pop star.

SEX by Mae West - an interactive staged reading of the sex symbol’s iconic Broadway Play deemed so scandalous  West was arrested for "corrupting the morals of youth."

3 Play in a Day Festivals - we bring a group of daring and salacious playwrights, directors, and actors to conceive, write, and perform several short plays over the course of 24 hours.

3 Beta Series Readings - a reading series with a sole objective to further develop and workshop a script through a free showcase & talkback for potential producers, directors, actors, writers, investors, donors, and audiences complete with coffee, bagels, and mimosas to help keep the moderated Q&A going.

Your contributions will go to making up to 36 nights of performances! We can't do it without you.


Other Ways You Can Help

We WISH everyone we loved lived in New York with us, but we understand that some people enjoy things like grass and nature and being blissfully unaware of the meaning of the phrase “trash tornado.” What you can do is share our campaign and donate if you can. We'll still send you a lovely thank you card and you'll be forever in our hearts.

#BombshellBenefit #TheDirtyBlondes

The Dirty Blondes is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of The Dirty Blondes must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.
