story:
"The [U.S.] election is a time where we can [approach] a lot of themes", explains director Georges Bigot. "Manipulation, Power, Truth, Lie, Shadow, Light...and also Fear. It is the reason why I propose to Theatre Y to create an ensemble and to work on this tragedy of Macbeth; a tragedy where each word is a painting. It is a monument of art...to our basic fears and terrors. It is very important to share...and to talk about all this fear.”

This fall, Theatre Y will produce its most artistically ambitious project to date as part of the Chicago Shakespeare 400 International Arts Festival! Invited by the renowned Chicago Shakespeare Theatre, and under the direction of French theatre luminary Georges Bigot, Theatre Y will explore the nightmare of William Shakespeare's MACBETH. 

It is Bigot's' vision, and Theatre Y's hope, that, through an intimate staging of MACBETH, we can better understand our modern world, our politics, ourselves, and our interconnection.  "For me, art and theatre belong to everybody. And it is a food...a kind of agriculture for the soul".

We open October 19, 2016 at The Chopin Theatre in Chicago. And we need your help to make it happen!

Who are the Theatre Y Ensemble?

Theatre Y is dedicated to the international laboratory with an ever-diversifying group of collaborators from many lands.  To put it succinctly, we seek formidable allies worldwide and we produce work with them.

Over the last ten years, Theatre Y has garnered both critical and public acclaim for our daring and passionate work. Playing to sold-out audiences, Theatre Y's productions feature award-winning actors from the Chicago community and have been highly praised by theatre critics throughout the city. Chicago Stage Review has called Theatre Y's productions "among the bravest and best of theater in Chicago", and we have attracted a loyal and discerning audience.

MACBETH will be the first production created by the brand new Theatre Y Ensemble, established and directed by Georges Bigot. To read more about this exciting step in Theatre Y's evolution, visit our ensemble page.

Who is Georges Bigot?

Central to Ariane Mnouchkine’s Theatre du Soleil during the 80’s and 90’s, Georges Bigot is one of France’s most lauded contemporary actors. Known all over the world for highly physical ensemble work, his style reads like “mask in human form that, when turned towards an audience, hits you like a punch in the stomach”, Bigot “lights up our imaginations and overwhelms us even in memory” (Olivier Berardi).

Sixteen years ago, as a student at Northern Illinois University, Theatre Y founder and Artistic Director, Melissa Lorraine, studied with Bigot. "He was the first to shatter my expectations" remembers Lorraine. After working with him for one month, she felt "like I had never performed before; I didn't actually understand anything about the theatre; that I had never seen a real artist on stage until Georges Bigot". 

Why MACBETH?

To Bigot, MACBETH is "both a nightmare and a cure". To be sure, there are witches, ghosts, shrieking owls, and enough stormy weather to make anyone sleep no more, but how can a tragic tale of ruthless ambition, murder, and tyranny be hopeful? "When we understand that we have escaped from the ugly nightmare, we are so happy we are still alive...we are maybe more [appreciative of] this life and more respectful. It's a medicine from the human soul. For me, Shakespeare wrote a cure".

As for how we can best tell this nightmare on a very tight budget and in a very intimate space, Mssr. Bigot is blunt: "We have no choice but to do theatre with everything because we have nothing". 

"I am so excited to be telling this story with Georges," says Lorraine. "He has a wild and special vision for it, something piercing and vicious. Relentless. I believe Georges tells the truth, demands that everyone around him tells the truth, and that Shakespeare does the same. The two of them put together could create a cocktail that will wake up the masses. This is the hope."

Why are you taking a full year to produce MACBETH?

Bigot requires full-commitment from the ensemble. We are analyzing the words of William Shakespeare in painstaking detail so we are acting "at the foot of the letter", stripping away all pretense and assumptions, looking deep within ourselves, relearning how to walk, talk, dance, and move so we fully embody, not just the characters, but the power, the manipulation, the fear, the paranoia, and the supernatural soliciting they represent. 

"I feel privileged to be a witness to this work" says Lorraine. "I feel privileged to be in the room and witness these actors being pushed to a refining, razor's edge". To put it simply, if the purpose of the typical rehearsal process is to put all the pieces of a production puzzle together, Georges will not allow us to even assemble the puzzle until each piece is meticulously hand-crafted to perfection.

Sounds hard.

It is! But it's also very rewarding. After all, "the labor we delight in physics pain." : )

I want to help! What do you need?

Like any good, small, non-profit, art-focused theater company, we are quite adept at getting the most out of every penny we have. We have already been able to pay for Georges' travel and for rehearsal spaces up to this point. But, as this is our most ambitious production in our ten-year history, we hath not foisons enough to fill up our will. 

In order to properly execute Georges Bigot's bold vision for MACBETH, we are asking all art and theatre lovers to consider contributing a total of $10,000. This generous amount will enable us to pay for Georges' future travel and lodging, rehearsal space going forward, costumes, props, set and lighting design, and marketing materials. 

Actors will receive a small stipend that is already budgeted and is not part of this campaign. As Melissa Lorraine testifies: "This is a real labor of love that Georges has gathered around himself".

That's a lot of money! What do I get? 

Because learning from and witnessing the dynamic power of Georges Bigot's creative mind is such a special experience, we want to share it with the city and the people of Chicago as much as possible. That is why most of our donation perks include not only complimentary tickets to our production of MACBETH, but also invitations to our September Launch Party with the cast and Georges, special previews and talk-backs, as well as an exclusive reception with Georges.

One very generous donor will be given property in Scotland, and the right to be called a Laird or Lady of Scotland. That's right. For our top donor, we will actually buy you actual land in actual Scotland - 100 square feet of it to be exact - through Highland Titles. Not only will you be able to refer to yourself as a Laird or Lady of Glencoe, but you will also have a tree planted in your honor, camping access to Keil Hill, and you will be helping preserve the lands and wild life of the Scottish Highlands.

Theatre Y is a registered 501(c)(3) non-profit, so any amount you can donate is tax deductible. Your generosity will be forever appreciated by all of us at Theatre Y.

Are you trying to win us with honest trifles only to betray's in deepest consequence?

Nice one! And never!

Live theatre, by it's nature, is unpredictable. We can memorize all our lines, commit blocking to muscle memory, and rehearse a show for an entire year and still be surprised during any given performance. Because this is a performance art, there is always a chance of shows being canceled or dates being postponed due to weather, performer health, lightening striking a telephone pole outside the venue, or some rump-faced runyion saying "Macbeth" out loud in the theater and putting a hex on the whole thing.  

However, Theatre Y has an excellent track record of performance durability. Also, over the years we have launched several successful crowd funding campaigns, including one other IndieGogo and two Kickstarter campaigns that were all fully funded and delivered on time!

We will not be bound in to saucy doubts and fears!

When and where does the show run?

We open at The Chopin Theatre on October 19 and run through December 4, 2016. Your contribution will help ensure that this production is as dynamic and gripping as Mssr. Bigot's vision. Visit www.theatre-y.com for all show and ticket information.

What if I'm not able to donate money at this time?

Even if you can't make a financial contribution to our production, please share this campaign with your friends and family across social media. Also, visit the Theatre Y website, Like us on Facebook, join our mailing list, and consider donating your time to help us. We're always looking for good, responsible theatre lovers to help with our shows!
story_txt:
"The [U.S.] election is a time where we can [approach] a lot of themes", explains director Georges Bigot. "Manipulation, Power, Truth, Lie, Shadow, Light...and also Fear. It is the reason why I propose to Theatre Y to create an ensemble and to work on this tragedy of Macbeth; a tragedy where each word is a painting. It is a monument of art...to our basic fears and terrors. It is very important to share...and to talk about all this fear.”
This fall, Theatre Y will produce its most artistically ambitious project to date as part of the Chicago Shakespeare 400 International Arts Festival! Invited by the renowned Chicago Shakespeare Theatre, and under the direction of French theatre luminary Georges Bigot, Theatre Y will explore the nightmare of William Shakespeare's MACBETH. 
It is Bigot's' vision, and Theatre Y's hope, that, through an intimate staging of MACBETH, we can better understand our modern world, our politics, ourselves, and our interconnection.  "For me, art and theatre belong to everybody. And it is a food...a kind of agriculture for the soul".
We open October 19, 2016 at The Chopin Theatre in Chicago. And we need your help to make it happen!
Who are the Theatre Y Ensemble?

Theatre Y is dedicated to the international laboratory with an ever-diversifying group of collaborators from many lands.  To put it succinctly, we seek formidable allies worldwide and we produce work with them.

Over the last ten years, Theatre Y has garnered both critical and public acclaim for our daring and passionate work. Playing to sold-out audiences, Theatre Y's productions feature award-winning actors from the Chicago community and have been highly praised by theatre critics throughout the city. Chicago Stage Review has called Theatre Y's productions "among the bravest and best of theater in Chicago", and we have attracted a loyal and discerning audience.
MACBETH will be the first production created by the brand new Theatre Y Ensemble, established and directed by Georges Bigot. To read more about this exciting step in Theatre Y's evolution, visit our ensemble page.
Who is Georges Bigot?
Central to Ariane Mnouchkine’s Theatre du Soleil during the 80’s and 90’s, Georges Bigot is one of France’s most lauded contemporary actors. Known all over the world for highly physical ensemble work, his style reads like “mask in human form that, when turned towards an audience, hits you like a punch in the stomach”, Bigot “lights up our imaginations and overwhelms us even in memory” (Olivier Berardi).



Sixteen years ago, as a student at Northern Illinois University, Theatre Y founder and Artistic Director, Melissa Lorraine, studied with Bigot. "He was the first to shatter my expectations" remembers Lorraine. After working with him for one month, she felt "like I had never performed before; I didn't actually understand anything about the theatre; that I had never seen a real artist on stage until Georges Bigot". 



Why MACBETH?
To Bigot, MACBETH is "both a nightmare and a cure". To be sure, there are witches, ghosts, shrieking owls, and enough stormy weather to make anyone sleep no more, but how can a tragic tale of ruthless ambition, murder, and tyranny be hopeful? "When we understand that we have escaped from the ugly nightmare, we are so happy we are still alive...we are maybe more [appreciative of] this life and more respectful. It's a medicine from the human soul. For me, Shakespeare wrote a cure".



As for how we can best tell this nightmare on a very tight budget and in a very intimate space, Mssr. Bigot is blunt: "We have no choice but to do theatre with everything because we have nothing". 





"I am so excited to be telling this story with Georges," says Lorraine. "He has a wild and special vision for it, something piercing and vicious. Relentless. I believe Georges tells the truth, demands that everyone around him tells the truth, and that Shakespeare does the same. The two of them put together could create a cocktail that will wake up the masses. This is the hope."

Why are you taking a full year to produce MACBETH?
Bigot requires full-commitment from the ensemble. We are analyzing the words of William Shakespeare in painstaking detail so we are acting "at the foot of the letter", stripping away all pretense and assumptions, looking deep within ourselves, relearning how to walk, talk, dance, and move so we fully embody, not just the characters, but the power, the manipulation, the fear, the paranoia, and the supernatural soliciting they represent. 

"I feel privileged to be a witness to this work" says Lorraine. "I feel privileged to be in the room and witness these actors being pushed to a refining, razor's edge". To put it simply, if the purpose of the typical rehearsal process is to put all the pieces of a production puzzle together, Georges will not allow us to even assemble the puzzle until each piece is meticulously hand-crafted to perfection.

Sounds hard.
It is! But it's also very rewarding. After all, "the labor we delight in physics pain." : )
   I want to help! What do you need? Like any good, small, non-profit, art-focused theater company, we are quite adept at getting the most out of every penny we have. We have already been able to pay for Georges' travel and for rehearsal spaces up to this point. But, as this is our most ambitious production in our ten-year history, we hath not foisons enough to fill up our will. 
In order to properly execute Georges Bigot's bold vision for MACBETH, we are asking all art and theatre lovers to consider contributing a total of $10,000. This generous amount will enable us to pay for Georges' future travel and lodging, rehearsal space going forward, costumes, props, set and lighting design, and marketing materials. 
Actors will receive a small stipend that is already budgeted and is not part of this campaign. As Melissa Lorraine testifies: "This is a real labor of love that Georges has gathered around himself".
That's a lot of money! What do I get? 
Because learning from and witnessing the dynamic power of Georges Bigot's creative mind is such a special experience, we want to share it with the city and the people of Chicago as much as possible. That is why most of our donation perks include not only complimentary tickets to our production of MACBETH, but also invitations to our September Launch Party with the cast and Georges, special previews and talk-backs, as well as an exclusive reception with Georges.
One very generous donor will be given property in Scotland, and the right to be called a Laird or Lady of Scotland. That's right. For our top donor, we will actually buy you actual land in actual Scotland - 100 square feet of it to be exact - through Highland Titles. Not only will you be able to refer to yourself as a Laird or Lady of Glencoe, but you will also have a tree planted in your honor, camping access to Keil Hill, and you will be helping preserve the lands and wild life of the Scottish Highlands.
Theatre Y is a registered 501(c)(3) non-profit, so any amount you can donate is tax deductible. Your generosity will be forever appreciated by all of us at Theatre Y.

    Are you trying to win us with honest trifles only to betray's in deepest consequence?
Nice one! And never! Live theatre, by it's nature, is unpredictable. We can memorize all our lines, commit blocking to muscle memory, and rehearse a show for an entire year and still be surprised during any given performance. Because this is a performance art, there is always a chance of shows being canceled or dates being postponed due to weather, performer health, lightening striking a telephone pole outside the venue, or some rump-faced runyion saying "Macbeth" out loud in the theater and putting a hex on the whole thing.

We open at The Chopin Theatre on October 19 and run through December 4, 2016. Your contribution will help ensure that this production is as dynamic and gripping as Mssr. Bigot's vision. Visit www.theatre-y.com for all show and ticket information.

We're always looking for good, responsible theatre lovers to help with our shows!

story:
Help fund Porpentine's Upcoming Production, Michael Frayn’s Copenhagen, January 21 - January 31, 2015 at the Nave Gallery, 155 Powderhouse Blvd, Somerville, MA 02144.

About Porpentine

Porpentine is a Boston area theatre company founded in 2013 and dedicated to the production of classic plays of all time periods. Our mission is to make live theatre an affordable option for all people, so that there is real choice in entertainment and that human interaction is celebrated in both the plays we perform and the audience experience.


The Production: Frayn's Copenhagen

Porpentine is pleased to announce its January 2015 residency at the Nave Gallery in Somerville, MA, where we will perform Michael Frayn’s Copenhagen.

In Copenhagen, Frayn re-imagines the famous 1941 meeting of physicists Niels Bohr and Werner Heisenberg, which has been subject to much speculation. Heisenberg was Bohr's finest student and then colleague. His warm relationship with his mentor was damaged beyond repair during this 1941 meeting in Copenhagen. No one knows what exactly the two men discussed. What did Heisenberg believe could be done, and should be done, about atomic bombs? What did he want from Bohr? These questions call up many powerful issues and emotions involving Nazi Germany and nuclear war.

Frayn's Copenhagen revolves around Heisenberg and Bohr's falling out over the moral ramifications of what they have done. The spirits of the two men and Bohr’s wife Margrethe, meet after death to attempt to answer the question, why did Heisenberg come to Copenhagen? As they debate and reject possible answers to that question, the conversation addresses nuclear power and its control, the rationale behind building or not building an atomic bomb, the uncertainty of the past and the inevitability of the future.

Copenhagen is Porpentine’s second production, following a successful run of Robert Bolt’s A Man For All Seasons earlier this year. R. Nelson Lacey, Floyd Richardson, and Ann Carpenter portray Heisenberg, Bohr, and Margrethe. Jon Taie directs. Sharon Lacey designs sets and graphics.

For tickets, visit Brown Paper Tickets.

What We Need & What You Get

We are committed to making live theatre affordable! Keeping ticket prices low means we rely on your generous support to cover our expenses.

Your support helps us pay our actors for their work! They enrich our experience of the world, and we appreciate it. Copenhagen has few characters, which equals fewer actors to pay, but for a small company, these modest stipends are a big expense.

If you aren't in the business of producing plays, you may not know that the playwright (and his publisher and agent) also needs to be paid for his work. Buying the rights to the play is the biggest cost. Without the rights, the show simply can't go on.

We are grateful to our venue, the Nave Gallery, for hosting us in January. Thank you, Nave.

And thank you, patrons and friends! We have some delightful goodies and perks to show our gratitude.

The Impact

2015 marks the 70th anniversary of the bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki. It is timely to bring you Copenhagen, a powerful play about the complex ethical questions that arise when physics is applied to the creation of atomic weapons.

Our first production, Robert Bolt's A Man For All Seasons, also dealt with issues of the human conscience. We hope to continue to produce plays that are not performed frequently in the New England area, which are entertaining, challenging and beautiful.

Other Ways You Can Help

Come to the show!  Please spread the word about Copenhagen and about our Indiegogo campaign.

Some of Our Perks

$100 Porpentine Woodblock Print

$25 Porpentine Plush Toy by Gund (3 inches tall)

$15 Peace Postcards

$10 Copenhagen Poster + Christmas Peace Stickers


$5 Porpentine Button

story:
Constructive Outrage Productions is "Sounding Off" for suicide prevention by presenting a piece of provocative story telling in the theatrical piece, 2 Dangerous People Sharing 1 Small Space.  To do this, we need your help to bring this production to life!!!

The piece chronicles the journey's of Maynard (Played By Paul Moon) and Ginny (Connie Castanzo) though a witty drama as they try to find themselves together.

Constructive Outrage Productions is determined to bring light to the sensitive, controversial topics that people are too afraid to touch or go near, but to do so in a way that incorporates the art of story telling in an effort to reach the masses.  We strive to use theater as the vehicle to not only bring awareness to the harsh reality that suicide rates have continued to climb throughout the years, but to use it to touch people into creating a catalyst for change to help prevent these tragic outcomes from continuing.

story:
Short Summary

We are Ugly Button Productions and this is our first play, On the Edge!

On the Edge is about a man named Todd who gets found out by his roommate, Gwen, as he is on the verge of committing suicide. While she argues as to why he needs to step back and look at his life more positively, he uses philosophy and reason as opposed to anger or heightened emotion to explain why he should go through with it. We hope that On the Edge gives a good insight as to how people live with depression and anxiety, and how a person can rationalize things that to many people don't seem rational at all.

With your funds, you can help more people to get interested in the topic of mental health, rid these issues of social stigma, and possibly get not only acceptance, but help from the community.

What We Need & What You Get

We need approximately $1000 total to put on the play in the Toronto Fringe Festival.
$750 will go towards a participation fee which provides us with a production space for the duration of the festival.
The rest of the remaining funds will go towards costumes, props and set pieces, along with programmes and advertising.

If we don't reach our total goal, the funds will go toward our savings for the participation cost, as that is the most expensive.

For those of you who donate $10, you can receive a set of Ugly Button or On the Edge stickers, OR an Ugly Button pen.

If you donate $15, you can receive a copy of Todd's suicide note as seen in the trailer, OR an Ugly Button postcard signed from the creators of the play.

If you donate $20, you can receive a page of the original script.

If you donate $30, you can receive an On the Edge notebook.

And if you donate $45, you can receive an Ugly Button tote bag!

Please let us know which perk you choose if the amount you donate has multiple options!

The Impact

On The Edge is a project that we hope will raise awareness of depression and anxiety, and the people who suffer these conditions.

We aim to provide entertainment and a time at the theatre the audience will have a hard time forgetting by means of pushing boundaries and introducing new ways of thinking about ideas most people take for granted.

This project means a lot to, not only me, but the people who have contributed to our play already, through our benefit concert, and we hope that it'll mean a lot to all of you as well!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate, it would still mean a lot to us if you could spread the word and send a link out for others to donate.

Also, keep an eye on our Twitter page for information on our upcoming events. We have a number of events in the works right now such as benefit concerts, public fundraisers to raise UBP awareness, and possibly readings of some other short plays that you do not want to miss!

story:
*NOTE*

Part II of this campaign can be found here: https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/aces-inc-s-annual-summer-scholarship-part-ii/x/6936380. 

Thank you to everyone who contributed to Round I of our campaign. So far, we have raised around $3000, through Indiegogo and outside means. This means we still have $2000 left to raise! 

Who are we?

ACES Inc. Academy for Comprehensive Excellence and Scholarship is a nonprofit organization that provides New York City high school students with the skills necessary to turn an interest in under-represented extracurricular activities, specifically New York City street handball, into a means of attaining higher education opportunities.

What do we do?

For the past two years, we have run a summer program in parks across New York City, offering free eight hour-long handball clinics twice a week, while providing snacks, drinks, training, mentorship, handball equipment, and tournaments to our attendees. 

At the end of each summer, we host a tournament which award a total of $5,000 in scholarship money to the winners. This money can only be collected after the players graduate and provide proof of admission into a college/university, a technical institution, or any other approved institution of higher education. 

The success of this program has been accomplished by a dedicated staff of qualified athletic coaches, academic mentors, and volunteers who pride themselves in creating a safe and fun learning environment where both athletic and personal growth can be fostered.

Our Community

The community we serve is made up of high school students who generally hail from working-class to lower middle-class neighborhoods in Brooklyn and Queens. 

They practice handball day and night to improve their game, putting hours of blood, sweat, and tears onto the courts. 

However, due to its status as a street sport, handball has not received as much funding from foundations or universities, despite being such a quintessential part of New York City. Because of this, scholarship opportunities for handball players are scarce to nonexistent, making it difficult for students to transform their passion for handball into further academic development, an opportunity often afforded to basketball and football players.

EVERY DOLLAR COUNTS

Over the past years, we have brought together over 120 students across New York City, 95% of which come from the New York City Public School System, So far, we have given out $10,000 in scholarship money. 

But at this point in time, we need YOUR help more than ever!

This year, we hope to raise $5000 for our scholarship fund. Any additional amount raised will go to either running our clinics or future scholarship funds. Even if you can spare just a dollar, your help will contribute to the furthering of our players’ futures. You will be funding more than just a scholarship, you will be giving inner city high school students the chance to thrive in a positive environment, grow as a person and as an athlete, create strong friendships, and open academic doors. Your donation would be an immense help as we work to empower our students, and would also provide support for an underrepresented New York City community and sport.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to support our campaign financially, don’t worry! You can also help by raising awareness of this fundraiser via social media, word-of-mouth, etc. And if you would like to volunteer/participate in one of ACES Inc.’s events, be sure to like and follow our Facebook page at:

https://www.facebook.com/pages/ACES-Inc-Academy-for-Comprehensive-Excellence-and-Scholarship/355318837858837?fref=ts

and to check out our website at:

http://acesincacademy.org/

Thank you all so much!

Note: More perks coming soon!

Note: More perks coming soon!

story:
Lehigh Valley Dance Exchange | Promoting Artistry, Connections & Opportunity
lvdanceexchange.org | lehighvalleydanceexchange@gmail.com
484.599.0252

Join Lehigh Valley Dance Exchange in promoting artistry, connections, & opportunity by making a tax deductible donation today! Your investments will facilitate the best of the best to our Lehigh Valley dance community.

LVDE sprouted in 2009, a strong professional dance presence was lacking. By bringing together the talents, various arts programs, organizations, and beautiful facilities in the community; LVDE has successfully stimulated arts professionals to network, share performance costs, locate dancers, show and make work, host master classes, and embrace the potential of professional dance in the Lehigh Valley.

LVDE has produced;

9 Cabaret Nights

Hired over 27 Teaching Artists

Hosted 5 choreography commissions

Engaged hundreds of local dancers and audience members

And on March 7 – 8, 2015 we will embark on our third annual SpringUP Dance festival.

With support from our partners and sponsors (including Northampton Community College and Lehigh Valley Arts Council - PPA Project Stream support) the SpringUP Dance festival has been a HUGE success with over 135 dancers in attendance in 2014 (this was a %30 increase from 2013). This festival has been designed to serve the community free of charge and with your contribution we can continue to grow.

For SpringUP 2015 we have another dynamic roster of artists lined up. January will also feature a residency and choreography commission with dancer maker Antonio Brown. With these ambitious engagements in our future, we are asking for your help.

Every dollar raised will go directly towards artists fees, travel and accommodations for SpringUP faculty, marketing, and overhead expenses in making sure we provide what the community deserves.

Thank you for supporting the Lehigh Valley Dance Exchange and our 2015 programming through a tax deductible donation today!

Alex Reekie, Sarah Carlson, Jessica Marino (LVDE)
Special thanks to Tabatha Robinson-Scott (SpringUP Dance Festival Partner)

story:
Help jump-start and save KENTUCKY STAGE(S) spectacular 2014-15 season!

Kentucky Stage(s) is Southern Kentucky’s Equity Professional Regional Theatre in residence at the Southern Kentucky Performing Arts Center (SKyPAC.)

Our great first season included “The Lion in Winter” with guest artist Andrew Prine, “The Glass Menagerie” (in honor of our inspiration, regional actor and force of nature, Pat Taylor), “Working: a Musical,” “The Importance of Being Earnest,” and “Lombardi.”

We’ve planned an exceptional second season: “A Streetcar Named Desire” opens September 25, followed by Neil Simon’s “Laughter on the 23rd Floor,” “A Kentucky Christmas Carol,” “The Mystery of Irma Vep,” and the astonishing musical that takes place in our own back yard, “Floyd Collins.” For more details on the season and dates, check us out on our web page, www.kentuckystages.org OR our Facebook Page.

Kentucky Stage(s) fills a vacuum left by the loss of the region’s former professional theatre and, indeed, was formed out of the company that bound together to make a daring turn-around there. While the results there were astounding, years of financial issues caused the theatre management to close its doors. The core of the last-year turn-around, however, formed a new company and found a new home at the new SKyPAC. Stage(s) is one of two resident companies at SKyPAC, the other being Orchestra Kentucky.

In ONE YEAR, we have established working relations with Actors Equity Association and with SDC, the union of stage directors and choreographers in the US. AEA has supported us to such an extent that we can, this year, offer Equity membership candidate “points,” a way for actors and stage managers new to the business, to work their way into the union. This particular aspect of the relationship was granted a full year ahead of the developmental schedule. What does that do for the SoKY area? Where the area is rich is in the educational theatre resources…at least three groups for young performers and an amazingly regarded university program grace Bowling Green. A number of well-known theatre professionals have come through here. Besides offering a chance to see professional work in our own home-town, Stage(s) now offers a great new door-way into the profession itself.

As is well known, funding for theatre of any kind, especially when at a professional level, is crucial. Very few theatres are able to survive on ticket sales alone. While we spent the first year establishing our company and molding it artistically, the bills were footed by the personal support of our Executive Director, Craig Taylor. He, obviously, cannot continue that, so the search for funding began.

Now, the exasperating part….

An expected piece of funding did not materialize and the shortfall has endangered the very existence of the second season and we need your help NOW! This campaign is a short-term (5-day) jump-start to help save the first show, “A Streetcar Named Desire” now and help us keep the ball rolling while we really hit the funding road… HARD! (look for the upcoming events: “The Stella Yell-aah” and “Full Bunny Contact.”

While we are still in the process of establishing ourselves as a non-profit organization, we are under the fiscal sponsorship of the amazing Fractured Atlas, which is an “umbrella” non-profit organization. Larger contributors can help us with a tax deductible contribution there. For information on how to go about that, please email kenhailey@kentuckystages.org

Please help us keep this spectacular season rolling… and we hope to see you there SOON!


From "Lion in Winter," and "The Glass Menagerie," to "Lombardi," and "The Importance of Being Earnest," Kentucky Stages has consistently delivered high quality entertainment with the barest budget at ridiculously low ticket prices.

          -Jeffrey Beard

Kentucky Stages has brought professional theatre to Southern Kentucky with a minimal budget. Please help bring another season of classic and contemporary theatre to Bowling Green.

           -Marie Guthrie

Investing in Kentucky Stages is investing in the soul of a city that is exploding with life. It is a commitment in bringing excellence in theatre arts to this area, but more importantly it is ensuring that our stories, stories rich in history, expression and importance are shared.  From this stage, the echo of our lives can be heard. It must not be silenced.

          -Sara Jones

story:
The Play:

I and You is a complex, touching, funny, and extremely moving story of two 17-year olds brought together by very unique circumstances.   Caroline is very sick.   Her liver is failing.   She has been pulled out of school and is confined to her room.   Anthony is a classmate of hers that she barely knows.   He comes over unannounced to work on a class project -- for which they have been apparently paired -- about Walt Whitman.    What happens between them in this 95 minutes is life changing.   

The play's author, Lauren Gunderson, is currently the most produced playwright in the United States and yet somehow, remains unknown to a vast majority of Canadian theatregoers.   This production will change that, and in a big way.

The Company: 

  • Outlook Theatre is a not-for-profit and project-based theatre company that has been in existence since 2015.
  • It was founded and is led by Artistic Director, Marc Bondy (who will also direct I and You)
  • It receives no annual operating funding from any level of government 
  • I and You will be Outlook Theatre's first full-scale independent production.

What We Need & What You Get

With no support from our Government Funding Bodies (Toronto Arts Council, Ontario Arts Council and Canada Council) we rely on crowdfunding, in-kind donations, ticket revenue and sponsorships from the private sector in order to meet our production expenses.   I and You - our current project -- has a total production expense of $26,500. 

Outlook Theatre is committed to paying all artists involved a living wage.   In fact, it is part of our mission to help launch emerging artists without asking them to work for free.    Artistic Fees for this project will amount to $13,500.   All other production expenses amount to $13,000.  Projected box-office revenue is expected to be $13,000.  As of January 1st 2018, Outlook Theatre has secured $1000 from the private sector by way of sponsorships and we have also secured in-kind contributions totalling $1200.    In addition, I will be donating my directing salary back to the production ($3000) as a personal contribution because I believe so heavily in this project.

We are setting a crowdfunding goal of $9000 for this campaign to cover the short-fall ($8300 plus $700 for Indiegogo platform fees). 

The Impact

Your dollars will be used to create a living, breathing piece of live theatre that has the power to inspire and move all who experience it.   And it will bring this incredible play to Toronto audiences for the first time.    Moreover, you will play a part in providing an ever-so-gentle nudge forward in the early stages of careers of some very fine emerging artists.     

Risks & Challenges

The biggest risk in putting this production on independently is going into debt should we not raise the funds we need to cover our projected revenue shortfall.   Outlook Theatre is committed to this production and to paying all the artists involved.   We will not pull the plug on this production no matter what.   So a failure to cover our production expenses will result in company debt (which we would very much like to avoid).

As theatre artists, one of our greatest challenges is finding ways to engage younger theatre audiences so that we can build the audiences of tomorrow.  We are constantly searching for ways to develop young people's interest in the theatre and keep them coming back for the next 50+ years.    This play appeals specifically to young people and it will get their bums in seats.  It is written in their vernacular and about things that resonate with them.   We believe the best way to engage a new audience is to allow them to see themselves reflected on stage.    I and You does that, brilliantly.   This story will appeal to people who already go the theatre while at the same time appealing to younger, first-time theatregoers.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute to our campaign financially, there are more ways to show your support and to help us reach our goal:

  • Help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign by sharing it within your networks.   You can do this easily by using the Indiegogo "share" tools right here on the site
  • Buy tickets.   Make an early commitment to come and see the show by purchasing an advance ticket and marking your calendar.
  • Make an in-kind contribution
    • Have access to printing equipment and supplies?   Offer to print our posters, postcards or tickets for free
    • Volunteer to usher one of our performances
    • Dabble in photography?   Volunteer to take some publicity or production stills for us to use in promotion of the show.
    • Have contacts in the media?   Help us to get a preview article in The Toronto Star, Globe & Mail, Now Magazine or a radio interview on CBC Radio
    • Are you teacher?   Buy a block tickets for your class for our student matinee on April 25th.   

We cannot wait to bring this amazing play to audiences in Toronto this spring.    Please help us to make a big splash by supporting our campaign.    Thank you in advance for your interest and your support of Outlook Theatre's I and You.

Volunteer to usher one of our performances

story:
Summary:

Enchant Vertical Dance has been Seattle's all inclusive pole dance studio for over two years now. We have been given a rare and extremely out of the blue offer to take over another space within the 12th and Pike building that we can't pass up! Spaces in this building go fast and tenants stay for years. Our Enchanting Students had the idea of creating this campaign to help fund our dream!  

 

What We Need:

We have hit almost all of our goals! The only thing we have left that we need are mirrors! Our mirrors will cost $1000.

 

To offer classes in this space we will need the following:
6 new poles ($3,500) - Done! 

A contractor to reinforce the flooring and put up the poles ($1,000) - Done!

Marbled Grey Marly Dance Flooring ($800) - Done

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Promote our classes to your friends!

story:
April was. Who?

Hi. We are the producing team for the 2017 SoLow Fest show

Post-April

Post-April  is a devised one-person play created by Philadelphia theatre artists Sarah Knittel, James Haro, and Dani Solomon. Our trio formed earlier this year in order to bring to (after)life the enigmatic character of April Denise Atwater.

April's story begins with her death in a swimming pool.

Wait - what happens next?

April is on a mission to ensure that the mad experiment of her life will be remembered on her own terms.

We'll be bringing this story to the Da Vinci Art Alliance this month, June 22 - 25

She's half way there!

Post-April is being co-produced in concert with Jess Conda's "Cinematic Human" - AND thanks to BRAT Productions we will be able to pay ourselves for our work. BUT, there are still a few things we need.

Which is why we are asking if you can Indie to our GoGo -

Costs that your contribution will help offset -

  • Our indoor pool! (oh yes - technically an indoor pool. Technically.)
  • A silly amount of white balloons and fringe pennants - set dressing for the underworld
  • Props and materials to recreate the April made while she was alive
  • Rental Fees for rehearsal space and equipment (sound, light, power tools to battle the demons within -)

Other Ways You Can Help

Come see the piece! 

RSVP to our Facebook event page (click here)

Share the link on the internets, and tell your friends about us!

Tell Jess Conda and BRAT Productions that they are THE BEST (and let them know April agrees)!

Go to the SoLow Fest website and support all of the great work that you can! We'll probably see you out at a show. We can hug and be friends!!!
 

Post-April


Performed by Sarah Knittel 
Directed by Dani Solomon
Created by Dani, Sarah, and James
Co-produced by BRAT Productions
(Performed in rep with Cinematic Human by Jess Conda)​

Da Vinci Art Alliance (Philadelphia - Catherine btw. 7th and 8th) 

TIX: PWYC - Suggested $20; $10/show. For reservations, email - bratsolow@gmail.com

(FYI - Seating is very limited due to the intimate seating arrangement for the show)

June 22nd @ 8:00pm
June 23rd @ 6:30pm and 9:30pm
June 24th @ 8:00pm
June 25th @ 8:00pm


Run time- 40 minutes

story:
Who We Are 

Building Better People Productions is an Annapolis. MD- based theater that does shows for kids and families, featuring professional actors, that are all about respect and kindness and other good things. It was started in the fall of 2015 by Lynne Streeter Childress, an actor, teaching artist and director who has been in the theater world in some shape or form for over 20 years, and has worked at cool places like the Kennedy Center, Arena Stage, and the Folger Shakespeare Library. Much of that work has been for, with, and also sometimes playing, children (like in the world premiere and original tour of  the musical adaptation of the classic children's book, "Alexander and the Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Day"). Now she is branching out on her own, and here is why: Lynne spends a lot of time on Facebook, and in internet comment sections, and could not ignore that we are living in a time of open disrespect and empathy towards other people, especially those with different ideas than you. She wanted to do something, and was led to write pieces for kids that showed the beauty of self-worth and kindness, because theater is a powerful way to influence, and youth is a great time to be influenced for good. And that's where BBP Productions came from, and here is what we are doing!

Our first show, "We Got It!", which is all about empathy and which Lynne wrote, will premiere this May with daytime weekend shows, first at the Faith Auditorium of Bridgeway Community Church in Columbia, MD, and then at Metropolitan Kitchen and Lounge in Annapolis. We also do are doing play production classes this spring and summer, and this fall, we plan to both rent space for another run of "We Got It!", opening it to the public and to school groups.

If you help fund our campaign, you will be building Building Better People! You would be helping us spread good things into the air by teaching little ones and their families how to treat themselves and other folks. You would be helping us bring a message of understanding to kids, and we need more of that, don't we? 

We Need Some Stuff!

Your generous donations at every level will really help us do things like:

Pay actors, because although they love doing art, we would also like to help them eat. Buy some sound equipment that we can use in different venues. Find some cool props and costumes. Help with our marketing efforts, so that people know about us. Space rental for shows, as well as for classes. Paying for shows for groups to see the show who might not have the funding to come on their own.  That's really cool. 

You'll Get Some Stuff!

You will find more details right over there >>> BUT when you donate you will get everything from a shout out on our website, to Lynne calling you and singing a nice song that's also about nice stuff, to tickets to upcoming shows, to even having the show come to you at your school, church, house, festival, or wherever you want to bring us. And since we are sponsored by Fractured Atlas, a 501 c 3 organization that helps artists raise money, your donation to us is either fully or partially tax-deductible, based on what your perk is. 

Other Things That You Can Get In On This

We know that everybody isn't in the position to be able to give money right now, and that's quite alright! You can share this campaign on your social media networks, come see our May 14 shows in Columbia or our May 22 shows in Annapolis and go to our website and check out everything we have going on
We are also accepting donations of costumes and props. If you have a closet full of interesting stuff that you aren't wearing, like your Grandma's flapper dress, or your Dad's polyester suit he used to go to discos in, we would love to hear about it. Write us at Info@bbpproductions.com
If you know schools or venues that might be interested in having our show come to them, contact us at info@bbpproductions.com
Send us your prayers and good wishes and vibes. We need those. 

We Can Do This, Y'all! Can I call you "Y'all"? Cool.

The details of putting together a theater company are challenging, and we are also aware that people might be resistant to our message and the idea that we as people need any changing at all.  We value the trust that you are putting in us by donating, by coming to see our shows, and by bringing your kids to our classes. Our goal is to put the same positive spirit that runs through our work into HOW we do our work, and to treat everyone that we come across the same way that the characters in our shows do: with respect and kindness. We think that sounds good.

Building Better People Productions is a fiscally sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Building Better People Productions must be made payable to "Fractured Atlas" only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.
story_txt:
Who We Are 
 Building Better People Productions is an Annapolis. MD- based theater that does shows for kids and families, featuring professional actors, that are all about respect and kindness and other good things. It was started in the fall of 2015 by Lynne Streeter Childress, an actor, teaching artist and director who has been in the theater world in some shape or form for over 20 years, and has worked at cool places like the Kennedy Center, Arena Stage, and the Folger Shakespeare Library. Much of that work has been for, with, and also sometimes playing, children (like in the world premiere and original tour of  the musical adaptation of the classic children's book, "Alexander and the Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Day"). Now she is branching out on her own, and here is why: Lynne spends a lot of time on Facebook, and in internet comment sections, and could not ignore that we are living in a time of open disrespect and empathy towards other people, especially those with different ideas than you. She wanted to do something, and was led to write pieces for kids that showed the beauty of self-worth and kindness, because theater is a powerful way to influence, and youth is a great time to be influenced for good. And that's where BBP Productions came from, and here is what we are doing!
Our first show, "We Got It!", which is all about empathy and which Lynne wrote, will premiere this May with daytime weekend shows, first at the Faith Auditorium of Bridgeway Community Church in Columbia, MD, and then at Metropolitan Kitchen and Lounge in Annapolis. We also do are doing play production classes this spring and summer, and this fall, we plan to both rent space for another run of "We Got It!", opening it to the public and to school groups.
If you help fund our campaign, you will be building Building Better People! You would be helping us spread good things into the air by teaching little ones and their families how to treat themselves and other folks. You would be helping us bring a message of understanding to kids, and we need more of that, don't we?    We Need Some Stuff!

Your generous donations at every level will really help us do things like:
Pay actors, because although they love doing art, we would also like to help them eat. Buy some sound equipment that we can use in different venues. Find some cool props and costumes. Help with our marketing efforts, so that people know about us. Space rental for shows, as well as for classes. Paying for shows for groups to see the show who might not have the funding to come on their own.  That's really cool. 

You'll Get Some Stuff!You will find more details right over there >>> BUT when you donate you will get everything from a shout out on our website, to Lynne calling you and singing a nice song that's also about nice stuff, to tickets to upcoming shows, to even having the show come to you at your school, church, house, festival, or wherever you want to bring us. And since we are sponsored by Fractured Atlas, a 501 c 3 organization that helps artists raise money, your donation to us is either fully or partially tax-deductible, based on what your perk is.

If you know schools or venues that might be interested in having our show come to them, contact us at info@bbpproductions.com
Send us your prayers and good wishes and vibes. We need those. 

We Can Do This, Y'all! Can I call you "Y'all"? Cool.
The details of putting together a theater company are challenging, and we are also aware that people might be resistant to our message and the idea that we as people need any changing at all.  We value the trust that you are putting in us by donating, by coming to see our shows, and by bringing your kids to our classes. We think that sounds good.

story:
Short Summary

Hey folks - 

Do the names Thomas C. Reilly, William H. Macy, Alec Baldwin, Cate Blanchett, and Benjamin Cumberbatch mean anything to you? Because I can guarantee you that none of these actors are in my play.

My name is Patrick Mulvihill and as some of you know, I've been writing for a long time now. And in the spirit of total transparency, I started writing when I was about six, so it's like forty years. 

After studying with the likes of Andres Dubus III, James Carroll, Thomas Kennedy and other writers of their considerable ilk, I worked for Neil LaBute, NYC theater guru Stephen Pevner, USA Films, and New Line Cinema as well as writing for Warner Brothers and other production entities, most of the major creative advertising companies in Hollywood, and Fortune 500 companies in corporate America. Screenplays, creative advertising, marketing materials, corporate videos and creative content - I've written it all. 

And now it's time to step into the arena I've always wanted to try: theater. That's why I am going to put up a night of my own one-acts as a part of the Los Angeles Fringe Festival, one of the country's (if not the world's) premiere Fringe Festivals.

As writers we usually have to write what we're paid to in order to feed ourselves. SOMETIMES we get to write what we HAVE to, the words inside us that NEED to get out. This is one of THOSE times. 

What We Need & What You Get

I need to raise $1,000 in the next thirty days. A mere pittance, you may say. You may even write a check for a grand and send it off. You may ask me to pass the salt - I don't know. I'm just a caveman. 

What I do know is that by funding this theater project you will make a lot of people laugh and maybe, just maybe, a grown man cry...

No? Nothing? Sorry - that's the Hollywood emotion manipulation on auto-trigger. 

Here's the dilly, straight up no chaser:

Through a few investors I've been able to clear the first couple hurdles. And now your money will make this project happen. It's tangible. It's real. It's up five times during the Fringe Festival and I can just about guarantee you that should you attend, you will leave with a smile on your face (but can't really because then the legal department will have my a**). It's irreverent, it's funny (so say those who've seen parts of it), and I can honestly say that I am very proud of it. Even the naughty bits. 

Whether I reach my goal or not, all the proceeds will go to making this happen and paying out remaining fees and the OTHER people who help make theater happen: sound/tech, actors, ticket takes, etc. Do I get any cheddar, you ask? ONLY if there's any in the pot at the end of the Festival, after the show has run its course and the door receipts have been divvied up and everyone else's been paid...THEN I might get a little taste. I'm not doing this to make money. I'm doing this for love of the written word - and to do it WELL. 

The Impact

Why is this important? Where do I get off? 

Listen, if you wanna step out into the alley...

It's art. And art is important. Far more important than I think many of us realize. It provides sustenance, it is a mirror into the human experience, and there's always hot chicks around. 

But seriously, theater has been of vital importance to our species since the ancient Greeks. Its immediacy and energy are unlike any other artistic discipline. And it brings us together. And in this case, hopefully, to laugh unreservedly.

Other Ways You Can Help

At the end of the day, even more important perhaps than your contribution is your support. I understand if you can't commit to the cause for any number of reasons. But if you believe in it, please spread the gospel. Indiegogo even has share tools! How crazy is that? Get people in tune with the LA Fringe Festival, and maybe, just maybe, you all can help a brother looking to make a little magic happen.

story:
Short Summary

Stained Glass Theatre Joplin seeks to provide training, resources, and opportunity for individuals in our community to identify, develop, and utilize the gifts God has given them for “family friendly” artistic expression.


In addition to family friendly theater productions, SGT Joplin cultivates an environment for the community to explore and develop interest in artistic areas. While developing interest and ability in the arts, SGT Joplin provides opportunity for relation-ships to be strengthened, both within the community of SGT Joplin volunteers, and in the broader community as well.

Excellent productions, supportive and encouraging community life, and exposure to training and experience from like-minded artists are all hallmarks of the work of SGT Joplin.


On May 22, 2011, the cast and crew of our production, "I Remember Mama," had finished their last show and were beginning to strike the set and clean up the building when the devastating tornado made its way through Joplin. The winds blew, the walls crumbled and when it passed, the building that housed Stained Glass Theatre Joplin was gone. There were 56 members of the Stained Glass family in the building; three members of our family lost their lives and six others were seriously injured.


We are still heartbroken over our losses, but the God-given spirit of the Stained Glass Theatre family is strong, and we appreciate all the love, support, encouragement, and especially the prayers that have been sent our way as we have been seeking the direction that God would have us move.

For the past three years we have been a "roving" theater troupe, constantly having to find places to audition, rehearse, and perform. We have been able, in spite of the difficulties, to continue to offer regular productions with only a brief disruption. (Our first production after the tornado, "Father of the Bride,"  was the following September.)


This year we have been blessed to be able to purchase an old church building that we can make our new, permanent home. While it has a lot of character and potential, it needs work in order for it to be usable as a theater.



What We Need

Having already raised over $75,000, we have been blessed with a $50,000 matching grant that will help us accomplish that goal. In order to receive it, we need your help to raise $100,000. This will get us halfway to our ultimate goal of $500,000 that will make the new Stained Glass Theatre Joplin more than we ever dreamed. All funds raised will go toward the renovation and remodeling of our new home.


To Inspire and Thank You for Your Donation, We're Offering Great Perks!

Please check them out on the right-hand side.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help. We need you to help us spread the word. Share the link to this campaign on your Facebook Page. Tell your friends about us. Shout it from the mountaintop. Just help us let people know our need.

story:
We're legal! Help celebrate The Builders' 21st birthday, the publication of our new book, the world premiere of our latest show, and our next project! 

2015 was a big year for the company - we are so proud of everything that we accomplished and  hope you can help us get started on our next adventure!

We wrote a book!  

It's called "Performance and Media in Contemporary Theater" and was co-authored by Shannon Jackson (of UC Berkeley) and artistic director Marianne Weems.  Over the last seven (!!) years they have braved our Brooklyn storage unit, carefully gone through our vast and dusty archive searching for ephemera that would help to bring  our productions back to life  and written about the company in a way that satisfies readers on both an academic and entertainment level.  

Each chapter takes you through a different production, with sections including "Openings," "Storyboard," "R&D," "Operating Systems," and "After Party." 

Here's an excerpt included in the "After Party" section of of the Super Vision chapter, by company member and performer Rizwan Mirza:

Multimedia Theater Glossary

Multimedia - a genre of modern theater in which former Midwest residents move to New York or Los Angeles and develop work and existential angst using technology.

The Performance Space - no, not a stage, well sometimes.  Always make sure to call the stage the Performance Space.  But do note, in multimedia theatrical pieces there need not be a stage.  This should inform you of the brilliance of the work.  And lack of funding.

Various Technicians - a veritable 'Les Mis' like crew of goateed, wool-hatted, "cleverly" captioned tee shirted, unshaven (females included) sexually deviant beer drinking souvenir buying geniuses.

There are a few photos in the gallery on this site.

We premiered a new show! 

In September we premiered our newest production, ELEMENTS OF OZ, as part of Peak Performances at Montclair State University (NJ).  A lighthearted 21st century mash-up of the classic story The Wizard of Oz, ELEMENTS OF OZ features YouTube fanatics, heavy metal, and a heartfelt recreation of the iconic film. Audiences also leave on their cell phones - the stage action is enhanced by interactivity with viewers' smart phones, delivering the Technicolor Land of Oz of our imaginations. 

The New York Times said it was “loopy,” “charming” and “technically marvelous.”  

We had so much fun making this show, and are looking forward to touring it over the next few years!

More photos in the gallery.

We turned 21!

We were so busy we missed our 20th anniversary, so hope you can help us celebrate our 21st.  Now that we can drink, we are planning a party to launch the book in January - please plan to join us!

What's next?

The company is mulling over what to do next...immigration?  Opera?  Classic literature?  It's all on the table.  Which brings us to...

What we need, straight up.

Money.  $7,500 is the goal.  It's tough out here for a middle-aged experimental non-profit theater company! We LOVE our process and the work that it fosters, but it's not exactly inexpensive.  This money will allow us to start to work on that next project, and keep our head above water for another year!  What more can we ask for.

ANYTHING helps, and we thank you so much.

Want more info on the book and/or The Builders?

The Builders Association has been around since 1994 (!!).  More info on the company and our shows can be found here:

www.thebuildersassociation.org

The Builders Association: Performance and Media in Contemporary Theater is available on Amazon.

story:
Guerrilla Girls On Tour! recently publishing our annual GIRLCOTT list -- a list of theatres across the US that do not include one single play written by a woman in their mainstage seasons. (http://guerrillagirlsontour.com/monkey-business/girlcott-good-news/) This year the number of theatres has grown to 101 theatres, including New York City’s Pearl Theatre Company, Classic Stage and The Public Theatre.  In Minneapolis, the Guthrie Theater, one of the most prestigious regional theatres in America, recently announced its 50th anniversary season would include 12 productions written and directed by white men. (One production is co-directed by a woman). This continued exclusion of women and artists of color from the main stages of American Theatre is unacceptable. Therefore on September 24thGuerrilla Girls On Tour! along with 50/50 in 2020 and the Women’s Initiative members of the Dramatists Guild will present WE ARE THEATRE - a SPEAK OUT about the lack of parity for women theatre artists in America.

WE ARE THEATRE is an evening of monologues, skits, songs and short plays about sexism in theatre written by women playwrights from around the world. Participants include Theresa Rebeck, Kate Bornstein, Andrea Lepcio, Brooke Berman, Kathleen Warnock, Caridad Svich, Yvette Heyliger, Velina Hasu Houston, Shay Youngblood and Guerrilla Girls On Tour!  

The Cherry Lane Theatre has been generously donated for WE ARE THEATRE, however we must pay for insurance, box office, house manager, stage manager and videographer. The SPEAK OUT will be streamed live.  All funds will go towards these costs.

If you donate $25 we will send you a signed Guerrilla Girls On Tour poster – “I Still Love Feminism More Than Ever”.   For $150 you'll receive two VIP tickets to WE ARE THEATRE.  For $200 you’ll get two VIP tickets PLUS a signed poster.

WE ARE THEATRE will bring women theatre artists to the forefront, reminding the theatre going public that women have been writing plays for eleven centuries, yet we continue to be under produced, under published and completely erased from the canon perpetuating the assumption that there is too little work by us and too little of it which is any good. WE ARE THEATRE is an evening of reflective, constructive, thoughtful, personal, contemplative, experimental, conventional and empowering theatre by the a few of the thousands of women theatre artists around the world who continue to carry on the tradition of creating great global theatre.

If you cannot attend but want to see discrimination in theatre hit the road once and for all visit http://www.facebook.com/WeAreTheatre and stay tuned for more updates.

story:
SLaM: the Hockey Rock Opera will be presenting this July at the inaugural Finger Laker Musical Theater "Pitch" Festival for new musicals.  

Only YOU can help us get there!

We are raising funds to pay for rehearsal space, our amazing choreographer Taryn Noelle (who originated the role of Steamy in our first run), score and script revision costs, compensation for the creative team for the week of work missed, dramaturgical costs, costumes, gas and food!

SLaM: the Hockey Rock Opera is based on a true story. This original musical started when my boyfriend and I were travelling around Europe. He was trying to play division 1 hockey, after having no success in Canada. We had both been battered by the US border, post 9/11, and in Europe we could be together, border free. But travelling has its own challenges, and when I started singing about our struggles in Mora, Sweden, my boyfriend turned on a digital recorder and caught it all live.

After recording 19 songs acapella, I found an orchestrator in Montpelier, Vermont. Together we turned it into a full fledged musical.

The show was produced by Green Mountain Theater Group in October, 2010, to great reviews.

original cast on our real ice stage!

I kept working on this fledgling show, and it was accepted into an inaugural festival this summer in upstate New York. We get to "Pitch" the show, to industry professionals, with the goal of a full production.

I found a New York City professional dramaturg, Charlie Schulman, and a new accompianist, Sheila Metcalf, and together we are building an amazing production.

The leading male, Silky la Mouche, will be played by James Blanchard. James has performed in musical theater all across his native Vermont. Credits include leading roles with Lyric Theatre, one of the country's largest all-volunteer theater groups, and Vermont Stage Company, the only professional, resident theater in Burlington, VT. He also hosts "Musical Theater in the Green Mountains", a weekly radio program focusing on local theater music, on The Radiator, 105.9 WOMM (theradiator.org.). He can be seen next in Sweeney Todd, with the Stowe Theatre Guild. James is proud to help bring this Vermont-born musical to a wider audience.

I'll be playing the female lead, Steamy Rika, who is based on me.  It is definitely strange to play a version of yourself on stage, but no one believes in this project more than I do - so who better to "Sell It".

Sheila, our Narrator and pianist is a creative and inspiring talent to work with and help guide SLaM musically to this next level.  She received her B.A. in music from Johnson State College in 2002. After an early start working in musical theater (The Rocky Horror Show, The Fantasticks, Jesus Christ Superstar, Hair) she turned her attention to the singer/songwriter areas of music. The last decade has been filled with teaching piano, writing and performing with eclectic projects and musicians in the beauty of New England.  She is pleased to return to the setting of the theater to be part of this production of SLaM.

Our first full production, back in 2010, of a new show that no one had ever heard of received great reviews all over the state, and got mentioned in The New York Times, USA Today, and crazy random places like The Bombay Times and The Beijing Times.

People still come up to me and ask for downloads of the songs that they can't stop humming.

Nothing like this show has ever been done before. This has real potential to make it all the way to Broadway! And with your help - we can surely do it!
story_txt:
SLaM: the Hockey Rock Opera will be presenting this July at the inaugural Finger Laker Musical Theater "Pitch" Festival for new musicals.  

Only YOU can help us get there!
We are raising funds to pay for rehearsal space, our amazing choreographer Taryn Noelle (who originated the role of Steamy in our first run), score and script revision costs, compensation for the creative team for the week of work missed, dramaturgical costs, costumes, gas and food!

SLaM: the Hockey Rock Opera is based on a true story. This original musical started when my boyfriend and I were travelling around Europe. story:
The Bear is a theatrical presentation which we have been passionately developing over the past two years at The Actors Studio in New York City. What is unique about our approach is that we will be incorporating the improvisational moments discovered in our explorations of the original Chekhov play, which is in and of itself very brief. These explorations will be adding moments to the One Act play, thereby expanding the piece into a full length play. The additional scenes will consist of circumstances outside the original plot, discovered through the actor’s personal realities.

Beyond the stage version of the play, we anticpate creating a film version of our process of The Bear. This is the Final Goal of the project - a screenplay adaptation developed from the one act play, to be shot in Romania, incorporating additional scenes and Chekhovian characters. The work thus far at the Actors Studio is seen as a first step towards that goal. First, to rehearse and perform the play as a core, and then to begin to bring in other scene ideas and characters, such as a funeral scene and a church confessional scene. The objective of this first step is to develop a full length play out of the one act, with the imaginary circumstances arising out of the personal lives of the actors, but still within the context of the play.  

Your generous donations will allow us to fully realize an expanded rehearsal process that will include your participation, to further develop connections between the audience and the actors. Giving you a look behind the curtain of the theatrical experience, to see how our human experience influences art and life. What better way than through Chekhov, who first brought the complex beauty of simple life to the stage.

If you refer to our list of perks, you will see the different exciting ways you may participate through the various contribution categories. Some of you may even be invited to play with us onstage. For those who are not close enough, and would still like to be involved, we would provide access through internet technology.

This is a crucial element of the project, beyond the production - to bring the public into the acting experience by allowing participation in the process. For us to capture and document the actors’ process/method and give the audience an inside look into that world. This is an aspect of the project that is envisioned as web-based, incorporating elements of an online community.

This for us would be only the beginning of an expansion of possibility for artistic communication, available to everyone with an interest in creativity. A celebration of life for all involved.
 

MIHAELA MIHUT is originally from Transilvania, Romania. There she received her Bachelor's Degree in Theater from the Academy of Theater and Film in Bucharest. While still in school, she had the opportunity to work on stage with some of the greatest Romanian actors. Her curiosity of new approaches to theater arts led her to New York City, where she received her MFA in Theater from the Actors Studio Drama School, and later was one of the few to be accepted as a Lifetime Member of The Actors Studio. Her experiences also led her to discover a love of teaching acting. She has performed at The National Theatre in Romania and Off Broadway in NYC, and has taught in studios in NYC and in Greece under the stars near the Acropolis. She currently teaches acting at The School of Visual Arts in New York City.

story:
Meet Passed Dance

Passed Dance is a small modern dance company in a large art-filled city. Despite having had no funding, amidst a crumbling economy, in a society that often fails to support dance with the same vigor as visual arts, music, and theater...we survived our first year! Personal ups and downs sprinkled with a few fights during the rehearsal process couldn't even keep us down. We have shown our work in Manhattan, Brooklyn, and the Bronx. We went on an artistic retreat at the Dragon's Egg in Mystic, CT. And we received the PILLAR Choreography Residency at BODYART Studio in Queens, NY. All in all, not bad for a small group of women dedicated to making their mark on the world through dance.

We are embarking on our second year by creating a new lighthearted piece, We Didn't Win the Lotto...But We Still Enjoyed the View, a reminder to stay in the moment, keep spontaneity alive, laugh, play, and enjoy the company of those we love. We are also continuing work on our evening length collection of pieces inspired by therapeutic work done with the acutely mentally ill, Behind Locked Doors.


Our Goal and How You Can Help

In our second year we are attempting to do something that is virtually unheard of for a small dance company that receives no major funding - pay our dancers for their hours of hard work and dedication. We are asking for your help in achieving this goal, along with aiding us in offsetting the high cost of studio rental fees for rehearsals, costuming for our new work, and a new photo shoot for marketing and promotional materials. 

No donation is too small...every dollar helps us offset the high cost of producing high quality dance in New York City. Just $1 pays a dancer for 5 minutes of rehearsal time (or buys her a Luna bar to keep her stamina up). No donation is too large either. If you won the lotto or pulled your money out of the stock market before it crashed and are now hoarding money under your mattress we can help ease your burden of figuring out how to invest that money.

$25 - pays 1 dancer for a 2 hour rehearsal or covers studio rental fees for a 2 hour rehearsal
$50 - pays for costume materials or pays 2 dancers for a 2 hour rehearsal or covers 4 hours 
         of studio rental fees
$100 - covers all costs for a 2 hour rehearsal 
$250 - pays for a new photo shoot 
$500 - covers all rehearsal costs for 1 month
$1000 - pays all of our dancers for a weekend performance


No Money, No Problem

Tell your friends! Use your email, facebook, and twitter accounts to help us get the word out. 

We understand that in this economy you simply may not have any extra money to part with (and sometimes that $4 cup of coffee just trumps everything, including bills and supporting your favorite up and coming dance company...we won't judge you). 
Helping us get the word out is just as important as making a monetary donation.


With great gratitude,
Corinna Brown
Cara Aubrey Gallo
Kendra Kambestad
Djuna Passman, Artistic Director

story:
The Play

Political satire from a university perspective. The Stephen Harper Play re-imagines the scandals and diplomatic decisions of our Prime Minister with some of the most out-there (literally, in the Arctic) explanations ever. A lampoon on the man-in-charge as well as our own political ignorance that begs us to answer the question: how well do we know our leader?

My colleagues and I created a 45-minute theatre piece that debuted in January as a part of U-Vic's Student Alternative Theatre Company. Building off our success, we created our own Victoria-based theatre company, Theatre Theatre, aimed at producing works that focus on a blend of humour and social commentary. 

The Stephen Harper Play is our inaugural production. It explores the disconnect between our world leaders and the impressions they convey through the media. By combining real-world scandals with ridiculous explanations, The Stephen Harper Play shows us just how much we don't know about what our leader is doing.

What We Need

Our goal is to raise money to cover the festival entrance fee, as well the sets, costumes, props, marketing, and all the other things required to produce the show.

Our Budget:

Expenses:

Festival Entrance Fee          $625
Props                                       $225
Marketing                               $350
Front of House                      $150
Costumes                               $350
Set Pieces                              $200
Contingency                          $100

TOTAL COST                        $2 000

All proceeds go to help these young artists develop and produce their work without having to pay from their own pockets. Theatre Theatre believes in supporting young artists, and any contribution is greatly appreciated.

What You Get

There are, of course, perks for contributing. All donors' names will be printed in the program. We also offer lots of other goodies, such as signed posters and gift cards.

For a full list of our perks, just check out the sidebar.

Our Mission

We believe whole-heartedly in the ability of theatre to provide perspective in a tumultuous world. Theatre Theatre's prerogatives are twofold: to entertain and enlighten. Our goal is to poke fun at all of the problems of the modern world, from global politics to love and relationships. After all, some of the biggest problems in the world seem trivial when we're reminded of what's important.

Other Ways You Can Help

Just because you can't contribute money doesn't mean you can't help! Help spread the word. More bums in seats means more people get the message and helps young artists like you wouldn't believe!
