story:
The History

In 2010, On The Square Productions mounted a production of A Midsummer Night’s Dream in a private Astoria greenspace. This production was successful in many ways, but the support and encouragement from local businesses and community members was perhaps the most important. One evening as the show started cast, crew, and audience noticed two local children transfixed by the action. The two were watching through a parking lot fence positioned above the playing area. These neighborhood children had stumbled upon a magical event practically in their backyard. This moment inspired the company to replicate that magic on a broader scale. In order to make this experiment more accessible, OtSP created this program free of charge, and set their sights on found spaces seemingly commonplace to all. So The Astoria Free Theatre Project was born.

Short Summary

The Astoria Free Theatre Project is a bi-annual theatre production produced by On The Square Productions.  As producers who not only work, but live in Astoria, Jackie LaVanway and Rachel McPhee-Benson have identified a need for free, professional theatre in their neighborhood.

The Minervae tells the story of one mythological goddess who refuses to move over for the fashionable new “cult” of Christianity. Jilted, Minerva sets out to re-convert the converted. Standing in her way are the schemes of the other Olympians: bitter Vulcan, volatile Mars, ambitious Apollo, and the enigmatic Diana. It’s a titanic clash of faith vs. revelation, with mortal Man caught in between.

The aim of this project is to bring a free, professional piece of new writing to an Astoria found space biannually. The Astoria Free Theatre Project will make its debut with Steven Bost's The Minervae in July 2012. This event is made possible in part by the Queens Council on the Arts with public funding from the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs.

The goals of Astoria Free Theatre Project are:
  • To give back to the community where we have made our home by offering accessible, professional theatre.
  • To promote the idea that theatre can happen anywhere.
  • To support the voices of new writers and bring them to new audiences.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We've set our sights high for The Minervae with a project goal of $5,000.  Because our show is free of charge we cannot depend on recouping some of our funds from ticket sales; so are coming up with some creative ways to raise capital!  With your genrous donation to On the Square Productions you'll be helping to make the following possible:

  • Printing of scripts for our actors, and programs for our patrons
  • The beautiful costumes and set pieces that will create Mount Olympus and the post-catastrophic world of the Christians
  • Non-traditional theatrical lighting fixtures that will help set the tone and atmosphere of our world
  • Musical instruments - we will purchase drums and acquire other intruments to enhance our storytelling
  • Load in/Load out costs- we'll  have to rent a vehicle to deliver and disassemble our set and costumes
  • Stipends for Artists, Crew, and Designers- people donate so much of their time in the arts, and while a great deal of independent theatre is on a volunteer basis, it's very important for us to pay our artists
  • Advertising costs- you can help us raise money for us to generate marketing tools so we can promote our show to the very best of our ability
  • Rehearsal space- we need a comfortable, clean environment for our actors to feel free to create
  • Park Permits- to allow us to legally be there in the space to give the best show we can!
  • And many many more things!
If we don't make our $5000 goal, we have some backup plans that would involve scaling back on some of our advertising and production costs. We'll beg, borrow, and steal (legally!) what we can, without compromising the quality of the work and our aesthetic.  We love our donors, and we'd like to reward all of you for your generous donation!  Please see below for our different tiers of sponsorship.

The Impact

It may sound cliche to say, but every dollar helps.  A donation of $5 can cover an actor's script or a can of spray paint. $20 buys an hour of rehearsal space, and $100 makes up 20% of our entire costume budget!  Any donation, no matter how big or small, means a infinite number of possibilities- especially when you have a creative team as talented as the ones we've assembled!  We couldn't be more pleased with this throught provoking, intelligent, magical piece of theatre we'll be presenting this July.  To be able to provide this type of programming free to our neighbors in the place where we live is an incredibly rewarding feeling.  We hope to inspire young minds and change people's perception of a theatrical event.  Theatre is magical- it can happen any where at any moment, if you just look around.  We'd love to share our magical world with you this July 2012 in Athens Square Park.

Other Ways You Can Help

Wanna help but low on the moola?  Not a worry!  We will be in need of many volunteers to help make our vision a reality.  Here's some ways you can partake in the fun!

  • House manage one of the shows.
  • Assist in building the set, hanging the lights, and other load in fun!
  • Help strike on July 30th.
  • Have a car?  We'd love to borrow it to move set pieces, costumes, and lights from location to location.
  • We're currently seeking in kind donations for chairs, bottles of water, sunblock, and bug spray.  If you have any business connections to the aforementioned list, please let us know!
  • Give flyers and postcards to local businesses- we need to spread the word to the neighborhood.
  • Give us some love on Facebook and Twitter by sharing us with your friends!

The Impact
It may sound cliche to say, but every dollar helps.  A donation of $5 can cover an actor's script or a can of spray paint. $20 buys an hour of rehearsal space, and $100 makes up 20% of our entire costume budget!  Any donation, no matter how big or small, means a infinite number of possibilities- especially when you have a creative team as talented as the ones we've assembled!  We couldn't be more pleased with this throught provoking, intelligent, magical piece of theatre we'll be presenting this July.  To be able to provide this type of programming free to our neighbors in the place where we live is an incredibly rewarding feeling.  We hope to inspire young minds and change people's perception of a theatrical event.  Theatre is magical- it can happen any where at any moment, if you just look around.  We'd love to share our magical world with you this July 2012 in Athens Square Park.


Other Ways You Can Help
Wanna help but low on the moola?  Not a worry!  We will be in need of many volunteers to help make our vision a reality.  Here's some ways you can partake in the fun!

House manage one of the shows.
Assist in building the set, hanging the lights, and other load in fun!
Help strike on July 30th.
Have a car?  We'd love to borrow it to move set pieces, costumes, and lights from location to location.
We're currently seeking in kind donations for chairs, bottles of water, sunblock, and bug spray.  If you have any business connections to the aforementioned list, please let us know!
Give flyers and postcards to local businesses- we need to spread the word to the neighborhood.
Give us some love on Facebook and Twitter by sharing us with your friends!

story:
This January, Workshop West's Realtor Canoe Theatre Festival is presenting Edmonton's Serial Collective, and their production of Ladies Who Lynch. It's promising young playwright Jason Chinn's twisted treatment of the leisured classes and those who serve them. It was a surprise hit when it was first developed as part of Azimuth Theatre's Emerging Company Showcase in 2010, receiving nominations for Best New Play and Outstanding Production at the Elizabeth Sterling Haynes Awards. 

Three well-to-do ladies stop for lunch after a morning shopping binge. Judith, the clear alpha female of the pack, dominates the gab session. She's determined to have fun on her birthday lunch. She looks forward to her time with the girls. Between questioning choices on cosmetic surgery, and yapping about her pageant princess son Caleb - Maureen is not exactly giving Judith what she wants. And Francine - the young one - well it's always something with her! To top it all off, the Waitress can't get anything right. 

She needs a drink. And then something snaps. 

Starring: Candace Berlinguette as Judith 
Nadien Chu as Maureen 
Amy Keating as Francine
Molly Flood as The Waitress 

Written by: Jason Chinn 
Directed by: Garett Spelliscy

story: Thank you for taking the time to read more about this exciting new project.  My name is Kellie Hodges and I'm seeking your investment for my work as a choreographer.  I graduated with a BA in dance from Point Park University and went on to dance professionally in Chicago with Thodos Dance Chicago.  My work has been a part of the company's repertoire since 2008, performing in Chicago, touring through Alaska, at the Busan International Dance Festival, and at Jacob's Pillow.  For the past 3 and a half years I have been teaching jazz at Point Park University as an adjunct instructor.  The opportunity has enabled me to cultivate my teaching methods and theory of dance.  With this cultivation I have been able to further my development of my own choreography as well.  I have choreographed a wide span of works ranging from flashmobs to work performed at Point Park University's Pittsburgh Connections.  Most recently my work received 3rd place in the International Choreography Competition hosted by the Jazz Dance World Congress in August 2012.  In an effort to continue moving forward I have submitted a new work and been accepted to Peridance's Showcase at APAP (the Association of Performing Arts Presenters) in January of 2013.  Your contribution would allow my work to be seen by arts presenters, agencies and managers from all over the world.  In order to present my work I must raise $950 in 7 days.  This will provide publicity including press releases and media exposure while also covering theater and technical fees.  The opportunity to showcase my choreography in the company of the many talented artists that APAP hosts is priceless and would give me exposure to achieve my goals as an artist.  Your donation would be so valuable to the continuation of showcases for emerging artists.  If the goal is not met, all the contributions will still go towards the sponsorship.  THANK YOU for your time and consideration.  Check out a video of the work on the link above.  Please feel free to share this with any arts supporters and lovers.  I am sincerely thankful to all my supporters.  Anything helps.  Keep the arts alive and growing! Thank you.

story:
Hello!

My name is Kolleen Kintz, AKA, your clown hostess with the most-est for Prepositions: A Circus Between the Times!
What is Prepositions you ask? It's a circus for all ages, featuring acrobatic dancers, and a traveling troupe of rag-tag clowns. Our show features a wide diversity of artists and age groups in collaboration: youth, teens, and adults! 

Prepositions tells a story about all the "little moments" that sneak up between the "bigger times." The moments when we actually discover something special and new about ourselves. The moments when we connect with someone or share in something genuine.
It is so important to me that we reach our campaign goal, the goal of sharing this show with families near and far. Circus is about community. It brings us together and offers us a shared experience of joy and wonder. Circus reminds of that the impossible is possible, but that everything is easier when people work together.

The popularity of circus is growing with the success of big budget shows. Shows like Prepositions help keep circus a more accessible art form. Circus has strong roots in small towns and shows like ours keep the experience of a circus one that all families can afford to share.

We are bringing Prepositions to Joe's Movement Emporium on May 23rd, but we need your help!

We are trying to raise $2000! And, it goes very quickly when creating a show with 26 different performing artists. Here is how our funding will be used:
1) Renting our Venue
2) Building Lighting and Sound
3) Hiring our Technical Crew
4) Buying Costumes and Props for all 26 Performers
5) Securing Aerial Equipment, Rigging, and Scaffolding
6) Developing Marketing and Programs
If we do not meet our goal of $2000, the show will go on! We will be grateful for every penny that we fundraise, and Prepositions will make its debut. But, it will do so more simply, and without the same vision we have for this production. 
Collaborating with such a large group of artists can be challenging. However, we are working together to overcome any creative roadblocks, and make sure every voice is heard. Our goal is to share a diverse and unique circus experience with you!
We are so appreciative of your support, THANK YOU! Some of you may not be able to contribute financially to this project, we understand, and we ask that you please share this campaign with your friends and family; make some noise! Be sure to use the handy Indiegogo SHARE buttons to post this campaign to social media.
Time to Build a Circus!
With gratitude, 
Kolleen Kintz

story: ...

The Clump

The Clump (as we like to call ourselves), has been invited to perform at the 2014 Dumbo Dance Festival (September 25-28) in New York. Our group is comprised of 10 dancers and 1 choreographer, consisting of former and current students of the School of Dance at Florida State University (Tallahassee, FL). 

Yo vengo de todas partes, and towards everywhere I go, choreographed by Samantha Pazos (in collaboration with the dancers), first premiered at the Nancy Smith Fichter Dance Theatre at Florida State University, on April 25, 2014. The original 25 minute work was created in partial fulfillment of the requirements of the MFA degree in Dance. This personal piece was initially inspired by my father's story as an immigrant who arrived in the U.S. 

Ideas that are explored are:

·  Displacement

·  Oppression

·  Home/Homeland

·  Memory

·  Rebellion

·  Immigration/Journey

It was a year-long process that culminated into two performances. Now, with your help, we can continue to showcase this labor of love by performing at the DUMBO Dance Festival. This performance will provide the dancers another opportunity to work and collaborate together.


The Choreographer

Samantha Pazos is a dancer, choreographer and vocalist from Miami, FL. She is a proud graduate of Florida State University’s School of Dance with a Master of Fine Arts degree in Dance Performance and Choreography. She received a Bachelor’s degree from the University of Miami in Theatre Arts and dance.

Her dance training stems from The Ailey School, Jose Mateo Ballet Theatre, Ballet Concerto and Patricia Penenori Dance Center.

Most recently, Pazos has explored dance through the use of installation and interdisciplinary work. She has performed alongside performance, art-folk band, Glitter Chariot, at Art Basel Miami 2013, has collaborated with poet, Oscar Fuentes, at the Wynwood Arts District, and is currently collaborating with Miami-based choreographer, Pioneer Winter. Currently her work is deeply influenced by her Cuban-American and Miami roots, touching on issues of exile, displacement and identity. 


DUMBO Dance Festival

The 14th annual DUMBO Dance Festival, produced by White Wave, showcases cutting edge contemporary dance by emerging and established choreographers and dance companies. Last year’s marathon festival featured over 80 companies.

This year’s performances will take place September 25-28, 2014, at the John Ryan Theater, located at 25 Jay Street, in Brooklyn. We have the opportunity to perform excerpts from “Yo vengo de todas partes, and towards everywhere I go”.


What We Need & What You Get

We are aiming to raise $4,000.00

10 dancers x 400.00 (roughly for a round-trip ticket) = $4,000.00

Where will this go? To ALL our TRAVEL EXPENSES, specifically towards round trip plane tickets. The majority of the cast will be flying out of Tallahassee, FL, and it is quite expensive to fly out of there.

**Any additional funding will go towards Metro Cards to help the dancers get around the city, and to and from the performance venues.  Cost: $29.00 for a 7 day pass.

WHAT DO YOU GET WHEN YOU DONATE?

·  Shout outs

·  Exclusive emails/announcements

·  Personalized thank you cards

·  T-shirts

·  Photos signed by the cast


The Impact

Your donations will not only support the arts but they will support a piece whose meaning is very relevant with today’s current issues. If you are from Miami, help support your locals by making sure our voices are heard far from the borders of our Magic City. It is up to us to challenge audiences and help build the framework for future generation of artists. With your support we will be able to do just that.


Risks & Challenges

Challenges: To raise and provide the funding that is needed for 10 dancers to travel to and from NYC.

Risk: If we do not meet our goal we will have to adjust how much we cover for the entire cast, and continue to search for alternate forms of funding. Some cast members may not be able to perform in NY due to each individual’s tight budget.


Other Ways You Can Help

Other ways you can help our campaign is by promoting it!

·  Spread the word about our campaign through social media (Facebook, Twitter, Instagram) and share our Indiegogo page

·  Send emails out to friends, family, coworkers

·  Challenge your friends to donate $1 - 5 to our cause

story:
Emmy Rivera grew up in the projects in Paterson NJ. After her parents forbid her to have a Sweet 16 Party, she showed them and had a Baby Shower instead. She has been working full time ever since. Having worked since she was 17, first for 10 years in retail, followed by 24 years in the construction industry, she discovered in her 40s that her passion and talents lie in writing and performing stand-up comedy. Eight years later, after honing her craft in NYC, the call of the miserable life of a road comic is too loud to ignore, as are the cries of her adoring Grandchildren who are growing up in Kansas. Never having made a great financial success on the East Coast, it's time to follow her passions and show the kids you can do anything to set your mind to, if you work hard and find people who will have your back. Who said you can't have it all?! Or. todo! (Todo = All in Spanish.)

Making this move takes guts, but not as much as asking for help funding her dream. Hey, can't blame a girl for trying!

This money will help pay off her car, which she needs to travel the road and if all else fails, sleep in (her car is actually too small to sleep in) and to cover modest living expenses so she is not yet a burden to her family (she's saving that for the kids when they get older) until she gets this going. It's happening people! 

Emmy Rivera is a New York City-based stand-up comic, and storyteller. She performs at comedy clubs around the City including Carolines, and Broadway Comedy Club and is a popular performer at cabaret rooms such as Don’t Tell Mama, and The Duplex. As well as the acclaim she recently received for the show 'The Other Side of the Hudson' at the SoHo Playhouse, she was honored to emcee an ERA rally in D.C., where she was thrilled to hypocrite-shame slut-shamers. She has been hailed as “One to Watch!” and featured in Time Out New York. Emmy is workshopping her (obligatory) NYC Solo Show and working on her first book, a collection of personal essays that will inspire while traumatizing you. 
Follow her at: https://twitter.com/emmyrivera

story:
• What? A secret agenda behind the music industry?

It sounds farfetched, but why does it seem that mainstream music artists are glorifying satanic images and ideas in their music, pictures and videos? Could it be that they've sold their souls??

'Alex Cross and His Rise to Fame' follows Dick Richards, a low life loser who would do anything to be famous but doesn't have the talent, charisma, or looks to get him there. That is, until he meets Baal, the CEO of Beelzebub Talents who gives Dick a new name 'Alexander Cross' and promises him a life of fame and fortune. Unbeknownst to the naive Dick, it will come at a cost - his soul!!

Come follow Alex's journey during his rise to fame and learn the truth about the music industry when he is exposed by the conspiracy researcher who was once his greatest fan.

The Play

Faust meets Jesus Christ Superstar!

 'Alex Cross and His Rise to Fame' is a comedy that aims to entertain with it's 3 alternative endings.  A play that offers a sarcastic and satrical social commentary on the corporate dominance and commercialization of the music industry and the artists being exploited by it.

The Production

Created and presented by Medulla Oblongata Productions as part of the 23rd annual St. Ambroise Montreal Fringe Festival at the one and only Mainline Theatre, June 15 - June 25, 2013. 

It is a highly ambitious project but we've strapped ourselves in and are ready for a rockin' ride!

It is our aim to make this a highly professional and engaging show so that we can produce an unforgettable experience for our spectators and in doing so, to win the award for Best Production at the 2013 Fringe. To make this happen - we need your help and loving support!

Your contribution will help us to make this production everything that we are aiming and striving for it to be.

The Devil's In the Details

Here's a breakdown of where the money from your kind donations will be going towards.

  • Venue Fee
  • Rehearsal Space rental
  • Props & Set building/renting
  • Costume for 11 actors
  • Make Up for 11 actors
  • Transportation
  • Our Press Kit Materials
  • Printing (Posters, Flyers, Programs)
  • And everything else!

Our campaign goal of $7000.00 is not enough to put on this show. However, reaching our Indiegogo campaign goal will allow us to be in a position that we can make a good show with the bare bones budget we've created. The closest that we can get to reaching our projected budget of $9,000 the closer we will be to being able to focus on the making the best show for our audience without the stress involved of finding funding. All of the artist involved in our show are dedicating their time to it on a volunteer basis because they truly believe in the project and want it to succeed so we would appreciate any help that we can get.

What You Will Get

Not in exchange for your souls, but in exchange for your kind donations, we would like to show our appreciation with the following perks. This is just a taste - for more information about what perks are given for your level of support, please refer to the column on the right.

A shout out to you on all of our social network profiles by one of our cast members.

Your name on the donation list at the front door of the show.

A 'thank you' post card written in character by one of the characters of your choice.

A CD containing Alex Cross' original song 'My Fallen Angel' which will also contain videos, music, and art work.

A special thanks to you within our production pamplet.

Two free tickets to the show and two free cupcakes from Montreal's own D Liche Cupcakes at the show.

And much more...

 

How You Can Help

Donating your money to our project would be the best way in which you could help us to make this a memorable production. However, if you simply can't afford it, we understand, but you can still help us by sharing our indiegogo page on your facebook timeline or liking and sharing our Facebook Fan Page.

We appreciate any way in which you can help us make this production happen!

Our Company


Medulla Oblongata Productions is a company founded by Franco De Crescentis who is happy to be premiering his directorial debut of 'Alex Cross and His Rise to Fame'. He's managed to assemble a very dedicated creative team and cast who all have strong backgrounds in theatre and film entertainment. This play will be a collaborative effort made by a talented group of emerging artists in the Montreal theatre scene.

The Creative Team

Playwright, Producer, Director - Franco De Crescentis
Assistant Producer, Production Manager - Mayumi Yoshida
Stage Manager - Amanda Goldberg
Prop Builder - Megumi Furihata
Lighting Designer - Michael Panich
Sound Design & Composer - Laurent Laigneaux

The Cast

Kenny Streule - Alex Cross
Donald Shepherd - Baal
Franco De Crescentis – Gavin
Jason Yearow - Narrator & Various Roles
Anne-Josie Roy - Various Roles
Catherine Karas - Various Roles
Daphne Morin - Various Roles
Jenny Walker - Various Roles
Kathleen Glynn - Various Roles
Stéphanie Bijou  Various Role
Yan Thivierge - Various Roles
  

When and Where

6 shows at one of Montreal's finest venues: The Mainline Theatre (3997 St. Laurent) as part of the St. Ambroise Montreal Fringe Festival.

Saturday, June 15 - 8:15 p.m.

Sunday, June 16 - 10:45 p.m.

Tuesday, June 18 - 9:45 p.m.

Wednesday, June 19 - 8:00 p.m.

Thursday, June 20 - 9:15 p.m.

Saturday, June 22 - 10:15 p.m.


Here is where you will be able to purchase your ticket: http://montrealfringe.ca/en/show/alex-cross-and-his-rise-fame

--

Hope to see you all at the show!! Until then, keep those souls in tact! And please stay tuned for updates!!

It sounds farfetched, but why does it seem that mainstream music artists are glorifying satanic images and ideas in their music, pictures and videos? Could it be that they've sold their souls??
'Alex Cross and His Rise to Fame' follows Dick Richards, a low life loser who would do anything to be famous but doesn't have the talent, charisma, or looks to get him there. That is, until he meets Baal, the CEO of Beelzebub Talents who gives Dick a new name 'Alexander Cross' and promises him a life of fame and fortune. Unbeknownst to the naive Dick, it will come at a cost - his soul!!Come follow Alex's journey during his rise to fame and learn the truth about the music industry when he is exposed by the conspiracy researcher who was once his greatest fan.
The Play
Faust meets Jesus Christ Superstar!
 'Alex Cross and His Rise to Fame' is a comedy that aims to entertain with it's 3 alternative endings.  A play that offers a sarcastic and satrical social commentary on the corporate dominance and commercialization of the music industry and the artists being exploited by it.
The Production
Created and presented by Medulla Oblongata Productions as part of the 23rd annual St. Ambroise Montreal Fringe Festival at the one and only Mainline Theatre, June 15 - June 25, 2013. 
It is a highly ambitious project but we've strapped ourselves in and are ready for a rockin' ride!
It is our aim to make this a highly professional and engaging show so that we can produce an unforgettable experience for our spectators and in doing so, to win the award for Best Production at the 2013 Fringe. To make this happen - we need your help and loving support!
Your contribution will help us to make this production everything that we are aiming and striving for it to be.

The Devil's In the Details 

Here's a breakdown of where the money from your kind donations will be going towards.

Venue Fee
Rehearsal Space rental
Props & Set building/renting
Costume for 11 actors
Make Up for 11 actors
Transportation
Our Press Kit Materials
Printing (Posters, Flyers, Programs)
And everything else!
Our campaign goal of $7000.00 is not enough to put on this show. However, reaching our Indiegogo campaign goal will allow us to be in a position that we can make a good show with the bare bones budget we've created. The closest that we can get to reaching our projected budget of $9,000 the closer we will be to being able to focus on the making the best show for our audience without the stress involved of finding funding. All of the artist involved in our show are dedicating their time to it on a volunteer basis because they truly believe in the project and want it to succeed so we would appreciate any help that we can get.
What You Will Get
Not in exchange for your souls, but in exchange for your kind donations, we would like to show our appreciation with the following perks. This is just a taste - for more information about what perks are given for your level of support, please refer to the column on the right.
A shout out to you on all of our social network profiles by one of our cast members.
Your name on the donation list at the front door of the show.
A 'thank you' post card written in character by one of the characters of your choice.
A CD containing Alex Cross' original song 'My Fallen Angel' which will also contain videos, music, and art work.
A special thanks to you within our production pamplet.
Two free tickets to the show and two free cupcakes from Montreal's own D Liche Cupcakes at the show.
And much more...
 
How You Can Help
Donating your money to our project would be the best way in which you could help us to make this a memorable production. However, if you simply can't afford it, we understand, but you can still help us by sharing our indiegogo page on your facebook timeline or liking and sharing our Facebook Fan Page.
We appreciate any way in which you can help us make this production happen!
Our Company
Medulla Oblongata Productions is a company founded by Franco De Crescentis who is happy to be premiering his directorial debut of 'Alex Cross and His Rise to Fame'. He's managed to assemble a very dedicated creative team and cast who all have strong backgrounds in theatre and film entertainment. This play will be a collaborative effort made by a talented group of emerging artists in the Montreal theatre scene.
The Creative Team
Playwright, Producer, Director - Franco De CrescentisAssistant Producer, Production Manager - Mayumi YoshidaStage Manager - Amanda GoldbergProp Builder - Megumi FurihataLighting Designer - Michael PanichSound Design & Composer - Laurent Laigneaux
The Cast
Kenny Streule - Alex Cross Donald Shepherd - Baal Franco De Crescentis – Gavin Jason Yearow - Narrator & Various Roles Anne-Josie Roy - Various Roles Catherine Karas - Various Roles Daphne Morin - Various Roles Jenny Walker - Various Roles Kathleen Glynn - Various Roles Stéphanie Bijou  Various Role Yan Thivierge - Various Roles  
When and Where
6 shows at one of Montreal's finest venues: The Mainline Theatre (3997 St. Laurent) as part of the St. Ambroise Montreal Fringe Festival.
Saturday, June 15 - 8:15 p.m.
Sunday, June 16 - 10:45 p.m.
Tuesday, June 18 - 9:45 p.m.
Wednesday, June 19 - 8:00 p.m.
Thursday, June 20 - 9:15 p.m.
Saturday, June 22 - 10:15 p.m.
Here is where you will be able to purchase your ticket: http://montrealfringe.ca/en/show/alex-cross-and-his-rise-fame
--
Hope to see you all at the show!! Until then, keep those souls in tact! And please stay tuned for updates!!

story:
Hi! I'm Emily, a senior at the Rhose Island School of Design in Providence, Rhode Island. I have been developing my thesis over the past several months and am turning it into an outdoor performance in the College Hill area of Providence. The piece involves involves elements of
  • puppet theatre
  • toy theatre,
  • mask work
  • music and
  • live actors, among other things.
The piece is based around the events of the Conquest of Mexico and the fall of the city of Tenochtitlán, with it's primary focus on the role of La Malinche . La Malinche (although she has many names: Malintzin, Malinali, Doña Marina, La Chingada), was a Nahua woman who was given to the Spanish conquistadors as a slave and who eventually became an advisor and translator to Hernan Cortés.

As someone of Latin American heritage, I feel both complicit in and, in a way, a victim of the horrors of the Conquest of Mexico and want to deal with:

  • the nature of Malinche's relationship with Cortés which is oftnen treated as a pseudodromantic Pocahontas/John Smith relationship
  • Malinche's serving a dual role as both the 'mother' of modern Mexico and a scapegoat for all of the atrocities of the Conquest of Mexico
  • her relationship to the Virgin of Guadalupe.

I also want to bring this story briefly into the present and tie La Malinche to  the thousands of modern women working in the Maquilas set up on the border.

The funding we need will go to costumes, set pieces and propos (some handmade and some purchased) that will really bring life to the piece. We are not sponsored by a studen organization so have no base funding but want so desperately to get the message of this piece and it's exploration of history out to the public.

I really believe that this piece will have an impact on both the college community and the public who are interested to come and watch it. Tickets are free because to us, this isn't about making money, it's about creating awareness but unfortunately, we need some funding to go about doing that in the first place.

The first received funding will go into the making of the costumes and props that we have designs for and if we do not reach our entire goal, the props we intended on buying, we will figure out a different way to create their effect in the show.

As well as funding, we would love your time and interest. Having an audience to receive, process and get talking about information and the events of the piece is more important that just how loud a crowd of people is clapping. Please spread the word about both the physical show and the Indiegogo campaign through Indiegogo's share tools.

Thank you so much!

Emily and the "I Am One of Them and So Are You" team

story:
Hello and welcome to my campaign

Hi I'm Solomon, I'm 17 and a dancer from Brighton, England. I am honoured to have been offered a place at the prestigious contemporary dance school P.A.R.T.S.(Performing Arts Training and Research Studios) in Belgium starting this September 2013 for 3 years. The school conducted auditions in 23 countries and over 1000 people auditioned for just 50 places! I feel priveledged to have been selected for professional training, and one year before the minimum age requirement. I however cannot take up this place without your support and fulfil my dream to become a professional dancer.

'Talent is not enough by itself. It needs structure and support' Akram Khan

 

What I need from you

I have to raise £7,500 and with your contribution you will allow me to take up my place at P.A.R.T.S. by paying for:

  • Course fees and registration  £6500
  • Setting myself up in Belgium and living costs for the first month £1000

No contribution is too small. Every pound counts and will be much appreciated. Studying outside the UK I am not eligible for a student loan from Student Finance England. It will be such a shame and soul-destroying to be deprived of this rare opportunity solely due to having no financial support. Your contributions will be deeply valued and fully support me on my dance journey. Thank you.

If you look to the right, you will see what you can get as a heartfelt thank you for supporting me!

 

The Impact

The rigorous and holistic training programme at P.A.R.T.S. and access to the world's most established and recognised dance artists will undoubtedly give me an advantage in the highly competitive dance world. For the last 4 years and since the age of 13 I have spent up to 6 days a week travelling the 4 hour round trip to London for training, rehearsals and performances and it is this drive and dedication that has got me to where I am now.  Your investment in me at this key point in my development will help me to become part of the inspiring dance talent that comes out of P.A.R.T.S.

Please follow this link http://www.parts.be/ if you would like to find out more about P.A.R.T.S.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute to my campaign please spread the word and pass on to anyone that you think can. You can do this by using the Indiegogo share tools above.

Thank you for your time and support.

Best wishes,
Solomon

story:
OUR STORY:

For 20 years City of Angels Ballet has offered free ballet classes to children from underserved communities. City of Angels Ballet has worked with over 35,000 children from the Los Angeles Unified School District at no cost to the schools, the city or the children’s families. City of Angels Ballet has been featured on CBS Sunday Morning, LatiNation, an Emmy nominated piece by the Los Angeles City Channel, the Los Angeles Times, and numerous other local news programs. Our children have performed at the Los Angeles Music Center, the Orange County Performing Arts Center, Universal Amphitheater and the Japan American Center. Additionally, the children give back to the community by performing at Children’s Hospital, at an AIDS fundraiser in Riverside, CA and at local schools, community festivals and outreach performances to invited audiences of over 6,000 other children and the elderly.

The Founder and Artistic Director of the City of Angels Ballet, Mario Nugara was trained at the School of American Ballet, the official school of the New York City Ballet. He performed with the Boston Ballet, Fort Worth Ballet and on Broadway. Mr. Nugara has a BFA and MFA from New York University’s Tisch School of the Arts and was a Fulbright Scholar in conjunction with the Royal Danish Ballet and the University of Copenhagen. He has taught in the United States and Europe on the professional, university and student level.

THE NEXT STEP:

We continue to pull talented youth from some of the most underserved communities in Los Angeles and offer opportunities to the children through City of Angels Ballet's outreach programs. Children from the City of Angels Ballet School are immersed into a professional dance setting and often receive opportunities to perform alongside professional ballet dancers from the City of Angels Ballet. As these children develop an affinity for dance a door opens into a new world full of possibilities. 98% of our students at the City of Angels Ballet School are on full scholarship. The City of Angels Ballet School is the only not-for-profit ballet school in Los Angeles focused exclusively on developing and producing exceptional ballet dancers.

 

Some of City of Angels Ballet’s immediate goals include:

  • producing a full length ballet, which would provide our students invaluable performance opportunities
  • building a youth ballet
  • theatre  rental for upcoming performances
  • obtaining new costumes
  • increasing our outreach program
  • hiring an executive director
  • hiring a grant-writer/director of fundraising
  • adding more children’s classes to the curriculum

WHAT’S IN IT FOR YOU?

In recognition of your support, certain "perks" will be made available.  Everything from recognition on our highly trafficked website to a weekend trip for two to Los Angeles, CA! (includes roundtrip airfare & hotel)* Please, pledge today.  

*Trip to LA Excludes Hawaii and Alaska

 OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP:

Please help us get the word out about this campaign by sharing it with your friends by either word of mouth, posting on facebook, twitter, and other social media platforms. Please tell anyone and everyone! We genuinely appreciate your help.

If interested you may also make a tax deductible charitable contribution please contact us. (These gifts are not tax deductible unless rewards are "refused." Just click "make contribution." Then select the one at the very bottom of the page that lets you fill in your amount and states you are interested in no perks. If you goofed it up - no worries, we'll figure it out at the end of the campaign.)

Lastly, making your donation anonymously is also an option.

A sincere and heartfelt thank you from all of us at CAB and the children whose lives you will change for the better and give an opportunity of a lifetime!!

story:
Southwest Rural Theatre Project

A theatrical, performance based, endeavor dedicated to bringing the live theatre experience to rural areas of the American Southwest; educating and enriching lives by providing an outlet for creative community and professional involvement.

 

Part of what we do involves taking theater to parts of the rural southwest that doesn’t have easy access to theater. Another part of our tours involves going to places where the residents are no longer capable of going to the theater such as assisted living homes and senior centers. Our recent tour of Travelin’ Show travelled to 9 different assisted living homes and senior centers to perform to those who can’t come to us.

 

Your donations help us continue to bring this joy to these people as well as support our workshops. We are frequently casting our shows to include both seasoned actors/actresses as well as those who want to learn to act and work in a theater company.

 

Our upcoming season includes:

  • Miracle Worker - directed by Kamila Kasperian - August 10 through September 2
  • Touring Melodrama (TBA) - directed by Mike Lash - tour dates begin August 18
  • 2 One Acts - directed by Lena Baxley - September 7 through 23
  • Dark Of The Moon - directed by Leslie Joy Coleman - October 5 through 28
  • The Truth About Santa - directed by Jason Deuter - December 7 through 30
  • The Imaginary Invalid - directed by Jason Deuter - January 4-27, 2013
  • Love Rides The Rails - directed by Leslie Joy Coleman - February 8-March 3, 2013

What We Need & What You Get

We have been operating on a light system that is make shift and is becoming more and more unsuitable to our theatrical needs. By producing shows in our own venue, and raising funds in addition, we are able to promote and grow our mission to serve rural areas. With each new touring show, we are adding venues to our repertoire of spaces. 

We gladly thank people who contribute publicly in our programs, on our website and provide tax exempt receipts through our non-profit status.

The Impact

Your contributions will help promote our theater to continue our endeavors to serve the community both in our house and the places we travel too.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you want to help, but cannot help financially, please feel free to visit our website at www.swrtp.org and contact us to volunteer. We are always happy to take donations for props and clothing as well.

story:
UPDATE: We want to give a big THANK YOU to all of our donors who contributed to our indiegogo campaign for "The Alembic!" Now that we've met our initial goal, we can move on to stretch goals! Our next project will be a music video for our last show of the 2012 season, "In the Observarium," a chilling, live version of stories similar to those depicted in "Night Gallery," and "The Twilight Zone," but with all of those delightful and unsettling Victorian aesthetics that we love so much. One last contribution can really push us forward into the black for this project, and beyond!

Thank you for visiting Terra Mysterium’s Indiegogo page supporting our new show “The Alembic.”  We are a four-year old theatre troupe producing original works rooted in mythology, Earth mysteries, and positive transformation of the human condition. 

This is a tough time for young arts organizations.  Most new theatre companies discontinue their work after three years.  We’ve pushed past that barrier, and have an amazing piece of musical theatre to share with the world, but we need your help.

For the past three years, Terra Mysterium company members have purchased and made their own properties, costumes, and sets.  We are now entering into a new phase in our development by producing works that are intended for touring and repeat performances on the road.  This requires hiring professionals with experience to create sets, costumes, and properties meant to last a lifetime in order to give our audiences theatrical experiences they will remember. 

What We Need & What You Get

Our current, actual expenses are listed below:

Performers’ Stipends:

            TOTAL: $400

Set-Design/Build:

            TOTAL:  $400

Costume Design and Build:

            TOTAL: $1400

Stage Manager Stipend:

            $100

Properties:

            $300

Rehearsal Space:

            $300

Marketing:

            $100

Your contribution will create a lasting piece of theatre that can tour various festivals, conventions, and private parties. 

Should we not reach our goal, we are already committed to producing “The Alembic” at this year’s Chicago Fringe Festival, and we will open on Friday August, 31st at 7pm. We just might have to open without a set and in our underwear if you can’t help us. *grin* (And believe me, a Steampunk musical without costumes, set, or properties isn’t theatre we intend for you to see.)

The Impact

Terra Mysterium has grown in leaps and bounds beyond our first production in April of 2008.  We’ve touched people’s lives through our original songs, stories, and ritual theatre creations.  We’ve played at festivals around the Midwest, and deeply desire to widen that circle internationally in the next five years.  We are modern-day players reminding people of the sacred in the world around them and of the power of positive transformation.  You can help us to carry these stories into the wider world.

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that not everyone is in a position to make a donation at this time.  However, can you get word out about our campaign to your friends?  Please use the Indiegogo share tools, share our promotional videos and photos, and come see the show!

We know that not everyone is in a position to make a donation at this time.  However, can you get word out about our campaign to your friends?  Please use the Indiegogo share tools, share our promotional videos and photos, and come see the show!

story:
"If you can imagine it, you can achieve it; if you can dream it, you can become it."

-William Arthur Ward


Summary

Hello! My name is Alexandra and I am a ballet dancer from San Francisco. I began ballet when I was 3 and entered pre-professional training when I was 10. I’ve trained in San Francisco, New York City, and in Moscow, Russia at the Bolshoi Ballet Academy. This summer I trained in Finland with the famed Vaganova Academy of Ballet from St. Petersburg. In addition to my artistic skills, I am fluent in Russian and hold a B.A. in Slavic Languages and Literatures from University of California, Santa Barbara and a Kathryn Davis Fellowship for Peace from Middlebury College. I’ve had a wide array of experiences and endured many challenges that have prepared me to take on the professional world of ballet. I’m ready!

This campaign is very important to me, because more than just dedication and talent go into the process of being accepted to a company; finances play a huge role to pull this off. These last several months I have been working part-time, in addition to my daily hours of training. I fully funded my training program in Finland, as well as travel there and back. I have also been fully responsible for all ballet-related expenses this last year. I have been dedicating everything I have to this endeavor, but the last few months have been more difficult in terms of expenses, as I upped my training load significantly these last several months. The more I train, the less time I have to work to earn money to pay for training..  
Contributors will help me to achieve so much! They will help me to pay off training expenses from the last few months, but mostly they will fund my audition season in the months to come! As I hear back from companies responding to my submissions, I will find out whether or not they are interested in me as a potential company member. If so, I fly off to whatever city in whatever country the company is in and audition for them in person. I anticipate that January and February will involve lots of international travel and, of course, expenses. 

Thank you for your consideration!

How Will the Money Be Used?

My fundraising goal is to raise $10,000. This money will cover my day-to-day training costs, as well as audition-specific expenses, through February 2017. I've laid out details below to give a better understanding of how much certain things cost. And remember- there are special perks for all levels of donations!

Costs of training expenses:

$100/hr.- Private training with ballet coaches for technique, pointe, variations

$95- Pointe shoes

$8- Open ballet class

$75/class- Private Pilates cross training

$30/hr.- Studio rental 

$75/class.- Rhythmic gymnastics cross training

$50/appointment- Acupuncture 

 

Audition-specific expenses:

$1,300- Photo shoot for audition photos to send to companies

$200- Makeup artist for photo shoot

$350- Roundtrip flight to NYC from SF for photo shoot

$175/session- Videographer for audition variations 

$TBD- Roundtrip plane flights to the companies in US/Europe that I get accepted to audition at

$TBD- Room and board while auditioning January-February 

If I Raise Less?

What will I do if I receive less than $10,000? I will continue with my audition and training plans and use the funds allotted to me to cover the most expenses that I can. The rest I will figure out myself, as I have been doing. I will be in some credit card debt, but it will be worth it to achieve my lifelong goal. 

If I Raise More? 

$10,000 is the amount estimated to cover my training and audition expenses through February, but my work doesn't end there! Even after the audition process is complete and I have signed a contract with a company to begin dancing at in the fall, I will be working hard to improve in my field and prepare for my transition to the professional world. There are also a few activities that I would like to add to my regular training schedule and extra money would go towards paying for these.
These include: additional Pilates coaching, 10-series Zen Bodytherapy TM and Structural Integration, and One on One Prime Sport Coaching with Dr. Jim Taylor. 
There is also one coach of mine who has been training me absolutely for free!!! He believes in me so much and has dedicated so much time and energy to my improvement and has never asked for anything in return, other than my hard work and dedication. I would love to surprise him with a gift of $1,000 for Christmas to express my thanks (along with a signed company contract soon too!).

Risks & Challenges

Of course, there are no guarantees in this competitive audition process or in the subjective ballet-world in general. All I can say is that I have prepared my hardest for this opportunity and have the support of well known individuals in the field who believe in my success. I also believe in my abilities and have confidence moving forward with this process. I have strength and endurance to face whatever lies ahead. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you do not have the means to financially contribute to my campaign there are still other ways you can help! Even for people who do donate money, please follow up with the following actions: 

  • Spread the word! Please share this campaign on Facebook, Instagram, and other social media, email it to friends and family, and share with the performing arts community and dance philanthropists. The Indiegogo share tools make this a piece of cake!
  • If you have airline miles built up and wish to donate your miles instead of money that is of great help! Much of my next couple months will involve flying to different cities in the US and Europe, so help with plane tickets goes a long way!

story:
In 2017, Spark Movement Collective will premiere The Velveteen Rabbit in March at The Town School and Spark Collections of Change in September at the Actors Fund Arts Center.

Spark premieres a contemporary take on the well-loved story The Velveteen Rabbit by combining dance, shadow play, and puppetry to create an engaging show for families to enjoy together. This new twist on The Velveteen Rabbit has a resounding emphasis on the importance of play. In the show, the title character, the Velveteen Rabbit is quickly passed over by 'The Boy', and is tossed aside for more high-tech toys like iPads. One day the Boy begins to play with his Velveteen Rabbit again and they go on many imaginary adventures together. From their adventures traveling to outer space to deep-sea diving, the audience witnesses how using one’s imagination has no limits.

Spark’s newest addition to its annual performances is Spark Collections of Change, a biannual performance series featuring choreography by past and present company dancers created around a theme. The premiere performances will include all original works centering around the concept of change. Spark’s creative process heavily involves each dancer’s creative voice, and Spark Collections of Change will give dancers the opportunity take on leadership roles as choreographers and guide the creative process.

For the past seven years, Spark has achieved its mission of providing accessible dance experiences due in large part to the generosity of family, friends, and patrons. A tax-deductible donation of any amount will put us closer to our goal!

Spark must raise $5,000 to cover operational costs associated with the production, which includes the rental fees and rehearsal space.  

The second phase of our campaign provides stipends for the artists. Spark’s dancers are incredibly talented performers who dedicate so much of their creativity and craft to the company. Our dancers spend months in rehearsal studios developing and refining choreography, including 50+ hours preparing for each show. This goal also funds live our puppet maker, costume designers, and other crucial personnel that make Spark's productions possible.

 

Q: If you are selling tickets to the performance why do you need to raise money outside of the Box Office?

A: Ticket Sales typically cover a very small percentage of production costs for most performing arts organizations. At Spark, part of our mission is to create accessible dance experiences and one way we do that is by keeping ticket costs low.  Because of support from our generous donors, we’re able to stay true to our mission and continue to offer affordable tickets to our performances.

 

Q: How long does it take to create a performance like this?

A: Spark rehearses 3-6 hours a week for 5 months when developing a new work. Artistic Director, Chelsea Koenig, also works independently with composers and graphic designers to integrate additional art mediums into the show.

story:
So heres the deal..

The Acadiana Repertory Theatre is so thrilled to announce its inaugural New Works Festival. We have selected 10 shows submitted from all over the country and will have readings of these shows over the course of two weekends at Lafayette's newest theatre venue, Theatre 810. 

Our main purpose of the festival? To give our audience a voice in helping us to select shows for the next couple of seasons. Audiences will get a chance to rate each show and let us know if they would want to see it brought to full production. 

So, why do we need help? 

We want to make sure that this goes off without a hitch, especially because we want to make it a yearly tradition. And since we are giving the public a hand in choosing our shows, we are asking the public to give us a hand to make this the best festival it can be! 

What if we dont reach our goal?

Its flexible funding! So what is donated goes to the project! Its a great deal for everyone involved.

How else can you help?

Social media is a powerful thing! Help spread the word on facebook and twitter. Email your friends and family. Or even email us and tell us you want to get involved!

And of course BUY TICKETS:)

visit www.acadianarepnewworks.eventbrite.com to get your tickets now!

Make sure to visit our website and facebook page for up to the minute info on the festival, info on the plays and the playwrights, and info on all the great people that make up the Acadiana Repertory Theatre!

story:
No video? Make sure your flash player is up to date! Adobe Flash Player

When it comes to exposure to classical art forms, most students are overlooked or under stimulated.

But we're going to change that.

We want to challenge students to explore their own place in the world through the lens of classical theatre.

For four weeks during Summer 2013, fifteen to twenty upper Manhattan high school students will join with teaching artists from the Classical Theatre of Harlem for an immersive workshop. The curriculum will include theatre technique, history, and rehearsals. The workshop will culminate with three public performances of a classical theatre piece at an outdoor theatre space in upper Manhattan.

For more info about the workshop visit our website or send us an email at UMClassical@gmail.com for a complete workshop outline

This campaign will be the start-up money to get the UMCT Youth Workshop off the ground. Our full budget will be broken down like this:

 

Former student and teacher, producers Matt Payne and Garyallen Glass have been friends for over a decade. Garyallen has extensive experience teaching at both the high school and collegiate levels and holds a BA in Music from the University of Evansville and a MM in Vocal Performance from the University of Kentucky. He has also been involved in project development for Statement Arts, an arts education nonprofit in NYC. Matt has a BFA in Musical Theatre and has worked professionally as an actor and writer, with a wealth of experience in classical melodrama. His expertise extends into theatre for young audiences, performing and working with children in all levels of schooling.

Incorporated in 2005, the mission of The Shabazz Center is to continue the work of Malcolm X and Dr. Betty Shabazz through the advancement of human rights and social justice. The Shabazz Center was founded to serve as a memorial, educational, cultural, and civic resource for organizations and individuals seeking to honor the lives and ideals of these two dynamic leaders.

Advancement in human rights and social justice includes racial and gender equality, women and youth empowerment, community development and security, and economic opportunity both in America and globally. The Shabazz Center provides an important programmatic space to further these goals through educational programs in the humanities, arts and culture. Activities such as exhibitions, lectures, conversation series, workshops, and conferences fit squarely within the Center's core mission.

  1. Tell everyone you know about the UMCT Youth Workshop 2013. We want the whole world to know about the great work going on in our community.
  2. Check out OUR WEBSITE and OUR FACEBOOK PAGE.
  3. Shoot us an email. We can always use an extra brain and set of hands. We'd love to get to know you and your story, too!

The Shabazz Center is a 501(c)3 nonprofit organization. All donations are tax deductible to the extent allowed by law.

story:
What is this project?

We are creating a new piece of theater using poems, plays, short stories and other texts by the grand dame of American wit, Dorothy Parker. Ms. Parker portrays the human condition with great humor and compassion. She is shrewd in her observations of men and women and she delights in the absurd and the everyday. We will relate her insight to our contemporary life. We will wrestle with her texts to form a dynamic theatrical experience. 

 This piece will dive into questions about:

—isolation and alienation

—facing the void (existence)

—the need for love and connection

—male-female relationships

—the confines of societal codes

—the human voice

 Our process is highly collaborative—a big, juicy artistic stew. We begin with investigation: solo and also as a group. We will generate our ideas practically and cerebrally. We will work on our feet. We will get messy with art. We will throw out ideas and images and possible avenues. And we will shave them and hone them into a collective vision that is our springboard. The exploration of this vision is the meat of our process. We will ask a lot of questions. We will test our ideas, sculpt moments, and rigorously explore of our artistic impulses. We will craft an experience for an audience and share this creation. Dialogue with an audience is an opportunity for us to learn how our piece functions and see avenues for further development.

 

How are you doing it?

We will begin our investigation in a 5-day residency at the Dragon's Egg in Mystic, Ct. There we will dive into the pile of texts with wild abandon dividing our time between dramaturgical and physical explorations. After that, we head into a 6-day residency at Dartmouth College, sponsored by VOX Theater (www.voxtheater.org), which will culminate in a public workshop performance and feedback session. In May 2013, we will return to Dartmouth College to perform the first draft of our new piece in VOX Theater’s inaugural VOX Fest at the Hopkins Center. 

 

Our Funding

We are seeking funding for expenses directly related to the development of this new piece of American art. 

Dartmouth College and VOX Theater are generously sponsoring a large part of our transportation, space needs, and food and housing for the residencies. 

 However, we still need $3000 to cover:

—Materials for sets, costumes and lights

—Artist fees

—Additional transportation and space rental

Every penny donated goes directly to the resources needed to bring this new work to life and put it on the path to a full production. 

 

Our Team

Hannah Chodos (ACTOR) After graduating from Dartmouth in 2006, Hannah returned to her hometown of Los Angeles.  She became involved with The Actors’ Gang (Artistic Director, Tim Robbins) in 2004, while she was still a student at Dartmouth, and has been training and performing with the company ever since.  She is currently a teacher with The Actors’ Gang’s Prison Project, whose mission is to rehabilitate inmates through a creative process, using the company’s unique form of commedia dell’arte.  In 2007, she toured New York, New England, and South Africa with The Savannah Theatre Project, and in January of 2013, she’ll go on a national tour with The Actors’ Gang’s production of Tartuffe, in the role of Marianne.  In Los Angeles, she continues to work in film and TV, and has completed production on one (very) short film of her own (Tuesday – written by, and starring Hannah Chodos). www.hannahchodos.com 

Brough Hansen (ACTOR) (pronounced 'Bruff') is a recent graduate of the Brown/Trinity Rep MFA Acting program. As an undergraduate at Dartmouth College, he enjoyed roles in The Imaginary Invalid and The Underpants, and had the privilege of playing the titular character in an early bench reading of Wendy Wasserstein's final play, Third. He has written three full-length plays. He is a certified downhill ski instructor.

Thom Pasculli (ACTOR) is an actor, writer, and director currently based in Chicago.  Most recently he directed The Reluctant Lesbian (New York Fringe Festival), was the assistant director for Tina Landau’s Hot L Baltimore (Steppenwolf Theatre), and was the movement director for Amahl and the Night Visitors (Lincoln Center). Recent performances include Spectacle Lunatique (Redmoon Theatre, Chicago), Double Edge Theatre’s the UnPossessed (The Kennedy Center, Washington D.C.), Freedom! and The Sticky End of Make-Believe (Hilton Arts Festival in South Africa, New York Fringe Festival), Ageless: Festuge (Hostlebro, Demark), and Se Questo E un Uomo (Moscow Art School Studio). He is a former company member of Double Edge Theatre and has studied with Eugenio Barba and the Odin Teatret in Denmark and at the Grotowski Center in Poland. Pasculli has developed and produced new works and programs based on his physical training in South Africa, Colorado and New York. Awards include two Princess Grace Awars, the Dartmouth General Grant, and the David Birney Award for Excellence in Theatre Arts. BA: Dartmouth College. www.thompasculli.com 

Marina McClure (DIRECTOR) is a director of theater, opera, site-specific performance, public art, and installations. Her works confront injustice and advocate for the oppressed, the voiceless, the women, the queers, the outsiders. Her pieces are aesthetically sharp and often rooted in a distinct physical vocabulary. Her process is open and collaborative, favoring interdisciplinarity and a spirit of generosity. Marina’s work has been seen at REDCAT, The Kennedy Center, Manhattan Theater Source, The Eugene O'Neill Theater Center, New York & Capital Fringe Festivals, and in found spaces and theaters in Los Angeles, Washington DC, New York, New Hampshire, and South Africa. She is currently working with Handspring Puppet Company in South Africa and will assist Anne Bogart with SITI Company’s Trojan Women for this year’s Next Wave Festival at BAM. Awards include a General-Campbell Fellowship, FAR Space Artist Residency, and the Gurdin Directing Award. BA: Dartmouth College, MFA: CalArts. www.marinamcclure.com 

Erin O’Donnell (DESIGNER) is a puppet designer and scenic artist. Her puppet work incorporates live music and movement, and she specializes in handcrafted objects meant for live performance and manipulation. Her objects are charming and have an aesthetic appeal, even when stationary. She has created numerous puppet performances and installations, and recently expanded her artistic practice to include stop motion animation, directing and live action film. Erin has collaborated with Peter Schumann and Bread and Puppet, Mark Sussman and most recently with artist Allison Saar on the set and sculpture design for Garth Fagan and Wynton Marsalis’ show Lighthouse/Lightning Rod at BAM. BFA in Design for Theatre, BA in Western Society and Culture: Concordia University, MFA in Scenic Painting and Puppetry: CalArts. http://erinodo.carbonmade.com 

Shelly Rodriguez (DESIGNER) uses light to create art that is relevant, innovative and risk-taking. Shadow-work and exploration of the materiality of light are integral to her aesthetic. Her designs often blend creative whimsy with the dramatic, yielding memorable pieces. Shelly has lit for theater, dance, opera and performance art in New York, Philadelphia, Los Angeles, Texas and at the Williamstown Theatre Festival. She studied under Don Holder and Anne Militello, and has assisted Don Holder, Rebecca Makus, Jeanette Yew and Mark Simpson. She is currently assisting Don Holder with design for the hit television series Smash. BFA: Baylor University, MFA: CalArts. www.shellynrodriguez.com
