We will relate her insight to our contemporary life. We will wrestle with her texts to form a dynamic theatrical experience. 
 This piece will dive into questions about:
—isolation and alienation
—facing the void (existence)
—the need for love and connection
—male-female relationships
—the confines of societal codes
—the human voice
 Our process is highly collaborative—a big, juicy artistic stew. We begin with investigation: solo and also as a group. We will generate our ideas practically and cerebrally. We will work on our feet. We will get messy with art. We will throw out ideas and images and possible avenues. And we will shave them and hone them into a collective vision that is our springboard. The exploration of this vision is the meat of our process. We will ask a lot of questions. We will test our ideas, sculpt moments, and rigorously explore of our artistic impulses. We will craft an experience for an audience and share this creation. Dialogue with an audience is an opportunity for us to learn how our piece functions and see avenues for further development.
 
How are you doing it?
We will begin our investigation in a 5-day residency at the Dragon's Egg in Mystic, Ct. There we will dive into the pile of texts with wild abandon dividing our time between dramaturgical and physical explorations. After that, we head into a 6-day residency at Dartmouth College, sponsored by VOX Theater (www.voxtheater.org), which will culminate in a public workshop performance and feedback session. In May 2013, we will return to Dartmouth College to perform the first draft of our new piece in VOX Theater’s inaugural VOX Fest at the Hopkins Center. 
 
Our Funding
We are seeking funding for expenses directly related to the development of this new piece of American art. 
Dartmouth College and VOX Theater are generously sponsoring a large part of our transportation, space needs, and food and housing for the residencies. 
 However, we still need $3000 to cover:
—Materials for sets, costumes and lights
—Artist fees
—Additional transportation and space rental
Every penny donated goes directly to the resources needed to bring this new work to life and put it on the path to a full production. 
 
Our Team
Hannah Chodos (ACTOR) After graduating from Dartmouth in 2006, Hannah returned to her hometown of Los Angeles.  She became involved with The Actors’ Gang (Artistic Director, Tim Robbins) in 2004, while she was still a student at Dartmouth, and has been training and performing with the company ever since.  She is currently a teacher with The Actors’ Gang’s Prison Project, whose mission is to rehabilitate inmates through a creative process, using the company’s unique form of commedia dell’arte.  In 2007, she toured New York, New England, and South Africa with The Savannah Theatre Project, and in January of 2013, she’ll go on a national tour with The Actors’ Gang’s production of Tartuffe, in the role of Marianne.  In Los Angeles, she continues to work in film and TV, and has completed production on one (very) short film of her own (Tuesday – written by, and starring Hannah Chodos). www.hannahchodos.com 
Brough Hansen (ACTOR) (pronounced 'Bruff') is a recent graduate of the Brown/Trinity Rep MFA Acting program. As an undergraduate at Dartmouth College, he enjoyed roles in The Imaginary Invalid and The Underpants, and had the privilege of playing the titular character in an early bench reading of Wendy Wasserstein's final play, Third. He has written three full-length plays. He is a certified downhill ski instructor.
Thom Pasculli (ACTOR) is an actor, writer, and director currently based in Chicago.  Most recently he directed The Reluctant Lesbian (New York Fringe Festival), was the assistant director for Tina Landau’s Hot L Baltimore (Steppenwolf Theatre), and was the movement director for Amahl and the Night Visitors (Lincoln Center). Recent performances include Spectacle Lunatique (Redmoon Theatre, Chicago), Double Edge Theatre’s the UnPossessed (The Kennedy Center, Washington D.C.), Freedom! and The Sticky End of Make-Believe (Hilton Arts Festival in South Africa, New York Fringe Festival), Ageless: Festuge (Hostlebro, Demark), and Se Questo E un Uomo (Moscow Art School Studio). He is a former company member of Double Edge Theatre and has studied with Eugenio Barba and the Odin Teatret in Denmark and at the Grotowski Center in Poland. Pasculli has developed and produced new works and programs based on his physical training in South Africa, Colorado and New York. Awards include two Princess Grace Awars, the Dartmouth General Grant, and the David Birney Award for Excellence in Theatre Arts. BA: Dartmouth College. www.thompasculli.com 
Marina McClure (DIRECTOR) is a director of theater, opera, site-specific performance, public art, and installations. Her works confront injustice and advocate for the oppressed, the voiceless, the women, the queers, the outsiders. Her pieces are aesthetically sharp and often rooted in a distinct physical vocabulary. Her process is open and collaborative, favoring interdisciplinarity and a spirit of generosity. Marina’s work has been seen at REDCAT, The Kennedy Center, Manhattan Theater Source, The Eugene O'Neill Theater Center, New York & Capital Fringe Festivals, and in found spaces and theaters in Los Angeles, Washington DC, New York, New Hampshire, and South Africa. She is currently working with Handspring Puppet Company in South Africa and will assist Anne Bogart with SITI Company’s Trojan Women for this year’s Next Wave Festival at BAM. Awards include a General-Campbell Fellowship, FAR Space Artist Residency, and the Gurdin Directing Award. BA: Dartmouth College, MFA: CalArts. www.marinamcclure.com 
Erin O’Donnell (DESIGNER) is a puppet designer and scenic artist. Her puppet work incorporates live music and movement, and she specializes in handcrafted objects meant for live performance and manipulation. Her objects are charming and have an aesthetic appeal, even when stationary. She has created numerous puppet performances and installations, and recently expanded her artistic practice to include stop motion animation, directing and live action film. Erin has collaborated with Peter Schumann and Bread and Puppet, Mark Sussman and most recently with artist Allison Saar on the set and sculpture design for Garth Fagan and Wynton Marsalis’ show Lighthouse/Lightning Rod at BAM. BFA in Design for Theatre, BA in Western Society and Culture: Concordia University, MFA in Scenic Painting and Puppetry: CalArts. http://erinodo.carbonmade.com 
Shelly Rodriguez (DESIGNER) uses light to create art that is relevant, innovative and risk-taking. Shadow-work and exploration of the materiality of light are integral to her aesthetic. Her designs often blend creative whimsy with the dramatic, yielding memorable pieces. Shelly has lit for theater, dance, opera and performance art in New York, Philadelphia, Los Angeles, Texas and at the Williamstown Theatre Festival. She studied under Don Holder and Anne Militello, and has assisted Don Holder, Rebecca Makus, Jeanette Yew and Mark Simpson. She is currently assisting Don Holder with design for the hit television series Smash. BFA: Baylor University, MFA: CalArts. www.shellynrodriguez.com

story:
From our Director:

My name is Sean Pollock and I'm a NYC based theatre artist. I've been directing for ten years this September, and I'm thrilled to be making my mark on NYC a decade later with this thrilling revival with Cupcake Lady Productions.

Hazelwood Jr. High is a very special play to me. It's not done a lot, and I'm really thrilled to be bringing it back to New York since its original production in 1998. I found out about it through stalking Chloe Sevigny's Wikipedia page a few years ago (she played Laurie in the original production). I was fascinated by the play's description, so I ordered a copy online and the rest is history. Rob (Urbinati, the playwright) has been so incredibly supportive and resourceful as has Cupcake Lady Productions and my AD/SM, Sean I've really lucked out. While certainly the story of Shanda Sharer is without a doubt completely devastating, it's one I think the public needs to remember. We need to be able to talk about teen sexuality and LGBT issues with adolescences in and outside of the classrooms. As serial killer Aileen Wuornos once said, "if you can't be a good example at least be a terrible warning." This play is a terrible warning of what happens when parents, teachers and legal counselors look the other way when they don't know how to deal with these issues. 

I came out as a gay person starting when I was 13--though not officially til I was 14. It's a hard time to know who you are that young, though I think it saved me a lot of grief in the long run. I see a lot of myself and my peers in these girls. They're just trying to have agency in a world that keeps telling them no and that they're not old enough. For the most part, they know who they are and who they want to be. But they're just having trouble getting from point A to point B. This production is going to be different--we're going to be fully immersed in the world of these young girls. I don't want to give too much away, but I can tell you this story has never been staged quite in this way before. It's very exciting.

Also, because giving back to our community is important to me, thanks to Mayday Space (where the show is being held) we are presenting the show as an admission-free event with suggested donations to benefit the Ali Forney Center for Homeless LGBT Youth. Because of this, Cupcake Lady Productions is hosting this as a charity production to benefit this cause. So, we need some help to make this happen...

WHY WE NEED YOU

$250: Props and Costumes

$200: Rehearsal and Performance Space

$150: Actor stipends

 

CAST AND CREW

Tech team: Laura Mae Baker (Costumes, run crew), Melissa Farinelli (Lighting designer) and Rich Wisnesksi (Sound Designer)

PR and Marketing: Bronwyn Bishop and Michael Rehse

Starring:

Eve Kummer-Landau (Shanda) 
Bear Spiegel (Amanda)
Patricia Yeazell (Melinda) 
Kristin Dawn-Dumas (Laurie)
Marielle Young (Toni) 
Sofie Zamchick (Hope)

 

Cupcake Lady Productions presents the first New York City revival of: HAZELWOOD JR. HIGH by Rob Urbinati

Tickets available here at no charge:

https://web.ovationtix.com/trs/pr/965457

November 11th & 18th at 8:00 p.m.

November 12th, 13th, and 19th at 7:30 p.m.

 

Hazelwood Jr. High is performed with permission from Samuel French, Inc.

 

Rob Urbinati is a freelance director and playwright based in New York City. He has directed at Public Theater, Culture Project, Abingdon Theatre, Classic Stage Company, Pearl Theatre, Lincoln Center Directors Lab, New York Music Theatre Festival, New York University and theatres and universities across the country. Rob’s plays include Hazelwood Jr. High, Miss Julie in Hollywood, Rebel Voices, Cruel & Barbarous Treatment, Karaoke Night at the Suicide Shack, The Queen Bees, West Moon Street, Nymph Errant, Death by Design, and UMW: University of Mostly Whites. Hazelwood Jr. High, West Moon Street and Death By Design have been published by Samuel French, who will also be publishing The Queen Bees, Rebel Voices and Nymph Errant. UMW: University of Mostly Whites was published by Steel Springs Stage Rights, and his book, “Play Readings: A Complete Guide for Theatre Practitioners” was published by Focal Press/Routledge. His new play, Mama's Boy, opened recently at George Street Playhouse. Rob is Director of New Play Development at Queens Theatre. He is an alumnus of the Drama League Directors Project and The Lincoln Center Theater Directors Lab. His plays have received over one hundred productions world-wide.

 

Sean Pollock (Director) is a Brooklyn based writer, director, designer, creator, artist and photographer. Training: Ithaca College/NTI. Recent work: Gentlemen Prefer Bottoms at Dixon Place (Director/Designer), AFLIC at Fresh Fruits (Writer/Designer), The Y2K Play at MITF & The Tank (Writer), Jellybean Junkyard with Playlight Theatre Company (Writer). Upcoming: Silent Night Bloody Night with the Blood Brothers presents... and One and Done Productions (Director/Deviser/Designer). He also serves as the Literary Manager for Playlight Theatre Company and the Social Media Manager for the Blood Brothers present... eternal love and gratitude to Lil Sean, Rob, The Cupcake Lady team, Prod Staff and this incredible cast of female identified performers. www.seanpollock.net, Instagram: @seanpollockart

 

Hazelwood Jr. High features Eve Kummer-Landau as Shanda, Sofie Zamchick as Hope, Marielle Young as Toni, Bear Spiegel as Amanda, Patricia Yeazell as Melinda, and Kristin Dawn-Dumas as Laurie. Creative team includes Sean Morris (Assistant Director/Stage Manager), Laura Mae Baker (Costume Designer), Rich Wisneski (Fight Choreographer/Sound Designer), Melissa Farenelli (Technical Director), Michael Rehse (Social Media) and Bronwyn Bishop (Press and Social Media).

Admittance is free of charge, with a $10 suggested donation. All cash proceeds at door will benefit Ali Forney Center .

 

WHERE

Mayday Space Classrooms, 2nd Floor

176 St Nicholas Ave, Brooklyn, NY 11237

 

CONTACT

Cupcake Lady Productions

cupcakeladyproductions@gmail.com

 

Cupcake Lady Productions was founded in 2012 and is committed to promoting women in the arts and creating thought provoking and innovative theater for the community. Past productions include “Sunday on the Rocks”,  “The House of Yes” and “Tech Support: J-Train and Circe” - 1-Acts nominated for 11 awards at the Planet Connections Theatre Festivity, winner of 4  (Outstanding Overall One-Act for J Train, Outstanding Sound Design for Tech Support, Outstanding Actress in a One-Act, and Outstanding Actor in a One-Act). Other original works include “Imaginary Friends”, which was a multi media theatrical event featuring four 1-acts mixed with comedy and film shorts. “Imaginary Friends” was nominated for 8 awards, winning 2 at PCTF (Best Costume Design and the Planet Activist Award). Cupcake Lady Productions hosts the  “Night of Rotten Theatre” event, an annual “bad” playwriting contest which draws playwrights from around the world to submit their worst plays and performs the top finalists to compete for audience vote.

 

Cupcake Lady Productions also is a proud producer of “Cupcake Lady Wrestling”, a comedy wrestling troupe which has performed at comedy clubs and at Summer Streets in New York. Please vist the Cupcake Lady YouTube page at www.youtube.com/user/CupcakeLadyProd for more comedy videos. For more information visit the facebook page (https://www.facebook.com/CupcakeLadyProductions/), our website (http://cupcakeladyproductions.com/) or follow us on twitter at @CupcakeLadyProd. Cupcake Lady Productions is a 501c3 Fractured Atlas sponsored nonprofit.

 

HOW ELSE YOU CAN HELP

Spread the word! See our show

Cupcake Lady Productions production of Hazelwood Jr. High is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Cupcake Lady Productions must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
The Play :

 

"Nothing to be done"

Two tramps, Vladimir and Estragon, are waiting in the evening for a man named Godot.  Suddenly, Pozzo and Lucky arrive! 

One of the most famous plays ever written in the history of theater! Over years the absurd "Waiting for Godot" written by Samuel Beckett has followed me with his poetry, atmosphere and humanity. 

An experience between comedy and tragedy where the everyday futilities help us to wait for changes to come. 


Welcome : 


Hi everyone, 

Welcome to our Project!  My name is Mathilde Schennen.  I am a belgian actress who has been living in New York for one year.  I came to the City to study at the Lee Strasberg Film and Theater Institute where I met wonderful actors and my future cast for our production of the play "Waiting for Godot", written by Samuel Beckett .  First, I started out working on the play as an directing exercise but then I realized quickly that I couldn't stop dreaming about it. Therefore I decided  to produce the entire play.  Since the end of summer I have been directing my wonderful cast in the masterpiece “Waiting for Godot” which will perform in November 2011 at the Kraine Theater.


Who we are : 

We are an international team, coming from Switzerland, France, Belgium, United States and Austria!

Cast:

Vladimir: Constantin Tripes

Estragon: Rafael Svarin

Pozzo: Ash Maxime Goldeh

Lucky: Miro Caltagirone

Boy: Tomás Lallemand

Artistic staff and crew:

Director: Mathilde Schennen

Assistant director : Sabrina Worsch

Costume / Set design : Darla Krupnik


How the funds raised will be used : 

All funds raised will be used for the costs associated with the production of the play. Even if we do a lot by ourselves, we need your support to cover some costs that cannot be ignored. These include renting the theater ($1500+), the right of the play ($225), the insurance ($195), some specific pieces of costumes and props ($100+), a part of the promotion ($100+) and the technical supports ($50+).  Depending on our funds, we'll gain higher in quality and more freedom. Therefore we would like to thank you already for your help and support. For each contribution, you'll get a perk! We hope you'll enjoy the show!


Please send this link to anyone who would love to support artists! Talk about our campaign! We want to share our art work with all of you. Last but not least come and join us on the 21st, 22nd and 23rd of November at the Kraine Theater! We believe in a theater open to everyone and free for all!

story:
Linda Parris-Bailey wrote a story in 1973 about her cousin's death. Her cousin’s death was suspicious and mysterious to her. She was young. Her cousin had just come home from Vietnam and her family was relieved because he was actually home from the war. Her cousin was not like most people returning home from the war.  He was very quiet, almost Zen like. He wasn't like the other tortured soldiers, liker her other cousins. It wasn't really like him. He was crazy and came back calm.

So when he wrapped himself around atree, it was a shock.

So fast forward to Iraq and Afghanistan,to a time where deaths by suicide out number deaths in combat. It's a time where PTSD is common language and common terminology.

It wasn't like Vietnam. During the war in Vietnam, we saw the war. We saw the bodies coming home, loaded in aircrafts. During this war, we didn't see. We weren't allowed to see. No one was being drafted. Everybody was volunteering, serving 2 or 3 tours of duty.

Linda wrote this play as a tribute to her cousin. But she also wrote this play about women and women's experience with war.

 It's written, directed anddesigned by women.

We need your support to finish this play. We want this play to encourage communities to start having discussions about what happens when soldiers return from war.

So we are trying to raise $5,000. We need more. But $5,000 would help us produce the play with all of its visual and scenic elements.

Support this production. Support this anti-war statement.

"They only way to stop PTSD, is to stop the war."- Vet Center Employee

"Speed Killed My Cousin" is the story of a wounded, African-American, female soldier contemplating suicide while driving on the Long Island Expressway. Passengers in the car are her father, a veteran of the Vietnam War, and her deceased uncle. All of them suffer from Post Traumatic Stress Disorder. All of them have kept silent about the war. One of them has committed vehicular suicide while the others must whether they will break the silence or follow the same path.The central character comes from a long line of Black soldiers. However, she is the first women to see combat. The complexities of her experiences are explored thru digital media, music and text. The CBT ensemble that will complete thework consists of four core CBT ensemble actors, the playwright Linda Parris-Bailey, the director/ dramaturge Andrea Assaf, visual artist Melody Reeve. Umoja Abdul Ahad serves as a Vietnam consultant. Lighting designis by Darron McCroom.

"They only way to stop PTSD, is to stop the war."- Vet Center Employee
"Speed Killed My Cousin" is the story of a wounded, African-American, female soldier contemplating suicide while driving on the Long Island Expressway. Passengers in the car are her father, a veteran of the Vietnam War, and her deceased uncle. All of them suffer from Post Traumatic Stress Disorder. All of them have kept silent about the war. One of them has committed vehicular suicide while the others must whether they will break the silence or follow the same path.The central character comes from a long line of Black soldiers. However, she is the first women to see combat. The complexities of her experiences are explored thru digital media, music and text. The CBT ensemble that will complete thework consists of four core CBT ensemble actors, the playwright Linda Parris-Bailey, the director/ dramaturge Andrea Assaf, visual artist Melody Reeve. Umoja Abdul Ahad serves as a Vietnam consultant. Lighting designis by Darron McCroom.

story:
We need $10,000 to cover the cost of a FULLY REALIZED stage reading of:

                  "54" the musical

to be presented to the public for the first time in fall 2012. Once we are fully funded, we will be able to pay for: venue rental, rehearsal space, musical arrangements and orchestrations, fifteen actors, five musicians, one production manager, one production stage manager, one lighting package, one sound package, backline and staff. We will be inviting industry guests and fellow producers to this reading so they can evaluate us for a bigger commitment and take this show to the next level...

And here's why YOU should help fund this funkiest of projects:

If you think you've already got disco music figured out, then you probably haven't heard it the way we do...

"Disco music...is funk with a bow tie." - Fred Wesley (trombonist and arranger for James Brown)   

“54" the musical is a chance to revisit a brief, but revolutionary period of popular music and culture - the disco era – as we follow two couples exploring and celebrating history being made. The story begins in a predominantly black-attended funk club and ends a few months later in the high profile disco, Studio 54. Through the piece we follow the main characters navigating interracial relationships, drug use, sexual liberty, changing musical paradigms and love - at all costs. The music, while familiar to fans of the funk and disco era, has been repurposed to serve as both backdrop and storyteller. The piece will be presented as a living installation where the audience can viscerally connect with the excitement of the era and identify with the stories of the songwriters as they are re-imagined through the characters these songs have helped create.

“54" the musical was conceived during the summer of 2009 thanks to an excellent iTunes playlist and a decent car stereo and actually written whilst alternate-side-of-the-street parking in Manhattan the fall of 2009. It was registered with the WGA in March 2010, received a copyright in June 2010, was informally read around a dining table sometime thereafter, then read again in December 2010 at the historic Gramercy Theatre (now concert venue) in NYC and most recently enjoyed a more formal (private) reading for the new creative team in February 2012.

_______________________________________________________

SYNOPSIS: "54" the musical

It’s April 26, 1977 and the party has just begun inside the hottest new disco in town, Studio 54. Booze, cocaine and sex are all for the taking as COCO de GRAND PRIX, the club’s temptatrix, sits on a giant crescent moon suspended from the ceiling giving her signature performance of the evening.

Meanwhile in a small recording studio funk front man, CLIFF KNIGHT, and his band the BOOGIE KNIGHTS are laying down tracks during a session rehearsal. Watching them from the control room is ROBYN CONNORS, the white friend of CLIFF’s bandmate who has her own dreams of becoming a singer. Sparks ignite when they are left to themselves and CLIFF offers to take ROBYN home. But the vibe is about to turn bad when CLIFF is asked to compromise his reputation as a funk purist in exchange for a chance at playing the hottest disco in town. When he loses one of his best guitarists to the Reserves and an old flame challenges his character, he finds that not only his chance at success may be on the line but also his chance at love.

Can CLIFF save his reputation and his new relationship or will he lose the gig and the girl forever to disco music, drugs and the irresistible allure of Studio 54? The answer lies in the music of some of the most celebrated artists of the funk and disco era – CHIC, LAKESIDE, AVERAGE WHITE BAND, EARTH WIND & FIRE, MARVIN GAYE, KC & THE SUNSHINE BAND, DONNA SUMMMER and many more.

_______________________________________________________

ABOUT THEATRE C

Theatre C was founded in November 2009 to move audiences and open minds by creating vibrant theatre through the unexpected fusion of disparate art forms. Led by Artistic Director, Carlos Armesto, Theatre C presents plays, musicals and events that meld puppetry and burlesque, video and dance, acrobatics and installations, hip hop rock and salsa, and more. Blurring the line between disciplines and cultures, the company is a part of the next stage in theatre's evolution. www.theatreC.org

Theatre C is also proud to create L!VE Asbury Park as part of its ongoing mission. www.liveasburypark.org

story:
Hello World!

In July 2014 Contacting the World Festival will bring together 100 young theatre makers from across the world - India, Iran, Jamaica and the UK - for a week-long celebration of theatre in Manchester.

By supporting our campaign you can be part of the festival, enjoy perks that give you access to workshops and performances, and get the opportunity to be inspired by and celebrate cultures from around the world.

Your support will also be giving over 100 young people a unique and life-changing experience - one that they will never forget! And what could be better than that?

What We Need & What You Get

We have a fundraising target of £30,000, and so far we've raised £23,712. To meet our £6,300 shortfall, Contact's amazing volunteers and staff are doing a sponsored Triathlon event with a goal of reaching £3000. Combined with this £3000 Indiegogo campaign, we'll hit our target and make an amazing Festival happen!

We have fantastic perks on offer, from loyalty cards and limited edition T-shirts to free tickets and a VIP-booth experience. 

There are three fantastic double-bill shows on offer, over three nights. Please note perks including tickets for one of the three main shows are subject to availability, but we will endeavor to match all supporters to their preferred show.

If we don't reach our target, a pared down version of the festival will go ahead - but we can't make it a 'festival to beat all festivals' without your support. 

The Impact

Contacting the World gives Manchester audiences access to inspirational theatre from around the world. The travelling companies are rarely seen outside of their countries. None of those involved would have the chance to meet, exchange ideas and be inspired to new heights of creative brilliance without the festival.

The international companies involved as 'twins' are:

  • Bread 'n' Butter Entertainment, Mumbai, India  and Corby Young Actors, Corby, England
  • Margintheater, Tehran, Iran and Contact Young Actors Company, Manchester, England
  • Quilt Performing Arts Company, Kingston, Jamaica and Firefly Arts - FRESH, Livingston, Scotland. 

Contacting the World gives young people from around the world a once in a lifetime opportunity to travel to Manchester and live and work with Mancunians.  Through the programme they improve their skills in theatre-making, facilitation, writing, directing and communication; and we learn about them and their culture.

Previous Festival participants have this to say about the Festival:

“Contacting the World is exactly the sort of festival the world needs. A lot of the problems we experience in this world are the result of us not knowing or being able to relate to one another. CTW brings people together, helps participants to learn about each other’s cultures and uses the medium of creative expression through theatre to help spread the message of understanding and unity.” Emma, participant, 2012

“The opportunity to meet and work with talented artists from all over the world is incredible, between expanding our minds and improving our skills as people and performers, Contact provides a totally unique experience.”
Ruaridh, participant, 2014

Festival participants in 2012

Hosting the Festival in Manchester brings the Northwest to the forefront of creative arts globally. Contacting the World is an amazing opportunity for audiences and artists from around the world.

Be part of this rich cultural experience – an inspiration for now and future generations!

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can’t contribute, you can still help:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign!
  • You can use the Indiegogo share tools, email your friends a link to this page, and tweet about it to your hearts content!

Much love!

The Contacting The World team 2014 x

Contact, an award-winning theatre and arts venue on Oxford Road, Manchester - host for the Festival .

story:
The Bats are headed North to descend upon SPACE on Ryder Farm.
Steve Stout, Katherine Folk-Sullivan, Layla Khoshnoudi, Brad Anderson, and Teddi Milan are all a part of the Bats, the Flea Theater's resident acting company, and will be joined by director Danya Taymor and playwright Rob Askins, to develop his newest piece  "Permission". We have the unique privilege of developing this play together  at SPACE on Ryder Farm, an artist retreat 60 miles north of New York city that provides workshop space that spans 126 acres. Hiking trails, ponds, woodlands, a clear starlit skies  provide the perfect place to reinvigorate after an eight hour day of rehearsal.  This community of people will live together, rehearse together, cook, eat, brush their teeth together, building a special bond that turns a cast into a family. By the end of our week at SPACE we will have developed a new piece of theater that will be presented  in New York City in the fall.

What we Need. What you Get.
Our goal is $2500.  This covers everything for our workshop.  Travel, Food, Lodging and rehearsal needs.

SPACE subsidizes the cost of our stay but it is our job to come up with the balance. The balance for each participant is $350.

The travel is 26.50 round trip per person from beautiful Grand Central Station to the front door of SPACE on Ryder Farm.
 

After indiegogo's take of 4% and fees ($175), we will be left with $39.50. That money will go towards any specific props we need during the rehearsal period.

Perks-
$25- A ticket to see the presentation of the piece in the fall. And a beer to accompany it.
        If you can't make the presentation you can give your ticket and beer away. 


$50- Two tickets to the presentation in the fall. Two beers.

        A signed copy of the script. Playwright, director, and cast. (we will mail it to you if you can't make the performance)

$100- 4 tickets to the presentation.

         A signed copy of the script.

         A producer credit inside of the draft and on the program.



Rob Askins and Danya Taymor are two rising stars in the New York theather community. This is your chance to help these burgeoning artists.  Danya and Rob have experienced sold out extended runs of their shows at The Flea Theater and Ensemble Studio Theater, respectively.  These two are going to be names known throughout the American theater in a very short time.


And then there's the Bats: Layla, Katherine, Teddi, Steve, and Brad.  If you ask around New York City you'll find out that the Bats are known to have a young, vital, love for the theater.  We are constantly working on new works and have been a thriving part of the downtown theater scene for 17 years.

Thank you for visiting our campaign and contributing. We feel very honored to have this opportunity up at SPACE.

Check out SPACE on Ryder Farm here: http://www.spaceonryderfarm.com/


Other Ways you can help.
If you can't contribute monetarily, no worries.  Help us spread the word by sharing this campaign on Facebook or email a friend directly letting them know about it.  

We will also be throwing a fundraiser BBQ in Brad Anderson's backyard on 7/28.  Bring yourself and a friend and help us kick off our week.

story:
Dry with a Twist Theatrics, in collaboration with Kimille Howard, is launching its inaugural production!

Dry with a Twist is a budding new production company and is anxious to begin producing projects that will give opportunities for emerging artists to create exciting new works and breathe life into old favorites. Our motto is "freshly familiar". We feel that this production will really help begin Dry with a Twist's journey to the forfront of independant theatre. And we can only do it with your help!

Wilde Tales is a collective evening of theatre which presents three fairy tales by Oscar Wilde in repertory.

First published in 1888 and described by Oscar as "not for children, but for childlike people from eighteen to eighty", Wilde’s charming, deeply personal stories of statues and swallows, nightingales and lovers, mermaids and witches come to life in three unique adaptations by Kevin P. Joyce. Each story explores themes of love, loss, self sacrifice and humanity. Join us as we explore these tales of wit, whimsy, wisdom and woe by Oscar Wilde. This exciting new work will receive its World Premiere this August in the Dream Up Festival at Theater for the New City.

While all of this is extremely exciting, and will give all of the artists associated incredible experience and exposure to the world of independent New York Theater, we need your help. As you can well imagine, the cost of independently producing new work in New York City is extremely high, and we are asking you to dig deep into your heart and pockets to contribute to the fundraising efforts of Dry with a Twist. The budget necessary to successfully and fully realize the work is, comparatively, small and with your generous help we will reach our goal in no time and be on our way to creating exciting new works from old friends.

 We've a reasonably small amount to raise for Dry with aTwist to produce this work and have some really fun and exciting perks available!

 If you're unable to make a monetary donation at the moment, we completely understand. We also have a list of physical items we need to mount the production, perhaps you have some the items lying about your house and don't need them, send them our way! Another way you can help is by passing along the news and sharing the link to our campaign.

 

Thank you, thank you, thank you!

Kevin P. Joyce

Producing Artistic Director

Dry with a Twist Theatrics

 


Physical Items

Key rings (at least 3)
Fabric (elastic, netting, lace, the more texture the better)
1/2" dowels
Velcro
Wrist brace
Paints (earthtones, jewel tones)
Fishing line
Buttons, beads, costume jewelry, buckles
Gaff tape
Wood glue
Rice paper
Brown craft paper
A Wooden ladder
Milk crates
Envelopes
Stamps
Printer paper
Old clothes
For more information on materials needed or ways in which you can help, email wildetales@gmail.com or kevin.p.joyce@hotmail.com.

story:
Sandglass is theater company in Putney, Vermont dedicated to the arts of theater and puppetry as means of exploring contemporary issues, inspiring dialogue and sparking wonder. Our newest project Rock the Boat is a touring puppet show for young audiences that explores themes of refugees, inclusion and respectful curiosity.

A Poet in a boat, alone at sea, observing his routines suddenly finds his home filling with new characters seeking shelter and safety. Each, we learn, has fled some disaster: war, fire or flood. As all the newcomers and the Poet navigate life together on the vessel, they meet conflict, generosity, kindness and questions about who each other are. The Poet’s poems become richer and deeper, and the unlikely collection of beings learn to steer threatening waters together.

Rock the Boat is being developed by a multi-ethnic ensemble creative team including slam-poet D. Colin, composer Julian Gerstin and students from two elementary schools in Southern Vermont. Work with students will be integrated with their class curriculum through writing, story telling and music workshops with the creative team. The student’s voices will contribute to the script, development of a study guide and touring residency model.

Rock the Boat aims to get young audiences thinking about relocation and displacement by addressing attitudes about acceptance of those who come from other countries and cultures. The production provides a narrative in which there is room for everyone in an inclusive society.

Sandglass Theater is a renowned theater company specializing in combining puppets with music, actors and visual imagery. Since 1982, the company’s productions have toured internationally, performing in theaters, festivals and cultural institutions and winning numerous international prizes. Sandglass is a 501(c)3 not-for-profit theater company; contributions to Sandglass Center for Puppetry and Theater Research are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
Our upcoming project, TYSON vs. ALI, has already seen a great outpouring of enthusiasm from the NYC theatre community. People are both electrified and perplexed by the idea—in fact, two articles in The New York Times featured us before tickets went on sale!

Fearlessly led by director Reid Farrington, the staff of 22—including performers, designers, and technical artists—is dedicated to telling a story about the most contested “What Ifs” in boxing history. What if Mike Tyson and Muhammad Ali were to meet in their prime? Who would win? We are all wrestling with this material, these larger than life characters and this controversial sport and we aim to bring audiences an exciting, thoughtful provocative show that looks at who these men are, why they fight and what their similarities and differences are both in and out of the ring. The video (above) is made up of rehearsal footage that was shot during our residency at Abrons Arts Center in August 2013 and features text by James Baldwin to give you a glimpse at what we're working on.  

>> This campaign will raise the final $15k of our budget before the final performance.  

One of the questions we're frequently asked is, how do you make something like this?  To be sure, the process is ever-evolving and continues to build on technologies and methods that Reid Farrington has developed during his last 3 projects. 

To give you an idea:

February 2012: Reid rented 'Tyson' at the New York Public Library
May: Reid began to talk to Frank, the playwright
September: Started talking to 3LD and PS122 about what the project could be and how they could support it.
December: Awarded $18K from NYSCA to begin building TYSON vs. ALI
March 2013: Held auditions and cast 4 boxers to be part of the project: Roger, Jon, Dennis, and Femi.
April—June: Reid read a lot of books, watched a lot of footage of fights and press conferences. He met with Frank and Laura N. to discuss the narrative and visual themes, as well as operating principles of the show.
June—July: The guys trained at Gleason’s Gym in Brooklyn and Reid asked them to play around with clips from Tyson and Ali’s press conferences and other appearances. Our video editor made a collage of all the knock-outs that Tyson and Ali every had, so that they played at the exact minute and second of the round that they happened in. This is called our “mash-up.”
August: We built our set (a full sized boxing ring!) at Abrons Arts Center and had rehearsals 5 days a week. Laura N. worked on the exact combinations that Tyson or Ali and their opponents did in each knock-out with the performers. We placed the KO’s in the ring where they actually occurred and at the exact moment that they occurred. This is the foundation of our fight choreography. The guys move from one KO to the next, and fill the “gaps” with sparring or other action. We also started working with Frank’s script that he wrote based off of the existing video clips and text that we wanted to use. Juan started making a sound track to lay over the whole show, Laura M. started building out her lighting design, and Simon continued to work on editing video so that eventually we would be able to project the fight footage onto the life-sized screens that Dave, who plays the Ref, has to move to capture the images. We shared the progress we made over our 4 week residency with audiences in an open rehearsal and learned a lot about what needed to be done between then and January 3.
September: We had a few weeks of rehearsals at 3LD to revisit the material from August and discuss big adjustments that we wanted to make before returning to a period of intense rehearsals in December.
Now: We have just loaded in all our things to and are ready for our last 6 weeks of intense rehearsals to finish the show and merge all of the elements together. The guys climb into the ring on November 30 and don’t really get a break until our final performance.

We are fortunate to have the steadfast support of two NYC based organizations, 3LD Art & Technology Center and Performance Space 122.  Participation in PS122’s COIL Festival positions TYSON vs. ALI to be seen by producers and presenters and picked up for national and international tours. AND — If a 10-round match, complete with real boxing, projections of Tyson and Ali, and an elaborate script didn’t sound like enough — 3LD has charged us to simultaneously develop a 3D film of the project! This film will be a "stand-alone" artwork with it’s own unique story separate from the live performance. Think Pina (Wim Wenders' film about the choreographer Pina Bausch) meets Hearts of Darkness (the making of Apocalypse Now). The film will be submitted to Sundance, and other film festivals, and will serve as permanent documentation of the making of this large scale multi-media performance that's based on two cultural icons. Needless to say, the pressure's on!

There’s no doubt that we’re attempting to move some mountains with this exciting endeavor and in order to do this we need a strong network of fans. The total budget for TYSON vs. ALI is upwards of $350,000 and we've got just $15,000 left to raise. This portion goes towards the salaries of the performers, designers, and technical artists. Increasingly we see stories in the news and on Facebook about the cost (and impossibility) of being an artist in New York City and we're hoping you share our belief that everyone should be paid for their commitment, talent, and hours of labor. 

And, if you think about the real value of what we're offering, and the fact that tickets are only $20, we hope you'll consider making a donation of at least $60.

Here's how you can be a part of this: 

  1. Donate — any amount helps. We'll be offering great perks over the course of the campaign, and know you'll feel good supporting the creation of new work. 
  2. Buy a ticket — performances begin January 3, 2014 and we recommend you come back more than once! 
  3. Spread the word — Forward this link, find us on Twitter, Instagram, and Facebook (#watchoutfortheknockout #tysonvsali) or do it the old fashion way.

THANK YOU!

We look forward to posting updates from rehearsals, behind the scenes of the performance, and audience reactions. 


TYSON vs. ALI is produced by 3-Legged Dog Productions and commissioned by PS122 with support from a 50th Anniversary Grant from the Jerome Foundation, New York State Council on the Arts with the support of Governor Andrew Cuomo and the New York State Legislature. Production design support is provided by the Edith Lutyens and Norman Bel Geddes Design Enhancement Fund, a program of the Alliance of Resident Theatres/New York (A.R.T./New York).

story:
Parking ramps are spaces that are home to nothing, not even cars. Their functionality comes from their impermanence in our lives, and they end up seeing more movement of things, cars, and people than we can imagine. What does it mean to choreograph the movement of people in such a space? What does it mean for our bodies to find stability against the slope of the ramp, and what does it say about art when artists and designers come together to create sound, light, objects, warmth, and movement against the concrete of the ramp? For the past four months, more than 35 performers have been committed to searching for poise and stability amidst the socio-political mess that movement brings in its wake. Your contribution to this project will support an artistic process in which individuals come together to ask critical questions and to build community with one another without flattening our differences and ways of knowing. Join us as we commit to something immense in scale, in numbers, in size, and in scope.

Your contribution supports our vision

We are grateful to our communities for supporting our vision and making possible critical artistic interventions in the last few years. With your backing, we have produced 3600 Cuts (2017), Census (2016), and In Habit: Living Patterns (2012), and presented at the annual all-night Northern Spark Festival. In recent years, we have been (1) nominated for an ‘Outstanding Performance’ Sage award for Every Other (2015) – a large-scale, site-specific installation performance at the Grain Belt Studios, (2) commissioned by the Weisman Art Museum to create an installation and performance as part of the exhibition Clouds: Temporarily Visible (2016), and (3) commissioned by the Walker Art Center to create and present F6 (2013) as part of Momentum: New Dance Works.

Since 2004, Aniccha Arts has been producing site-specific performances that examine agency, voice, and group dynamics within community histories, institutions, and systems.

If we are not successful in raising the pledged amount, we would cut back on our material expenses. However, artist fees are our priority, and we would make every last effort to pay our performers for their time and labor.

Other ways that you can help   

You can help in non-monetary ways, too!

We need volunteers on the days of the show (Sept 29 and 30), helping with ushering, inviting, and welcoming people at the ramp and striking the show. Helping with directing traffic towards the performance is a great way to earn art volunteer experience and benefit the Parking Ramp Project!   

You could help get the word out and share information about this campaign and use the Indiegogo tools!

story:
Project: Get Lindsay to Brussels

Dear Friends and Family,

I was just accepted to an artist residency in Brussels, BE. The focus of the residency is exactly in line with the work I have been doing both as a solo artist, with Dramatis Personae, and with my teaching and community based work. This is an AMAZING opportunity for me to expand my artistic practice and I'm pretty sure I haven't been this excited about something...well....EVER! I really hope you can help, so I can make this dream a reality. You will forever have my gratitude and appreciation (although you probably already do!). Below are all the details about the residency, the training I will receive and the costs involved.

All my love,

Lindsay

Weave—­­Artist Residency in Brussels, BE

7 days

60 artists

1 abandoned building

the focus: community and improvisation

Weave is born from a shared urge to develop platforms for artistic exchange, research and performance on a large scale. The main aim is to provide time and space for artists to work together under clear artistic direction and within the frame of extended exploration and big-scale thinking. 

September 29- October 7, 2013

weaveness.org

Their Consideration: Now is the iEra which sees the Self in the centre of every concern. Hedonism, individual liberty, self-employment, focus on the private sphere, personal achievement, ego trips – western society is no longer a community led by shared principles and values but an aggregate of solitary individuals running for their own profit, good or thriving.

We believe that this stunning growth of the Self was necessary, but also that it brought about a decrease in sensitivity and sensation, resulting in a loss of presence.

Community and Improvisation are interlaced as they both constitute the grounds of our society:

• We live together within a defined society therefore we are part of a community, regardless of whether we want it or not.

• Life as an individual is nothing else but a constant session of improvisation alongside other improvisers, regardless of whether we are aware of this or not.

What I Need to Get There:

Costs for the Trip:

  • Approx $1000-1100 for the flight
  • $250 fee for full board, workshops, and Video/Photo documentation of the residency
  • $200 Incidental expenses

I am working hard to personally cover whatever costs I can't fund through this fundraiser.

Why Do I Need This?

Professional dance, theatre and performance artists from across the globe will come together for one week in a huge abandoned factory building in Brussels. We will meet and form a temporary community within which we will play, question, and perform together in order to explore the interaction of improvisation and community.

Through workshops, labs, jams and public sharings, I will be challenged to deepen and question my own practice and gain practical skills to continue to develop my work. Weave will also provide an opportunity for me to meet and work with fellow artists and extend my network.

story:
Who is Tree.Lock//Productions?

We are Meg Kirchhoff and Sterling Melcher.  Meg is a dancer in the Twin Cities, and Sterling is a theater artist in Philadelphia.  After graduating together from St. Olaf College 5 years ago, we decided to team up and begin a small production company called Tree.Lock//Productions, focusing on cross-country productions in dance and theater.  Our first production, SplitScreen, is a dual-city, simultaneous duet.  Working with Google Hangout and other publicly accessible technologies we’re using this production to investigate what it is to connect and remain human in a world that is quickly being inundated with new and far-reaching technological advances.  We want this show to help bring an empathetic approach to the way we perceive technological interactions on a daily basis, rather than having them take away our individuality or stifle connections within society.

Right now we are entering our final stages of production to get ready for the coming festival season.  In May we were lucky enough to spend two weeks in Fergus Falls, MN, participating in the Hinge Artist Residency through Springboard for the Arts.  Given the time and space in such a beautiful community, we laid the fundamental groundwork for SplitScreen.  Since the beginning of our process in April of 2018, we have been fully self-funding and are turning to you to help us achieve our new goals.

We are excited to present our work to the public, and through our work-in-progress showings we’ve seen audiences react emphatically about the work we’re creating.  Your contributions will allow us to bring a new level of professionalism to this production.

What does Tree.Lock want?

We are looking to raise $5000 for our production SplitScreen.  All funds raised will go towards production costs:  

  • Projectors
  • Subsidized ticket costs for each festival, focusing on radical hospitality
  • Rehearsal space in Philadelphia and Minneapolis
  • Performance space for both festivals (excluding the Minneapolis portion of the MN Fringe)
  • Working wages for two artistic consultants
  • Working wages for a musical collaborator
  • Working wages for Meg and Sterling

Everyone who donates will receive a personalized email from us containing photos and a small video clip from the production.  $25 or more gets a live shoutout during the festival $50 or more gets a shoutout, will be listed as a sponsor in our program. A $100 donation gets you everything listed above, as well as a personal Q+A session with the artists over Google Hangout

Regardless of whether or not we reach our desired goal, every amount of donation is greatly appreciated and will help us fully realize this production.

The long-term

We believe in the power of local, independently produced, experimental art and its inherent benefit to society.  Not only does it spread a sense of empathy and adventurousness, but it also allows us to view the everyday aspects of our lives in a different way.  This production, as a small contribution to that larger pool of experimental art, is trying to make sure that we do not lose ourselves in a digital age we cannot avoid.  We want to make sure that everyone who comes in contact with the work changes even a small perspective they have about the world for the better.

Both of us have been a part of various productions in our respective cities.  Meg has been both a choreographer and dancer in the Twin Cities, and is also a dance teacher for young dancers, allowing the experiments she creates outside of class to help effect the next generation of artists, and vice versa.  Sterling has produced and performed in various fringe shows over the past three years, and is committed to independent production of his and his fellow artists work in Philadelphia.

Why SplitScreen?

Experimental art is always a gamble, and its effects are often not seen for many years, if they are ever seen at all.  However, if this kind of work is not funded, and especially not funded by the public, then young artists won’t get the chance to discover their greatest work through failure or success, especially at pivotal points in their early career.  

We were lucky enough to be awarded a two week residency through Springboard for the Arts and their Hinge Arts Residency at the Kirkbride in Fergus Falls, MN.  This time allowed us an unmitigated rehearsal period where we were able to lay the groundwork for what will be premiered this summer. Also, we were awarded one of three Artist Grants from the Minnesota Fringe, covering the production costs usually associated with festival entrance. The combination of residencies and grants has shown us that other people believe in what we are doing, and want to see its fullest outcome. With the combined efforts of our own individual practice, and the time that we have already spent in research and development for this show we believe we can bring to life a production that, if anything, will be a new and entertaining experience for everyone in attendance.

Everyone has a friend we don't have

Even if you don’t have the ability to donate at this time, even the simple act of sharing this directly with people you know will help us expand our network, and reach our goal.  Even if 5000 people donate $1, we’ll make it there!

story:
The Cameo Theater

The Cameo Theatre opened in the 1930’s to serve the (Greater Binghamton) Robinson Street neighborhood. It has a bird cage style box office, inside the lobby. The concession stand and restrooms are located in the rear of the auditorium. The theatre was operated for many years by Ken and Fran Robinson, who were very popular in the community. The theater served over 800-1000 patrons at one time, until it's closing in 2002 and has been empty ever since. 

  • Local Walk-Up Theater
  • Second Run turn First Run Theater
  • Enjoyed by 1000's for decades! 

Every time I (Talia Moore) speak with someone about their memories of the Cameo Theater it's always positive and upbeat! Would Shakespeare allow this beloved theater die? No, Well neither will we! DT Productions has a unique opportunity to revive this theater into a "Live Theater" Playhouse that can be enjoyed by the patrons of the greater Binghamton Community. 

Who is DT Productions?

(Talia Moore working with community Theater group)

DT Productions is a "live theatre" and event production company that combines theater/film with learning, entertainment and outreach. We also train students/adults in the all areas of performing arts! We have worked with organizations such as: The Urban League, Boys & Girls Clubs, local church groups, local theaters and other performance venues in our community. We have five (5) Board Memebers including: Talia Moore-Director/Artistic Producer, Derrick Moore-Vic President /Acting Member, Qiana Watson-Treasure/Acting Outreach Coordinator, Clarissa Brown-Administration/Project Coordinator and Jay Fikes-Active Member. DT Production will strive to bring about a change for community with this project as well as provide a platform for theatre and community events for the new and revived Cameo Theater.

We Need To Revive The Abandon Theater

The Cameo Theater As It Stands Today:

Project Will Be Broken Up into 4 Phases:

Phase 1: Evaluation
Phase 2: Restoration Estimation
Phase 3: Building & Reconstruction
Phase 4: Maintenance

Where Your Donation Goes:

  1. $105,000-Purchase seating for the Cameo (700 @ $150.00)
  2. $17,000-Labor and Contracting Cost (Life of the project)
  3. $10,000-Repair/Replace Roof 
  4. $10,000-Wood/Nails and Other Re-Construction Material Cost
  5. $8,000-New Windows, Doors & Ceiling Repair 
  6. $7,800-Updated Energy Efficient Heating/Cooling System
  7. $6500-General Lighting & Electric
  8. $6300-Wall Repair/Installation and Sealant 
  9. $5500-Cameo Marque Repair
  10. $5300-Stage/Bathrooms/Office Reconstruction
  11. $5000-Theater fixture/accessories (Boxoffice/Concessions)
  12. $3200-Playhouse Operational Cost (Stage Lighting/Sound)
  13. $2000-Mold Control Treatment
  14. $1000-Pest Control Treatment
  15. $600-Building Assessment/Permits & Inspection Fees 
All this will help us to recreate the Cameo in to a LIVE THEATRE such as this.......

The Impact Of The Cameo Theater

To the Robinson Street community this space means "more" than a theater it represents "HOME." Fran and Kenneth Robinson gave their lives to make sure that their community had an enjoyable theater experience they could rely on. By DT Productions bring life back to this community theater venue, the legacy of Ken and Fran Robinson will live on and the community will have a reason to recapture and support the love and loyalty they have for this community theater. 

  • So many theaters are abandoned every year and more and more are forgotten. We refuse to allow this theater to become a statistic! 
  • DT Productions has put on various events throughout the Greater Broome County area  since 2006 and know we can bring quality events the community and families can share and take part in! 
  • We live here and we want to be entertained here! We care about our community and WILL NOT give up on this theater! The legacy of Fran and Kenneth Robinson will not DIE! 

Other Ways You Can Help The Cameo 

Here are some ways that you can spread the word about the Cameo.

  • Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Linkined, Pintrest, and Indiegog Share Tool!
  • Donate Unwanted Cell Phones! 

               WE DON'T NEED ANOTHER ABANDONED BUILDING ON OUR BLOCK!

                                 RESTORE THE CAMEO!
story_txt:
The Cameo Theater
The Cameo Theatre opened in the 1930’s to serve the (Greater Binghamton) Robinson Street neighborhood. It has a bird cage style box office, inside the lobby. The concession stand and restrooms are located in the rear of the auditorium. The theatre was operated for many years by Ken and Fran Robinson, who were very popular in the community. The theater served over 800-1000 patrons at one time, until it's closing in 2002 and has been empty ever since. 












Local Walk-Up Theater
Second Run turn First Run Theater
Enjoyed by 1000's for decades! 

Every time I (Talia Moore) speak with someone about their memories of the Cameo Theater it's always positive and upbeat! Would Shakespeare allow this beloved theater die? No, Well neither will we! story:
The Living Room Series embodies The Blank’s commitment to developing new artists and new work. Every Monday night from Labor Day to Memorial Day, we produce a “workshop” staged reading of a new play with a week of rehearsals. The author is partnered with experienced actors and directors who interpret the play and help the writer hone their story. New plays and playwrights are given a safe and nurturing environment where they can explore their emerging vision and present it to an eager audience who support new plays.

It began as an artistic gymnasium; a place where actors, directors, stage managers, playwrights and audience members could stretch their collective wings and explore new aspects of themselves. While established artists always took part, so did emerging artists; giving both the opportunity to explore who they are as creative beings and who they could become.

Our commitment to a rich diverse body of artists is systemic and has helped further their abilities over the years: young and old, male and female, from diverse ethnic backgrounds. We challenge them to explore aspects of themselves and their work that the “commercial world” doesn’t. They are of the highest professional quality. Many are Tony Award winners, Academy Award winners and Broadway professionals; some had their awards and experience before they worked with us, and some received those accolades after developing their craft at The Blank. Tessa Thompson, Molly Shannon, Noah Wyle, Jennifer Aniston, Jeremy Sisto, Matthew Lillard all performed in the Living Room Series before their careers took off (and even afterwards)!

We have developed plays by well-established playwrights like Tony Award winners Steven Sater (SPRING AWAKENING), George Furth (COMPANY), Tony Award nominees Nell Benjamin, Jonathan Tolins, and Michael John LaChiusa, as well as hundreds of emerging playwrights.

These plays have consistently gone onto venues throughout the world such as Manhattan Class Company, Victory Gardens, Vineyard Theatre, Laguna Playhouse & Transport Group. Nell Benjamin’s play THE EXPLORER’S CLUB won the NY Outer Critics Circle Award for “Outstanding New Off-Broadway Play” when produced by Manhattan Theatre Club after two developmental workshops in our Living Room Series. A SINGULAR THEY by Aliza Goldstein (the first play in the US with an Intersex main character) won the LA Drama Critics Circle Award for “Outstanding World Premiere Play.”

LRS productions depend largely on the passion and hard work of dedicated dramaturgs, producers and readers, as well as the volunteered talents of professional directors and actors. Even with the donation of so much valuable time and talent, there are still significant expenses involved in being able to accept nearly 500 submissions a year, then select and develop almost 30 scripts.

 

OUR PROCESS

The Living Room Series is the “next stage” of development. They are not “readings” with one 2-hour rehearsal. These are “workshops” which allow a rehearsal process and an opportunity for the playwright, director and actors to explore the material while putting it on its feet. They are simply staged, presented with “book in hand” (meaning actors carry scripts), and are a wonderful opportunity for audiences and the playwright to get a sense of the play's full presence and how it might be staged in a full production.

An Artistic Committee (AC) of volunteering writers, directors, and producers serve as the guiding force for the Living Room Series. They discuss plays and musicals submitted in an open submission process and make decisions about which plays will earn a spot in the LRS. One of the AC members becomes the Creative Producer on the project, shepherding the playwright through the process from first notes to final comments from audience members.

Each play gets a week of rehearsal, with the playwright making necessary changes as they go. A producer and a stage manager are assigned to each presentation. There is a tech rehearsal as the final step and the play is presented free to an audience on a Monday night at The Blank’s 2nd Stage Theatre in Hollywood.

 

OUR IMPACT

FOR THE PLAYWRIGHTS - It is a terrific opportunity to work on their play in collaboration with some of the best talent Los Angeles has to offer. Shaping a new play needs to be a communal experience and we offer support for that experience. Plays come alive in the third dimension, and we help the writer “see” their play; the experience is rare and valuable. And the writer gets to hear honest audience reaction, which is invaluable.

FOR THE BLANK - We get the opportunity to work with and support hundreds of artists each year, and create working relationships that have, with some, now stretched decades. We also get to present our audiences with exciting new plays before anyone else.

FOR THE CITY OF LOS ANGELES - We present nearly 30 evenings of free theatre to our neighbors in the local community. We also get to introduce our theatrical colleagues to new plays and playwrights. Many LRS plays have been produced in other theatres throughout Los Angeles as well as The Blank.

FOR THE INTERNATIONAL THEATRE SCENE - Playwrights know that The Blank’s Living Room Series is one of the best places to have their work developed and we receive submissions from writers all over the globe. The work we present in the Living Room Series goes on to impressive venues throughout the world, as do the artists we support.

The Blank Theatre’s Living Room Series has developed over 600 new plays and musicals in nearly three decades. We help create new plays, new playwrights, directors, actors, stage managers, producers, and thousands of delighted audience members, who are part of the birth of a new work of art.

The Future of Theatre is here. At The Blank. The time to give is now.

Please donate now! And please share our message!

 

Thank you!

story:
My name is Michele Antonioli.  I have been teaching ballet at the University of Montana in the School of Theatre & Dance for 25 years.  For the first time in those 25 years, we are going to stage the 2nd Act of Swan Lake.  This has been a dream of mine for many years.  I would like to share the experience of working on a significant portion of one of the most important ballets from the classical repertoire with my university dancers.  We have not been able to do this before because of a lack of funding for costumes.  One tutu can cost anywhere from $200-$500.  With a minimum of 12 swans needed for the corps de ballet, that is more money for costumes than we would normally have in our costume budget for 3 years of performances!  With the possibility of fundraising, we can purchase tutus and help make this dream a reality.

What We Need & What You Get

We need 12 classical tutus.  Each tutu will cost $225.  All contributions will go toward the purchase of tutus. The School of Theatre & Dance will be able to use these tutus for future productions.  In return, we have DVDs of our performance as well as pictures of either a particular swan you might know or the entire cast of Swan Lake for you.  You will receive a special thank you in our program and for special donations, we will provide 2 tickets to one of our performances.  

The Impact

Dancers who have achieved a certain level of technical training can benefit from learning the valuable skill of working as a cohesive ensemble in the corps de ballet.  Dancers who have arrived at this level of training also benefit from the experience of dancing in a real classical tutu.  When a dancer puts one of these iconic costumes on, their dancing changes in subtle, valuable ways.  Any of you who have worn a tutu know what I mean and any of you who might have children who have had this chance will also know the importance of this experience.  I am very hopeful that with your help my 12 dancers can have these experiences while they are dancing at the University of Montana. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Any contribution is appreciated.  If you can't afford to give money, we would also appreciate it if you'd share the campaign request with your friends who might be interested in this kind of project.

story:
What is it?

"The theatre, no doubt, is always in crisis.” Join in on an exorcism and funeral march for the theatre. What happens if we take all the reasons fancy dead Western men say theatre is bad and try to perform them to the fullest degree? Inspired by the book The Antitheatrical Prejudice which chronicles the deep-seated hatred of theatre throughout history, this piece examines, and does, why people have always thought theatre to be an abomination. Is it possible that we will find something realer than real through adopting theatricality as a mode of existence and compulsively rehearsing her vices: imitation, ostentation, imminence, effeminacy, and entertainment? After all, “all doers are actors” and “lying is the foundation of all humanity and civilization."


Rhinofest?

Scarlett Kim & Co.'s The Antitheatrical Prejudice is a part of the 26th Annual Rhinoceros Theater Festival hosted by Curious Theatre Branch. Here's a bit about the awesome Rhinofest:

Each year, Curious curates and produces the Rhinoceros Theater Festival, which provides production and exhibition opportunities to hundreds of artists, drawing thousands in attendance each year. The longest-running fringe festival in Chicago, the Rhino features works in theater and performance from Chicago companies and national artists alike. First organized in the Wicker Park neighborhood of Chicago, the Rhinofest is unique among national fringe festivals in that artists are never charged a fee to participate, and each year our programs are individually curated rather than selected on a lottery basis.


Reinforce THIS. (a.k.a. things we are interested in)

Acknowledging and interrogating the Canon/canonicity. Female celebrities that are not dead but whose careers are dead. Shakespeare quotes not just as “what they are” but as indexical objects. Process and product as one. Rehearsal room rituals. Our identities as twenty-something theatre makers. Staging not inherently performative texts. Historical analog between femininity and imminence. Structural principle of the pastiche. Creating/doing things in real time and space (except for when we’re doing fake things, we like that too, we just acknowledge it as such widly). Camp & Kitsch. The fact that the author keeps mysteriously saying the book was complete “under difficult circumstances.” Manhood and machinehood as not a dichotomy, but having a more intricate, tenuous relationship. Ineffability/irrelevance of Truth. Polemical theses. Using theoretical texts as instructional scores. Humor.


A sneak peek into our “scene” list...

  •  “Sodomy/Hysteria Dance”
  •  Britney and Christina may sing Blank Space together
  • You get to auction off a peep show from any member of the cast
  • The Mysterious, Mystifying game: Ouija
  • “Smear It All Over Until You Feel Sick”
  • Who knew how resourceful WikiHow could be?
  • Romeo and Juliet
  • The Most Boring Story


Your contribution will allow us to do these things:

- Construct our set, props, costumes, and lights and sound equipment. While we are working with a fairly minimal aesthetic in true fringe festival spirit, we’ve got some essential objects to furnish the physical world (furniture, mirrors, lightbulbs, drag things, etc.!)

- We’ve got lots of perishables and consumables for doing really real things in onstage. Also, our show changes night to night based on interactions between the performers and the audience, and the choices the audience make. Our pre-show routine includes preparing for all possibilities that may arise!

- While we have been fortunate to squat in various rooms at the Logan Center for the Arts for rehearsals, we need to rent a north side space a couple times for private viewings/open rehearsals before our opening, as we get limited access to our actual performance venue.

- Promote our show through printing flyers and postcards, as well as online channels.

- Cover other miscellaneous costs, such as transportation, shipping, administrative fees, Indiegogo processing fees, scripts printing fees, rehearsal props, etc.

- “The ensemble members are have various part-time and day jobs to support their creative careers, and in generously lending their time and attention to their project, some had to compromise some of their other money-making-things from time to time. I would be so grateful if we are able to take care of these amazing people by buying food on long rehearsal days, reimbursing transportation, etc.” - Scarlett


What’s the audience’s role?

A lot of our show is really about/by you, so we need your help to make it happen!

Structurally, the piece takes on the form of a pastiche: a patchwork of impressions, or, blank parody of elements that constitute the original narrative, forming this world through a visceral logic. The world employs elements of theatre – text, character, plot, audience, etc. – as ‘objects’ on a horizontal plane, creating an environment that can be experienced rather than a linear storyline that is neatly packaged to be preached. The audience is then invited to attend to the world exercising their own agency and construct for themselves their own version of how the puzzle pieces fit together: metaphorically, but also literally, as the audience will be invited to channels through which they can physically impact the world of the piece, and make sense of the whole thing in their own subjective way. The audience will be observed. The audience will perform. The audience will be imitated and fictionalized. Praised and chastised. They will be performers as much as performers are audience and performers. There is no ultimate or absolute moral that we wish for the audience to extract out of this choose-your-own-adventure experience. However, that is not to say that the piece is not interested in affect or pathos. In fact, we believe that the generous itinerary of inviting the audience to explore a smorgasbord of experiments has a heightened potential to elicit resonance and allow them to adventure on in their own ways afterwards. As the form and content intermingle and interchange in this world, the work at hand is not simply a surface-level, “meta-meta” discussion, but a fertile ground for catharsis. 


Who are we?

Scarlett came across our source text when she was directing Hamletmachine (with many of the same current company members!) looking for dramatically theoretical/ theoretically dramatic books on theory of drama. Since submitting the proposal to Curious Theatre Branch’s Rhinoceros Festival, Scarlett assembled a team of creatives with diverse intellectual and artistic passions. We are professionals and students working in various fields who have come together to lend our hard work to build this project from ground up. We have built a tightly-knit company with a solid working vocabulary, and our commitment to the collective process echoes in our work.

Scarlett Kim’s directing and producing the show. The performing ensemble is James Fleming, Natalie Houchins, Stephanie Litchfield, Michael Reinhard, and Derek Spencer. Derek’s also composing original music and designing sound with James. Marisa Chilberg’s designing costumes. Brett Pepowski’s designing lights. Sarah Kim and Éamon Boylan are respectively assistant and associate directors.


Want more info?

The Antitheatrical Prejudice is a part of The 26th Annual Rhinoceros Theater Festival hosted by the Curious Theater Branch. The show runs Jan 18 – Feb 22, every Sunday at 5pm at Prop Thtr (3502 N. Elston Ave.). Checkout the Festival’s website (rhinofest.com) for more information. Link to the ticketing page coming soon!


Thank you!

Please support young emerging artists who want lives in the theatre. We have come together to create something special that is full of humor, heart and grit. We have put so much of our own selves and resources into this process, and we would be forever grateful to you if you would consider helping what we have fully immersed ourselves into reality. Your contributions will enable us to execute this very unique project, and also empower us to devote ourselves to future creative endeavors.


antitheatrical@gmail.com
