A sneak peek into our “scene” list...

 “Sodomy/Hysteria Dance”
 Britney and Christina may sing Blank
Space together
You get to auction off a
peep show from any member of the cast
The Mysterious, Mystifying
game: Ouija
“Smear It All Over Until
You Feel Sick”
Who knew how resourceful WikiHow could be?
Romeo and Juliet
The Most Boring Story

Your contribution will allow us to do these things:
- Construct our set, props,
costumes, and lights and sound equipment. While we are working with a fairly
minimal aesthetic in true fringe festival spirit, we’ve got some essential
objects to furnish the physical world (furniture, mirrors, lightbulbs, drag
things, etc.!)
- We’ve got lots of
perishables and consumables for doing really real things in onstage. Also, our
show changes night to night based on interactions between the performers and
the audience, and the choices the audience make. Our pre-show routine includes
preparing for all possibilities that may arise!
- While we have been
fortunate to squat in various rooms at the Logan Center for the Arts for
rehearsals, we need to rent a north side space a couple times for private
viewings/open rehearsals before our opening, as we get limited access to our
actual performance venue.
- Promote our show through
printing flyers and postcards, as well as online channels.
- Cover other miscellaneous costs,
such as transportation, shipping, administrative fees, Indiegogo processing fees, scripts printing fees, rehearsal props, etc.
- “The ensemble members are
have various part-time and day jobs to support their creative careers, and in
generously lending their time and attention to their project, some had to
compromise some of their other money-making-things from time to time. I would
be so grateful if we are able to take care of these amazing people by buying food on long rehearsal days, reimbursing transportation, etc.” - Scarlett
What’s the audience’s role?A lot of our show is really about/by you, so we need your help to make it happen!
Structurally,
the piece takes on the form of a pastiche: a patchwork of impressions,
or, blank parody of elements that constitute the original narrative, forming
this world through a visceral logic. The world employs elements of theatre –
text, character, plot, audience, etc. – as ‘objects’ on a horizontal plane,
creating an environment that can be experienced rather than a linear storyline
that is neatly packaged to be preached. The audience is then invited to attend
to the world exercising their own agency and construct for themselves their own
version of how the puzzle pieces fit together: metaphorically, but also
literally, as the audience will be invited to channels through which they can
physically impact the world of the piece, and make sense of the whole thing in
their own subjective way. The audience will be observed. The audience will perform. The audience will be imitated and fictionalized. Praised and chastised. They will be performers as much as performers are audience and performers. There is no ultimate or absolute moral that we wish
for the audience to extract out of this choose-your-own-adventure experience.
However, that is not to say that the piece is not interested in affect or
pathos. In fact, we believe that the generous itinerary of inviting the
audience to explore a smorgasbord of experiments has a heightened potential to
elicit resonance and allow them to adventure on in their own ways afterwards.
As the form and content intermingle and interchange in this world, the work at
hand is not simply a surface-level, “meta-meta” discussion, but a fertile
ground for catharsis. 
Who are we?
Scarlett came across our
source text when she was directing Hamletmachine
(with many of the same current company members!) looking for dramatically
theoretical/ theoretically dramatic books on theory of drama. Since submitting
the proposal to Curious Theatre Branch’s Rhinoceros Festival, Scarlett
assembled a team of creatives with diverse intellectual and artistic passions.
We are professionals and students working in various fields who have come
together to lend our hard work to build this project from ground up. We have
built a tightly-knit company with a solid working vocabulary, and our
commitment to the collective process echoes in our work.
Scarlett Kim’s
directing and producing the show. The performing ensemble is James Fleming, Natalie Houchins, Stephanie
Litchfield, Michael Reinhard, and Derek Spencer. Derek’s also composing
original music and designing sound with James. Marisa Chilberg’s designing costumes. Brett Pepowski’s designing lights. Sarah Kim and Éamon Boylan
are respectively assistant and associate directors.

Want more info?
The Antitheatrical Prejudice
is a part of The 26th Annual Rhinoceros Theater Festival hosted by
the Curious Theater Branch. The show runs Jan 18 – Feb 22, every Sunday at 5pm
at Prop Thtr (3502 N. Elston Ave.). Checkout the Festival’s website (rhinofest.com) for more
information. Link to the ticketing page coming soon!
Thank you!
Please support young
emerging artists who want lives in the theatre. We have come together to create
something special that is full of humor, heart and grit. We have put so much of our
own selves and resources into this process, and we would be forever grateful to
you if you would consider helping what we have fully immersed ourselves into reality. Your
contributions will enable us to execute this very unique project, and also
empower us to devote ourselves to future creative endeavors.antitheatrical@gmail.com

story:
Our Story

Boy Gets Girl by Rebecca Gilman is an American contemporary thriller about what happens when a blind date turns into a living nightmare for young journalist, Theresa Bedell. This brave play breaks down the reality of stalking, sexism, and the ideas of romantic pursuit.

All performances will take place in the Underground Theatre of the PAC at SUNY Purchase in Westchester, NY.

Performance dates:

November 13 - 7:00 pm

November 14 - 8:00 pm

November 15 - 8:00 pm

What We're About

This show is being directed, produced, and managed by three outstanding students from Purchase College (State University of New York) in Purchase, NY. Director Maeve O'Neill, producer Amanda Pearl, and stage manager Jessica Rappaport embody every aspect of "girl power." Individually, they each bring a specialty focus to the development of the show. Together, they've created the ideal team with proficient skills in professionalism, organization, and productivity.


What We Need:

We need your support!!!!!

To run this production as smoothly and effectively as possible, we are aiming to raise $1,100.

This is where we need YOUR HELP.

Theatre is completely revolved around community engagement and support. That support comes from those who recognize the value of the arts and give (when they can).

Putting up a show is not an easy task (as we are quickly learning). If you've ever tried to make something out of nothing, you know exactly what we mean. But self-producing a show is not a hobby; it comes from a drive within a person deep within the artistic soul. 

Boy Gets Girl is a very personal and revealing piece of theatre that exposes the life of those who are affected by stalking, misogyny, and the victimization of the way society defines ideas of romantic pursuit. It's a very intimate and revealing show that spares no comfort to the audience or the actors.

A performance like this forces us as the production team to pay extra close attention to detail.

If you chose to support us, we have various perks that we think you will enjoy.

We have very specific allocations for where our money needs to go: 

Please join us in telling the story. 

Every day there are more stories about feminine victimization around the world. After Elliot Rodger's manifesto and "Day of Retribution" at UCSB, there has been an outbreak of support to women from women and men who won't stand for this kind of misogyny and horror. With movements like #yesallwomen steadily growing, there's no better time to put up a show like this and spread the message.

Please help us so that we can give this show everything it deserves in such trying times.

 ~ We thank you for your support ~
Director - Maeve O'Neill
Producer - Amanda Pearl
Stage Manager - Jessica Rappaport

If you would like to become part of the cause and read more about the UCSB tragedy that occurred this past May, click on the link below for a CNN report
. 
*Caution* It is a very difficult story to read.

Deadly Rampage in California College Town.

From the director:

Hi! My name is Maeve O'Neill and I am a junior Theatre and Performance major at Purchase College with a minor in Arts Management.  

Twelve years after making my first stage appearance, I am thrilled to announce my directing debut at Purchase College. Although this is my first solo piece, I am far from inexperienced. Throughout my years I've had hands on professional grade work in various mediums. I've always been very serious about any work that I do. Theater has always given me an exciting amount of freedom and a much-needed artistic outlet. 

I first read Boy Gets Girl last spring in my Acting Scene Study class where we performed Act 1, Scene 3 of the play with me as Theresa. This was the moment where I realized I needed to direct this.

Now just a few months later, we are under way with an amazing cast and a fantastic production team. As I keep saying, "Everything is coming together and that's more than I could have ever hoped for."

Now we need your help in making this dream turn into a reality for us.

story:
College students do lots of things with very little money. But, you’ve got to admit, not of lot of them would have the passion to pull this off:

                          An entirely student-mounted production of

                                       Shakespeare's As You Like It

                                                 at SUNY Purchase

Shakespeare in the Quad is happening! But here’s the catch- (and the thing that keeps our cast and crew up at night), -we have no budget.

With just a little financial support from you – your contribution in ANY amount (even $5 can go a long way) – can help us seriously blow everyone’s doors off.

What: A completely independent production of Shakespeare's “As You Like It”. As You Like It is the story of two cousins left to their own devices after being banished by an evil duke. It is a story of love, heartbreak, struggle, triumph, mistaken identity, familial loyalties, political and social structures and so much more.

When: May 6th,7th,and 8th 2016, just after the 400th anniversary of Shakespeare’s death

Where: A terraced outdoor space behind the Humanities building on the campus of SUNY Purchase, in Purchase, NY (Purchase's old amphitheater was recently torn down, so we scouted this previously unused performance venue and claimed it for “Shakespeare in the Quad”)

Why: SUNY Purchase students with a passion for Shakespeare find themselves with few school-provided opportunities to participate in one of the Bard’s plays. If we want to be involved in a show, it’s up to us.

Who: Approximately 25 SUNY Purchase students. (Already we’ve completed a series of well-attended auditions and callbacks and now have a talented 17-person cast and ambitious seven-person production crew)

So why should you pledge your hard-earned cash to this effort?

Perhaps you fall into one of these categories:

► Family and friends of someone in this show – We’re working so hard on this, guys, and we want to make you proud. It would mean the world to have your support.

► Shakespeare Lovers – Here’s your chance to encourage and support the next generation. Everyone in this production is participating voluntarily. Come fall in love all over again with this fresh new look at Shakespeare's classic tale.

► Shakespeare Haters – Clearly you’ve never seen a funny, heart-warming and efficacious Shakespeare production. Allow us the pleasure of converting you. We will tell it expertly with Shakespeare's wit, humor, and poetry and hopefully change your mind!

►Venture Capitalists – You know successful entrepreneurs when you see them, right? Just wait until you see our marketing plan! Heck, some SUNY Purchase professors have already pledged to make our production required viewing. This would be a wise and generous investment (Check out our list of perks!)

►Activists – Clearly you can appreciate that if you aren’t part of the solution (Shakespeare at SUNY Purchase!) then you are part of the problem. This revolution is happening! Join us! Already, within our cast/crew, we’ve united students majoring in Math, Literature, Arts Management, Visual Arts, Studio Composition, Playwriting and Screenwriting and beyond. And did we mention this show has innumerable themes relevant to the 21st century? Including an oppressive upper class and cultural repression, along with themes any college student can appreciate, like familial conflict, first loves, leaving a beloved home and returning to nature.

► Irish people and History Buffs – The themes of oppression in As You Like It echo the oppression of the Irish by the British-appointed nobility. We’re telling your story by setting this production in 1800s British-occupied Ireland. For your enjoyment, we intend to include some Irish dancing in this production. Our student directors (Virginia Edinger and Katherine Gilmartin) both have Irish heritage too!

► SUNY Purchase Alumni – As a student, you benefited from mentors and supporters. If this effort pulls at your heart, won’t you please “pay it forward?”

What we need

We’re thrifty and we’re working every angle we can. Here’s what $2,000 will buy us:

  • Costumes (we’re borrowing, renting, buying, sewing and paying for some dry cleaning)

  • Accessories (period hats, shoes, stockings, gloves plus sewing materials)

  • Props and set pieces

  • Graphic design and printing of promotional materials (including programs, posters, flyers)

  • Sound equipment (renting extension chords, speakers, etc. for our musicians)

Reaching the $2,500 mark will allow us to go above and beyond and make our production as historically accurate and professional as possible.

Thank you!

Our cast and crew thanks you, sincerely, for helping us achieve this dream.

Cast:

Rosalind- Liz Vacca

Celia- Maeve Pendergast

Touchstone- Peter Hayes

Orlando de Bois- Taylor Yellin

Duke Senior / Duke Frederick- Andrew Djang

Jaques- Danielle Woolis

Oliver de Bois- Elliot Colgan

Silvius / Le Beau- Ben Rendich

Phoebe- Sasha Williams

Amiens / Lord 1- Sydney Gottesman

Charles / Jaques de Bois- Myles Clohessy

Adam- Sam Perdek

Corin- Derek Sherry

Audrey- Emma Meyers

William / Dennis / Lord 2 & 3- Rob Reddington

Sir Oliver Martext- Jordan Schmidt

Crew:

Co-Director- Katherine Gilmartin

Co-Director/Choreographer- Virginia Edinger

Stage Manager- Chanelle Larios

Fight Choreography- Vincent Lane

Dramaturg- Leyla Gentil

Music Composition- Sequoia Sellinger

Musician- Ericka Longo

Asst. Choreographer- Linnea Seegars

story:
Our Project

Theater in Asylum is creating a stage adaptation of the 2016 Presidential Debates. With a small army of actors, designers, dramaturgs, and support staff, we are watching each debate, analyzing its content, devising an original piece around it, and presenting it live in NYC. With mimicry, abstraction, and earnest curiosity, we seek to illuminate the candidates, their policies, and their characters. 

 

What we've done so far (and the buzz we got for it!)

Over the past year we've immersed ourselves in presidential politics. We started with a few experiments using the Kennedy/Nixon debates, continued with a series of shows based on the Democratic Primary debates, and now we look to the general election. The language of politics and of politicians can often be opaque and exclusive, yet our democracy depends upon engagement and participation. We believe that voting is not enough. We must debate. Letting our elites discourse for us leaves a space in the democratic process between the citizenry and our elected leaders. We believe that it is in that space that corruption, deception, and oppression begins. We want to fill that space with engaged, informed, democratic participation.

In an interview with Howlround, Theater in Asylum co-artistic director Paul Bedard stated that, “There is so much information in an election year. I believe it is the artist’s duty to help make sense of it all, not with more information, but with interpretation, narrative, color, sound, story. Art helps us understand the stakes, the context, and the humanity within the chaos."

NY City Lens wrote that, "Not only was The Debates—a play that amused and educated a full house at the Kraine Theater on the eve of the primary elections—about politics. It was politics."

 

Our Process

  1. Watch Parties: We host a Watch Party of the presidential debates open to the public to view the event live on TV.
  2. Political Analysis: Next we invite the public to analyze the transcript with us and identify the material most ripe for the stage.
  3. Rehearsal: We begin devising, improvising, and learning the material.
  4. Performance: We perform the piece and engage in a dialogue with the audience.

 

We need your help

We have ambitious goals for this production including...

  • Make all watch parties and political analysis meetings FREE to all involved
  • Offer the majority of seats at the performances for FREE
  • Pay the artists working on the show a $150 stipend

  • Hand out 3,000 "How to Vote" guides for FREE all over NYC

In total, this show will cost about $6,000 to produce. We're trying to raise two-thirds of the funds needed through this IndieGogo campaign.

Any donation you can make, big or small, will help make this ambitious project a success.

     

    Thank you

    Nothing Theater in Asylum has done or will do is possible without your support. Whether you can make a monetary contribution or just donate some of your time (email us!), we're so appreciative and grateful for your support. We believe deeply in the work we're doing and are so blessed to be in a community as vibrant and engaged as this one. THANK YOU.

     

    Join us!

    Watch Parties at The 12th Street Ale House (192 2nd Ave at 12th St in NYC)

    • Tuesday, October 4 @ 9pm
    • Sunday, October 9 @ 9pm
    • Wednesday, October 19 @ 9pm

    Performances November 6 & 7

     

    The Debates is a production of THEATER IN ASYLUM. THEATER IN ASYLUM​ is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non­profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of THEATER IN ASYLUM must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” only. Any contribution above the value of the goods and services received by the donor is tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

Performances November 6 & 7 The Debates is a production of THEATER IN ASYLUM. THEATER IN ASYLUM​ is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non­profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of THEATER IN ASYLUM must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” only. Any contribution above the value of the goods and services received by the donor is tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
Short Summary

Malevolent Creatures is a theater project that began when our Artistic Director, Cecilia Cackley, read A Dictionary of Fairies by British folklorist, Katherine Briggs. So many of those stories about supernatural characters still seemed relevant to our world today. We have spent the past five years exploring three of these characters—Selkie, Black Annis and Tiddy Mun—and their stories through staged readings and workshops. This full production is a collaboration between Wit's End Puppets members and collaborators as well as visual artists from Maryland, DC, Texas and California. Other DC-area puppeteers and designers have been involved as well. 

National and world events reveal to us daily how relevant the struggles in these stories remain. The Selkie story we present, with its male/female power dynamics, echoes many #MeToo stories. Ongoing conflicts in Syria and Yemen are related to our telling of Black Annis' story in which children are endangered by their surrounds. Tiddy Mun, a fairy of the fenlands in England, reminds us that human actions are snowballing into global climate disaster. We share these stories to better grasp and grapple with these issues. 

What We Need & What You Get

We are raising $2000 for this full production of Malevolent Creatures. Here is what that money will allow us to do: 

-pay our sound and lighting designers who are creating the environment and ambience for the show

-pay the artist who created our beautiful crankie scroll

-pay our technicians who will help us prepare the theater for our performances

We have a number of different rewards for supporting our campaign including tickets to the show, custom stickers with artwork of our fairy characters, and your name in our show program. If you want to take home a piece of our work, you could get an original finger puppet. For an up close look at what we do, contribute at the highest level and meet the puppets after the show.

Risks & Challenges

There are many challenges in live theater: finding a space in our very expensive city, building all the puppets and set pieces from scratch, rehearsing three separate shows to a point of readiness for an audience, etc.  We have nearly surmounted all these hurdles and are almost at go time! This is our third full-length show created as a company and our second Indiegogo campaign. We will deliver all rewards and a great puppet play in the coming weeks. We hope you will join us!

Other Ways You Can Help

Helps us spread the word about the show on social media! Tell others who might be interested and follow our progress on our blog.

story:
Why FreeForm?

The theatre used to be a religious experience. The Greeks celebrated the god of sex, drugs and rock n’ roll (Dionysus) with theatrical rites. It was a religious experience. We want to bring back the spectacle, ceremony and wild abandon of those early days of the theatre. We want to treat each show as if its never been done before. We want the audience to be enveloped in the communal aspect of the shared experience. We understand that the audience is a part of the show. Every actor knows the audience is the missing scene partner in rehearsal. Everything we do is for the audience. So, why isn’t theatre more accessible for the average joe? It was in Shakespeare’s day. The groundlings commanded the attention of the performers. It should be like that again. We are here to make theatre great again! 

In 2017 Sean Newman and Patrick Rose sat in a Broadway theater to sit and watch Natasha, Pierre and the Great Comet of 1812. What unfolded was that very previously described religious experience. What Dave Malloy and Rachel Chavkin had created, with raucous abandon, wrapped our bodies and minds in rich detail the experience of being inside a Russian novel. We had drinks and rediscovered our love of storytelling and theatre. Suddenly we had to act! We along with a colleague, Jamie Fambrough, mounted our version of The Hunchback of Notre Dame. It was our thesis for what would eventually become Freeform Theatre Company.

We need your help to produce more theatre!

We need to raise $6,000.00 to help us produce our first phase.

The money will help pay various production costs. From performer stipends to costumes and scenery, your money will be visible in our productions.

You will be handsomely rewarded for your generosity! We have several tiers that allow you to give at whatever level is comfortable for you. With each level having equally exciting rewards. 

Please help us begin our first phase!

Phase one includes...

October- Macbeth: A Shakespearean Ghost Story

November- Ignition: A Freeform Concert.

December- A Very Freeform Christmas: A Christmas Party With Friends!

The Impact

You, our patrons, have the power to be a part of something new and exciting. Nothing like this exists in North Georgia! The impact of your contributions cannot be understated. Without an audience there is no theatre. We want the opportunity to give you what was given to us in that Broadway theater two years ago. We want to immerse you in another life. We want to break bread with you. We want to tell you a story. We need you to make that happen.

Risks & Challenges

Not going lie, this is going to be hard to do. Like with anything new people haven’t heard about us, but they will. See, word of mouth is our advantage. It will feel like something you can’t wait to tell a friend about. This experience is something people will want to share. Our marketing strategy is part of the storytelling. The audience will begin the storytelling experience before we sell them a ticket. We will use social media to deliver content and storytelling directly to our patrons before the see the show.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t afford to help us out, no problem. You can always volunteer. Visit our website www.freeformtheatre.com to sign up to help.

Please help us by sharing this campaign on social media and tell a friend… or four… or all of them!

Also use the Indiegogo share tools to help you do just that!

Thank you for your consideration and commitment to keep the theater alive. More importantly thank you for your contribution!

story:
Who Are We? 

We are Dive In Productions, an educational theatre company based out of Emerson College in Boston, MA.

Dive In Productions wants to give anyone, no matter their level of experience, a chance to learn and grow in the theatre community. Our company encourages people to "Dive In" and gives them the chance to experience real theatre. We produce 3-5 shows a season, focusing on new works by emerging playwrights. 

Our Spring 2015 season is our most ambitious yet, including:

  • Absence of Light, a "devised festival" (themed compilation of music & monologues)
  • Things We Did Last Summer, an original full-length play
  • The Ensemble Numbers, a cabaret
  • New Plays for Days, an original new works festival
  • Moments, a workshop production song cycle in collaboration with the Berklee College of Music. 

As our community grows, we want to continue expanding and offering opportunities to every level of actor, playwright, director, and theatre enthusiast. 

As college students we know how to be thrifty and keep production costs low, but we cannot make this upcoming season a success without your help. By becoming a backer, you help us to continue expanding our range of work while opening more doors for those who want to Dive In.

What We Need

Dive In Productions has been producing shows since last spring, operating entirely out of pocket up to this point. We do it for our love of theatre and passion for opening up the artistic community to people of all backgrounds. 

We are asking for $600 to cover production costs for the five shows in our upcoming season. These funds will cover the costs of props, costumes, and marketing expenses. 

In addition to theatre production, we want to showcase the hard work of our cast and production team through the Emerson College "EVVY Awards", which recognize outstanding works in the college community. 


Production Costs ($300): A show has a lot of moving parts. Production costs include props, costumes, set pieces, and other misc. purchases.

EVVYs Submission Fees ($150): Submitting to the EVVYs is a great opportunity for our actors, writers, and production team to be recognized for their work. A portion of our funds will go to submission fees to enter our works into the judging process. 

Marketing ($100): What’s a show without an audience? Marketing costs include printing posters and show programs.

Indiegogo Processing Fees ($50): Indiegogo takes a portion of funds raised, including processing fees for credit cards.

How Your Support Helps

You will be supporting an independent theatre organization that offers opportunities to anyone who wants to join the theatre community. With your help, we can double our number of productions this season! You will be giving newcomers and returning theatre enthusiasts the chance to explore their love of theatre and hone their craft.

Risks & Challenges

Our previous commitment to Dive In has brought us five successful productions in 2014. Our team is composed of dedicated student directors with experience both inside Emerson and in local theatre organizations, including The Players' Ring in Portsmouth, NH.

Even with this experience, we understand that problems can arise that are beyond normal control. We promise to carry out each and every show to the best of our ability, and keep backers updated throughout the season. The shows must go on!!

Other Ways You Can Help

You can see our upcoming productions in Boston, like us on Facebook, be a part of a production team, or come out to auditions (students only)! You can help...by Diving In.

story:
The new theatre company, Shakespeare on the Vine is pleased to present William Shakespeare's The Taming of the Shrew, directed by Tara Kayton running
July 31 thru August 22, 2015 at Brice Station Vineyards. 

Theatre makers from across the country will re-imagine the Bard's classic comedy of love and hate, tempers and temperament, and the unfamiliar roles we all play... or refuse to. To learn more watch our video!

Some of our expenses will be dedicated to renting a lighting/sound equipment package, obtaining housing & transportation for 25 artists, printing marketing materials, and other costly production needs. 

Help us raise A FOURTH of our OVERALL EXPENSES by donating today! 
Glance below at how your contribution will help:

$25 buys us one CAN OF PAINT for the set.
$50 pays for one NIGHT OF HOUSING at a home rental.
$100 rents us one LIGHTING INSTRUMENT.
$150 rents us a pair of SPEAKERS.
$200 covers the costs for one actor’s COSTUME.
$300 pays for a company member’s one-way FLIGHT.
$500 underwrites one company member’s SALARY.
$1,000 pays for the poster PRINTING.

Below are the people you will be helping:
CAST
Katherine                                                                  Petruchio
Sean M. Lewis                                                         Shelby Rose Richardson                                        
                                                     

Bianca                                                                            Baptista
Robert Zellers                                                             Sheila Doyle
                                                       

                                                       
Lucentio                                                                        Tranio
Charlotte Calvert                                                       McKenna Kelly-Eiding
                                                        


Grumio
Emily Wilson


CREATIVE TEAM
Brice Station Owners & Producers                     Producer & Director
Dolores & Stuart Mast                                             Tara Kayton                                   


Assoc. Producer & Lighting Designer                 Production Dramaturg
Laura J. Eckelman                                                      Ryan Davis

                                                         

                                                       
Scenic Designer                                                         Costume Designer
Misty Day                                                                      Summer Lee Jack
                                                        

Technical Director - Ross Aldrich
Production Stage Manager - Janet Cunningham
Marketing Director & Graphic Designer - Ryan Anderson
Graphic & Web Designer - Robert Mast
Video Editor - Paul Lieber
Photographer - Leda Mast
Marketing Coordinator - Ann Mazzeferro   



If you cannot contribute monetarily, we would love your help in other ways:

  • WORD OF MOUTH
    Share this campaign on your facebook page, via email, or word of mouth.
  • HOUSE AN ARTIST
    We need to house our artists in the Murphys area for July & August. If you have a spare bedroom, an apartment over your garage, or you know someone else who might, please email tickets@bricestation.com.
  • VOLUNTEER YOUR TIME
    Help build or paint the set. Distribute marketing materials. Gather props and costumes. Let us know by writing tickets@bricestation.com.
  • JOIN US FOR THE SHOW
    The best support is your attendance at the show. We would love to see you, and for you to see our work. Tickets are on sale now at the Brice Station website.

story:
The Company

Scandinavian American Theater Company (SATC) is beyond excited and proud to present the U.S. premiere of Then Silence by award-winning Norwegian playwright, Arne Lygre.

SATC was founded to provide unique perspectives through a new generation of Scandinavian playwrights and theater artists. Based in New York City, we are committed to strengthening the relationship between Scandinavia and the United States through collaborations and interdisciplinary artistic exchange that examine and challenge the cultural status quo. Within our first six years, we will have managed to present over 30 readings and 10 full productions.

The Play

SATC has grown swiftly and successfully in the first six years and producing this provocative and insightful play is another milestone that we hope you will join us in creating and celebrating.

Then Silence tells 10 stories that observe humanity and it’s struggles with power, domination, loss, mortality and ultimately, survival. The play was first produced in Oslo in 2009 and continues its relevance in 2016. The times we live in are wrought with brothers and sisters fighting and disagreeing with one another, but there is always hope to be found...somewhere.

Then Silence turns a mirror on human behavior that asks us all to consider and, hopefully, learn. The water is rising.

What We Need

Mr. Lygre’s conceptual and lyrical script provides a unique canvas from which our creative team can build a world out of light, color and sound. Donations of any kind go directly into supporting light, set, costume and sound design, as well as rehearsal space rental and marketing materials.

Milestone

Then Silence marks the third time SATC has produced at Theatre Row on 42nd Street in New York City and the first full production as a non-profit organization. This show is the most recent step forward as SATC becomes the singular theatrical company to combine and encourage artistic collaboration between America and Scandinavia.

Companies like SATC would not be able to continue to provide quality work without the help and blessings from you, the theater-going and art-loving public. If you are unable to donate at this time, please do not hesitate to pass along this campaign or our mission to those you know who may be interested in helping SATC continue to strive for excellence and diversity-of-thought in independent theater in New York City and abroad. 

THANK YOU!

Scandinavian American Theater Company

www.satcnyc.org

Then Silence will be presented

June 4th – June 19th

at The Lion Theatre at Theatre Row

410 West 42nd Street

www.theatrerow.org

And Special Thanks to our sponsors: 

The Royal Norwegian Consulate General of New York

The Danish Arts Foundation

Sons of Norway

Barbro Osher Pro Suecia Foundation

The Lower Manhattan Cultural Council

New York State Council on the Arts

New York City Department of Cultural Affairs in partnership with the City Council

Then Silence is made possible in part with public funds from Creative Engagement, supported by the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs in partnership with the City Council and the New York State Council on the Arts with the support of Governor Andrew Cuomo and administered by Lower Manhattan Cultural Council. LMCC.net

Lower Manhattan Cultural Council empowers artists by providing them with networks, resources, and support, to create vibrant, sustainable communities in Lower Manhattan and beyond.

observe humanity and it’s struggles with power, domination, loss, mortality
and ultimately, survival. The play was first produced in Oslo in 2009 and
continues its relevance in 2016. The times we live in are wrought with brothers
and sisters fighting and disagreeing with one another, but there is always hope
to be found...somewhere. 
Then
Silence turns a mirror on human
behavior that asks us all to consider and, hopefully, learn. The water is rising. 
What We Need
Mr. Lygre’s conceptual and lyrical script provides
a unique canvas from which our creative team can build a world out of light,
color and sound. Donations of any kind go directly into supporting light, set,
costume and sound design, as well as rehearsal space rental and marketing
materials.
Milestone
Then
Silence marks the third time SATC
has produced at Theatre Row on 42nd Street in New York City and the
first full production as a non-profit organization. This show is the most
recent step forward as SATC becomes the singular theatrical company to combine
and encourage artistic collaboration between America and Scandinavia.
Companies like SATC
would not be able to continue to provide quality work without the help and
blessings from you, the theater-going and art-loving public. If you are unable
to donate at this time, please do not hesitate to pass along this campaign or
our mission to those you know who may be interested in helping SATC continue to
strive for excellence and diversity-of-thought in independent theater in New
York City and abroad. 
THANK YOU!
Scandinavian
American Theater Companywww.satcnyc.org
Then Silence will
be presented 
June 4th – June 19th 
at The Lion Theatre at Theatre Row 
410 West 42nd Street
www.theatrerow.org 
And Special Thanks to our sponsors: 
The Royal Norwegian Consulate General of New YorkThe Danish Arts FoundationSons of NorwayBarbro Osher Pro Suecia Foundation
The Lower Manhattan Cultural Council
New York State Council on the Arts
New York City Department of Cultural Affairs in partnership
with the City Council 
Then Silence is made
possible in part with public funds from Creative Engagement, supported by the
New York City Department of Cultural Affairs in partnership with the City
Council and the New York State Council on the Arts with the support of Governor
Andrew Cuomo and administered by Lower Manhattan Cultural Council. LMCC.net 
Lower Manhattan
Cultural Council empowers artists by providing them with networks, resources,
and support, to create vibrant, sustainable communities in Lower Manhattan and
beyond.

story:
"Water links us to our neighbor in a way more profound and complex than any other." --John Thorson

Who Am I?

I am an actress and a global citizen, a playwright and an advocate. I believe that art should serve as the hybridization of entertainment and education. I believe in stories and that everyone has a story to tell. I believe in the power of theater to change the world. I am at heart a wanderer but one who wanders with purpose; I wander to change the world.

The Backstory: 

Seven years ago, in a freshman social studies class, I wrote my first paper about sanitation. Three years ago, as a senior in my high school's International Baccalaureate program, I wrote my first anthropological paper on the water and sanitation crisis currently occurring in Bangladesh.  Every year of my life since then, I have found a way to learn and explore another facet of Bangladesh's growing sanitation crisis. 

This project is the culmination of seven years of academic investment, seven years of only being able to write about the problem instead of being able to do something about it, seven years of theory. This is the year I take action.

What is it I'm trying to do? 

This year, through the unique opportunities provided to me by my home institution of Northwestern University, I am traveling to Bangladesh this summer to study the Bangladeshi sanitation crisis first hand. The goal of my project is to study how a diverse set of NGOs, governmental agencies, and grassroots programs function to combat the issues of water and sanitation, particularly in relationship to the needs of women and children. My project will ultimately culminate in a playscript, written to both draw attention to the sanitation crisis, to serve as a tool for discussion and progress, and to give a voice to those who would otherwise go unheard. 

While in Bangladesh there's going to be so much to see and absorb, it's going to be a challenge to filter it all down into one cohesive play. But I have tackled this process of creative distillation before. The first play I ever wrote dealt with HIV, Multiple Sclerosis, and Alzheimer's. From that project I learned how to conduct research on sensitive subject matter and create a meaningful theater production that served as a platform for community discussion and change.

What you can do:

Your support will go to enabling the creation of this playscript, helping to cover the tools I need to properlyrecord and photograph my fieldwork so I can craft and promote this as a theatrical performance for social change.  

The perks for this indiegogo project are reflective of myself as a writer and a global citizen. My swag includes personal postcards from Bangladesh, surprise rewards, and the chance to be a part of an original artistic work.

 

Making the Difference:

As a global health and theater major, I believe that art has the power to change the world for the better. With this project i am seeking to prove that belief. Please help me in this endeavor.

"Your life is an occasion. Rise to it." -Mr. Magorium from Suzanne Weyn's book Mr. Magorium’s Wonder Emporium

 

Lending a Helping Hand:

Even if you yourself are unable contribue, please pass this video around to anyone and everyone you know. Every little bit helps!

If you're interested in being a part of the journey itself, please tag along for the ride by following me at my travel blog wanderingoncourse.blogspot.com

 

 

Any contribution, big or small would be greatly appreciated. Thank you so much for taking the time to read this : )

story:
Hello from us!

Strung Up Theatre Company are an emerging theatre group made up of some of the best talent that the University of Cambridge has to offer. This August, we are taking two shows up to the Edinburgh Fringe but we need YOUR HELP to raise the money to buy the equipment that will set our show apart from the rest

What We Need 

We need to buy aerial silks and a trapeze in order for our show to become a reality. A static extended trapeze costs £165 and Aerial Silks cost £85 each. This means that we only need £250 for the go-ahead.

Why are you asking for £500 then?

Although we can run with £250, these prices are for the basic versions of each piece of equipment. Ideally we'd like to buy better quality equipment, to ensure the safety of our performers and it would hopefully mean that the equipment would last longer.

What will happen to the equipment after Edinburgh?

At the moment, Strung Up Theatre Company is just a name, but within a couple of years we want the company to grow into a professional theatre group. We have some incredible plans already for new shows that will also involve aerial acrobatics, to be performed not just in Cambridge but across the country and perhaps even internationally. In the long run, it will save us a huge amount to know that we've made the investment to buy our own, good quality equpiment that we can then train more and more people on.

Why can't you just buy it yourselves?

As much as we wish we were millionaires already, unfortunately that isn't the case. We're just a bunch of students, riddled with debt and without a penny to our name. We've sought backing from university societies but there's only so far that their money can take us and inevitably, they need their money back so that they can reinvest it into other shows. We need to start making our OWN money in order for Strung Up Theatre Company to become a reality. Please support our endeavours.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Please, please get the word out and make some noise about our campaign. Indiegogo have lots of share tools, so get using them! 
  • Come and see our shows in Edinburgh!!
    • https://www.facebook.com/events/534146869974400/?directed_target_id=541810389212766
    • https://www.facebook.com/events/541810389212766/?directed_target_id=534146869974400

story:
DREAM DANCE

 

DANCE can bring all the arts together in one. It is such an international Language that everybody in the world can understand and can relate to.

IFEEL I HAVE A MISSION TO FULFILL. Bring together all the arts and Unite through Dance. Of course much needs to be done.
 
There is so much discrimination, racism, division in the world but when you DANCE together non of that counts. You are like one body taking from one another and getting richer and fuller.
 
DANCE is INTEGRATION
DANCE IS FUSION
DANCE IS UNITY
DANCE IS COLLABORATION
DANCE IS COMPATIBILITY
DANCE IS BEING THERE ONE FOR THE OTHER
DANCE IS COMUNICATION
DANCE IS FULLFILMENT
 
I was accepted in a unique dance institution that starts a program only every three years.
 
This is a dream come true for any contemporary dancer and I feel lucky!
 
BUT I NEED YOUR HELP TO MAKE IT HAPPEN.
 
Please contribute to my campaign so I can spread to the world DANCE AND ALL WHAT IT CAN MEAN.
 
My goal is not a selfish one of only self fulfillment. I think that with such training at P.A.R.T.S I can really be usefull to youth around the world where I can reach them to build there dance artistic dreams and help them to fulfill them WORKING ESPECIALLY HARD ON INJURY PREVENTION IN CONTEMPORARY DANCE.
 
Dance is a powerfull comunication tool of integration of cultures, arts, languages and creative thoughts. I am also very interested in everything that concers injury prevention in Dance so that dancers can have fuller and longer careers. P.A.R.T.S is strongly involved in this direction.


We moved to Florence Italy when I was six years old and I continued to study dance. When I was 16 I understood that this was a very difficult profession that required traveling, training, learning and investing all of my time. I begged my parents to let me go to New York to attend a Martha Graham summer intensive and the next year to attend a similar seminar at Alvin Ailey also in New York and then it was London and Amsterdam and Vienna.

I did my professional three year formation in Milano Italy and I had the chance to meet some important coreographers. I got to know about the P.A.R.T.S school in Brussels Belgium which has over the years become one of the best centers for contemporary dance. It is something similar to Juilliard. For contemporary dancers.

They take only 50 dancers and train them for a three year period with the best dance professionals from all over the world.

THIS MEANS that this exclusive program starts only ONCE every THREE YEARS!!

To apply you need to participate to an audition Studios (P.A.R.T.S.) under the direction of Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker in Brussels, Belgium.  About 1,000 dance artists auditioned across the world from 70 countries in about 30 audition sessions across the world.

During my audition session there where about 70 people and less than 10 were asked to stay. Than you were invited in May 2013 for one full week of very demanding auditions at the school. There were at this point only 176 left from the 1032 applicants. At mid week half were sent home. And then only 50 were confermed.

I am a very lucky dancer and I got into this incredible school that gives an unique opportunity to have access to an amazing array of professionals that give you all their knowledge and help you become the best dancer and dance professional you can be.

The classes include yoga and tai chi and microbiotic cooking and injury prevention and all the possible techniques both teorethical and pratical.

Actually in January of 2013 I moved to Brussels because this is how much I wanted to attend P.A.R.T.S, found a little waitressing job and a room in a house right across the school. I did not know at that time I would make it in the final cut.

IT MAKES ALL THE DIFFERENCE IN THE WORLD FOR ANY CONTEMPORARY DANCER TO BE SO LUCKY TO ATTEND P.A.R.T.S

Please help me in any way you can reach my goal

I have a summer job and my parents are doing all they can.   I can make it to provide for my living expenses and hopefully my rent. However there is a steep 4500 euro one time inscription and 2500 yearly tuition fee. This is a lot of money we do not have and this is why I ask you to help me.

Therefore my goal is to put together 4500 euros for the inscription. This is what I need for the first year. I will be applying for grants and bursaries for the next two years and hope I won't need any other help.

Any help will be welcome even only spreading the word and using the Indiegogo share tools

 

Thank you so very much

Maya

story:
WAKE UP!!!!!!!!!!

We are raising money for our production of WAKE UP! a new play by Actor/Playwright Kim Fischer at the 2012 New York Fringe Festival. This show is fresh off of a great run in the 2011 New Orleans Fringe Festival where it received positive reviews and a great crowd of theatre goers!  

The play is about racial tensions between whites and blacks as they become violent in the present. Desean Johnson sits in prison at war with his own yellow skin. Does an Asian boy have the right to own and defend his American blackness?

 

WHO WE ARE

Hi! My name is Kyle Williams. I’m a part of an up and coming arts organization called Red Bone Theatrical based in Brooklyn, NY. We are a collective of artists and dreamers from all over the U.S. Our mission is to bring more dramatic art to the stage in North America. Maybe even the world! Yeah, I know that might be a little ambitious, but with your help our current project will be a smash.

Fischer asks the questions: What does it mean to be black enough? Is black simply a racial category or a cultural phenomenon of American society? Is it both? Does culture belong to anyone specific or is it open to outsiders? Does race automatically assign you a culture or can we be free to choose who we are? What is blackness?  

 

WHAT WE NEED

We are in need of funds like everybody else to put our dreams together. Our humble request is $3,500 to cover:

-          Equipment

-          Lighting Designer

-          Stage Manager

-          Insurance

-          Advertising

-          Taxes

-          Rehearsal Space

-          Publications

 

WHAT YOU GET

All donations are incredibly important to us so we want to at least give a little back to them to show how much we respect such a gift. We do not have a large budget but we do have big hearts and big dreams. Perks will include:

-          Name recognition on our website.

-          Producer’s credits in the Fringe Program.

-          Complimentary tickets to the show (current and future).

-          Cast pictures with donors, and more!

  

IMPACT

Red Bone Theatrical aims to have you help answer these questions as we make the conversation public. Drama is all about having a voice and shouting out to the streets full of wondering minds hoping for a passionate response! Or shouting in a theatre WAKE UP! WAKE UP! WAKE UP! CAN’T YOU PEOPLE SEE WHAT’S HAPPENING! All while they stare at you from comfortable seats like you’re crazy. Either way they will think about what you said. They will talk about it. That’s what you create by donating to this project; the magic of a new conversation.

We want to empower young actors and playwrights to produce new work for as many audiences as possible, in as many places as possible. A production like this one will help us enter the market and, more importantly, enter the conversations of our time. So please listen to your inner artist and donate to a group of dedicated thespians and art lovers with a cause.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We’d appreciate any help we can in achieving our mission. There are other, awesome ways to help us reach our goal:

  • Spread word of mouth about our Indiegogo campaign with your friends and family
  • "Like" WAKE UP! on Facebook http://www.facebook.com/WakeUpFringeNYC
  • Follow us on Twitter https://twitter.com/WakeupFringeNYC
  • Visit and leave comments on our website http://www.wakeupfringenyc.com 
  • Blog about us
  • Help out other projects through the Fringe Festival. They are our brothers and sisters after all

Thanks so much for your support!

story:
What is ICBINS?


ICBINS is a small, independent theatre company dedicated to the production of new comedy featuring emerging artists. ICBINS was founded in 2008 by two graduates of NYU’s department of dramatic writing who are passionate about creating a playground for young actors, writers, and directors interested in bringing new comedy to the stage.

This fall, one of ICBINS co-founders, Manny F. Perez, was selected to participate in the Riant Theatre’s Strawberry One-Act Festival with one of his amazingly funny pieces: When Greenland Melted... The Robot Rose. This post-apocalyptic sci-fi/comedy tells the story of four of Earth’s last remaining humans hiding out from the dreaded Evil Robots.

Participating in this festival is an amazing opportunity for everyone involved in the company. We will be performing this great piece on an Off-Broadway stage in front of many industry professionals. Winning the festival would provide Manuel an opportunity to see his play published in The Best Plays from The Strawberry One-Act Festival as well as a commission from the Riant Theatre for a full-length play. There is also a prize of $1,500 which ICBINS could apply to future productions.

For more information on ICBINS and our past work, please visit www.icbins.com.

What We Need & What You Get


The proceeds from this indiegogo campaign would be applied to the following:

  • Rehearsal space. The vast majority of the funds raised here will be applied on a space for us to prepare our entry.
  • An amazing robot costume.
  • And finally, if possible, some small compensation for the actors, designers, and other artists who have dedicated their time and efforts towards the creation of this project.


We would like to thank you for your support with perks such as:

  • A script, signed by the cast and author
  • A t-shirt featuring the Robot design by Alan Chen
  • A print featuring the Robot design by Alan Chen, signed by the cast and author
  • Your name, listed on ICBINS website as one of our valued benefactors


In the event that we do not reach our fundraising goal of $1,600, the sum raised will be applied to the costs listed above as we are able. This may mean that our actors and designers don’t get paid, or that we have a slightly less awesome robot costume. But we are committed to competing even if it means rehearsing in our living room and working for free!

The Impact

At ICBINS we believe that great comedy can make everybody’s day a little bit brighter and a little bit easier. We also believe in investing in new comedic voices that reflect the concerns of a new generation. Comedy isn’t easy, but with your help, we would like to give it our all.

Despite our historically super small budget, ICBINS has already produced several successful projects including full-length workshop productions of The Bros’ Play at The Creek (Long Island City) and Andy Takes a Husband at The Stella Adler Studio of Acting. We have also produced many workshop readings for young authors in the process of developing new work.

Competing in this festival will be one of our most ambitious and impactful projects to date. By helping to support our entry, you will be giving several talented, emerging young artists an opportunity to take their craft to the next level in front of a wide audience.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you are unable to contribute, there are other ways you can help!

  • The winner of the Strawberry Festival is determined by audience vote! So the best way you can help us is to attend our first performance on March 1st at The Hudson Guild Theater, and laugh and cheer for When Greenland Melted... The Robot Rose!
  • You can also share this campaign with your other friends who are interested in comedy and new theater.


Thank you so much for taking the time to check out our indiegogo campaign! We appreciate your help in whatever form it takes!
story_txt:
What is ICBINS?
ICBINS is a small, independent theatre company dedicated to the production of new comedy featuring emerging artists. ICBINS was founded in 2008 by two graduates of NYU’s department of dramatic writing who are passionate about creating a playground for young actors, writers, and directors interested in bringing new comedy to the stage.This fall, one of ICBINS co-founders, Manny F. Perez, was selected to participate in the Riant Theatre’s Strawberry One-Act Festival with one of his amazingly funny pieces: When Greenland Melted... The Robot Rose. This post-apocalyptic sci-fi/comedy tells the story of four of Earth’s last remaining humans hiding out from the dreaded Evil Robots.Participating in this festival is an amazing opportunity for everyone involved in the company. We will be performing this great piece on an Off-Broadway stage in front of many industry professionals. Winning the festival would provide Manuel an opportunity to see his play published in The Best Plays from The Strawberry One-Act Festival as well as a commission from the Riant Theatre for a full-length play. There is also a prize of $1,500 which ICBINS could apply to future productions.For more information on ICBINS and our past work, please visit www.icbins.com.
What We Need & What You Get
The proceeds from this indiegogo campaign would be applied to the following:


Rehearsal space. The vast majority of the funds raised here will be applied on a space for us to prepare our entry.


An amazing robot costume.


And finally, if possible, some small compensation for the actors, designers, and other artists who have dedicated their time and efforts towards the creation of this project.

We would like to thank you for your support with perks such as:

A script, signed by the cast and author
A t-shirt featuring the Robot design by Alan Chen
A print featuring the Robot design by Alan Chen, signed by the cast and author
Your name, listed on ICBINS website as one of our valued benefactors
In the event that we do not reach our fundraising goal of $1,600, the sum raised will be applied to the costs listed above as we are able. This may mean that our actors and designers don’t get paid, or that we have a slightly less awesome robot costume. But we are committed to competing even if it means rehearsing in our living room and working for free!The ImpactAt ICBINS we believe that great comedy can make everybody’s day a little bit brighter and a little bit easier. We also believe in investing in new comedic voices that reflect the concerns of a new generation. Comedy isn’t easy, but with your help, we would like to give it our all.Despite our historically super small budget, ICBINS has already produced several successful projects including full-length workshop productions of The Bros’ Play at The Creek (Long Island City) and Andy Takes a Husband at The Stella Adler Studio of Acting. We have also produced many workshop readings for young authors in the process of developing new work.
Competing in this festival will be one of our most ambitious and impactful projects to date. By helping to support our entry, you will be giving several talented, emerging young artists an opportunity to take their craft to the next level in front of a wide audience.Other Ways You Can HelpEven if you are unable to contribute, there are other ways you can help!


The winner of the Strawberry Festival is determined by audience vote! So the best way you can help us is to attend our first performance on March 1st at The Hudson Guild Theater, and laugh and cheer for When Greenland Melted... The Robot Rose!

You can also share this campaign with your other friends who are interested in comedy and new theater.
Thank you so much for taking the time to check out our indiegogo campaign! We appreciate your help in whatever form it takes!

story:
About Beautiful Soup Theater

Beautiful Soup Theater was founded in 2010 by Artistic Director Steven Carl McCasland with the goal of producing theater that could benefit the community. Once we select our shows, we reach out to the author(s) to choose charity that is important to them. A portion of our profits, and all donations collected by our actors post-show, are donated directly to that organization. Over time, the mission has expanded and we have begun to focus on our work as revivalists: producing works that are misunderstood or "lost". Previous productions include: Moose Murders, A Doll's Life, Yentl, Goodtime Charley and more...

What We're Doing

We are producing a revival of the short-lived Stephen Schwartz, Charles Strouse and Joseph Stein musical RAGS. Featuring Strouse's boldest score, RAGS is the epic story of Rebecca Hershkowitz and her journey to America. With the immigration debate in this melting pot on the rise, there is no time better than now to re-visit this wonderful and misunderstood musical.

A portion of profits and all post-show donations collected by our actors, will benefit The Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation, an organization of great importance to Mr. Schwartz. 

The Impact

Not only will this production raise funds and awareness for an important organization, but it helps us continue to bring back these wonderful lost works for today's audiences,

Why We Need Your Help

Rehearsal studios can cost over $60 an hour. And costumes can be pretty pricey, too. Plus there's the props (did we mention we need a gramophone?) and so much more! Without your help, we cannot make theater magic!

story:
The Project

Ladies and Gentlemen, enter The Cabaret! It’s here, it’s there, it’s
everywhere at Nowhere! The stage is yours to take…if you can find it. The
mobile Stage Car might be in The Cabaret – or moving anywhere! Call with the
table phones, get directions, join the ride!

A spacious shade and meeting point during the day, a sparkling buzzing night
club at night – the Drunken Sobriety Cabaret, an art project at the Nowhere Festival 2014, invites everyone to come and express yourselves. Gamers, players, circus artists, drag queens, impro theatre actors, Shakespearean performers – drunk or sober, all are welcome to jump on our stage.

The art project was conceived with artistic interaction and self expression in mind and aims to incite everyone to play theatre, fool around, go on stage or ask others to do crazy, daring acts. There will be opportunity to interact spontaneously, through the art phones, and also themed evenings (Titty Twister Bar - Priscilla Queen of the Desert - The Imaginarium of Doctor Parnassus!), games and programmed pieces of improvisation theatre where everyone will be invited to join.


 

The Vision

You stroll around the Nowhere area and see a shaded space: Colorful lights,
little tables, chairs… and you are invited: Come into The Drunken Sobriety
Cabaret! You have a seat, you have a rest… but what is that? There are funny,
artsy phones on the table, and one of them rings! You pick it up, surprised –
and are invited to join the stage… but where is the stage? It is moving around
Nowhere – if you find it, you can play! … You are strolling around the Nowhere
area, and see a stage – lights flashing up and down the side of the stairs...
what, this wasn’t there yesterday! Curious, you approach… on the stage you are prompted to play! Improvise! Be a Shakespearean actor, be a drag queen, be a harlequin, be… wait: A phone is ringing! You pick it up, and someone tells you to do something fancy, crazy, or an act of daring…

The Drunken Sobriety Cabaret idea was born out of a brainstorming
session of Sebastian and Tünde, who met at Costume Camp at Nowhere last year. It brought together their ideas of a mobile carriage which would incite and
invite Nobodies to play and of a stage where an improvised theatre pieces could be enacted by as many spontaneous actors as possible.

Thus the idea: A project called “Drunken Sobriety”, with two main
elements, The Cabaret and the Stage Car. The cabaret space will have a shade
structure and little tables and chairs, with a colorful setting, and a mobile
Stage Car. The Stage Car and some of the tables will move around during the
festival, so sometimes the cabaret space would have a stage, sometimes there
would be a cabaret popping up somewhere unexpected – close to a camp, or in the middle of Nowhere… To make the project even more interactive and connected, there will be Artphones connecting tables, stage and some other points at Nowhere, making it possible that anyone (or secret inciting agents from our team) might call up the tables or the stage, giving or asking for instructions or artistic input or some crazy acts of daring. We will have some announced plays and themed evenings.


 

The team

Our team is a transnational mixture of Burners from Toulouse, Munich, Vienna and Brno.

Project leads are:
* Sebastian aka “Lightning” (previous art projects
at Nowhere: 2008 ORNI, 2009 rolling gardenswing, 2010-11 ARTPHONE, 2012 installation of a nest, 2013 SweetART - the candyflosswigmakingcart), *Tünde aka “Thunder” (2013 The Altar of Spontaneous Baptism and Gifting, organizer of the Vienna Burning Ball 2014).

Some other team members are also seasoned Burners with experience in events organisation and art projects.

Stephan has co-created an amazing photo booth for the Vienna Burning Ball 2014 (amazing inside and beautiful outside), and participated several times in participatory art projects (see his work at http://www.stephanpetzl.comand http://www.onehookgallery.org/).
Steff has co-leaded a French Burners art project, Stairway to Heaven, that got built on the Playa in 2013 as part of the Burning Man CORE (Circle of Regional Effigies) initiative. It even got coverage in the American media Ignite and the Burning Man blog!


 

Your support

We have an art grant from the Nowhere organization and have gathered funds through a fundraiser event. We now need your support to make our vision come true and as amazing, sparkling and inspiring as we dreamed it.


We will use your contributions to complete the lighting of the stage and
the shade structures, and to finance our electric and sound equipment.


Please, give whatever you can – every contribution helps us to succeed
in building our beautiful collective art project and in creating a unique and
exhilarating space for self expression! You can also help by spreading the news
about our project – tell your friends, spread the idea, get excited, bring your
acts, bring your games, come and enjoy our Cabaret! Please share the link to
our page!

story:
Welcome to the Family!

Mammoth is the story of Jeffrey and Drew, two brothers welcoming home their ex-patriot sister Margaret to assist them in the sale of their childhood home. Over the course of her short weekend stay, the siblings must confront the terms on which they parted five years prior and reconcile the past they have clung to with the future they refuse to embrace. A play about family, love, and distance. 

This premiere production is over three years in the making. The script has seen workshops, edits, and total page-one rewrites. This March, playwright and director Kate Royal is thrilled to bring the show in its fully realized form to a debut audience at Rochester's Multi-use Cultural Community Center. Thanks to the work of a dedicated and passionate cast and creative team, we are eager to bring you an intimate, authentic, and exhilarating evening of theatre that will challenge your ideas of the traditional family drama.

How You're Helping

Thanks to your support, in less than two days we have reached our goal! But, of course, your continued generosity is more than appreciated. Over the next 15 days, we welcome any and all further funding to guarantee an exemplary experience for you and the rest of our audience! Let's keep the Mammoth train moving! 

Funding for our project will go toward production costs (scenic design, lighting design, and props), compensation for the unbelievably hard-working artists that have committed their time and tremendous talent to making this show what it is, and helping us ensure the lights stay lit at our phenomenal theatrical home, The MuCCC! 

Down to the Wire

We open in just over two weeks! As we move toward opening night, we are amassing all the tools at our disposal to bring Mammoth to life. Even though we have reached our initial goal of $1000, we encourage anyone willing to please donate whatever amount they can. Between our own resourcefulness and a trusty pinch of theatrical magic, we were prepared to work with whatever means we had, but thanks to the support of the Rochester community we are more certain than ever that we will make Mammoth the immersive and energizing experience it is meant to be. 

We're Here for the Audience

Mammoth is a passion project for all of those involved. We believe that this show has the ability to achieve in its audience what the best pieces of theatre always do: compassion and discussion. The story we are telling is one that will challenge our audience as much as it will resonate with them. In Margaret, Drew, and Jeffrey, our cast has created three individuals in whom each member of the audience will recognize both themselves and the people in their lives. Our goal is to give you an intense and intimate evening at the theatre that will create hours of conversation long after you've walked out the door. Without your help and generosity, we fear that Mammoth will not exist at the level of authenticity needed to make its full impact. Theatre exists for the audience, we are here for and because of you. 

Our Team 

Meet the team bringing you Mammoth at MuCCC! 

CAST: 
Margaret - Emily Putnam 
Drew - Luke Martin
Jeffrey - Marc Cataldi 

PRODUCTION:  
Playwright/Director - Kate Royal 
Dramaturg - Claudia Nolan 
Scenic Design - Rory Cushman 
Lighting Design - Andrew DG Hunt 
Videographer - Shawn Gray
Graphic Designer - Joanna Walters

Other Ways You Can Help

If donating isn't your thing, you can still show us some love! Follow and share us on Facebook, visit us at www.mammothplay.weebly.com or purchase tickets at www.muccc.org!

story:
Scrapland by: Hannah Bisewski

A family struggles to remain standing after the loss of its patriarch, while disaster stalks them from beyond their home, through the detritus of a bombed-out American city. Neither here nor there, Scrapland is a place torn to shreds by a violence that erupts from the inside, seeps from the outside, marks an era, and offers no explanation.

Scrapland is the thesis production that marks the completion of writer Hannah Bisewski's playwriting MFA at Columbia University.  

Scrapland will be at the Signature Theatre's Ford Studio (480 W 42nd, 3rd Floor)



BUT WE CAN'T DO IT WITHOUT YOUR HELP

Scrapland will be co-presented & produced by Columbia Stages, the Signature Theatre's Ford Studio & YOU!


WHAT WE COULD GET IF YOU HELP US REACH THE GOAL!

CRUCIAL PROPS AND SCENERY

COSTUMES

DESIGN ELEMENTS


MEET THE PEOPLE YOU ARE SUPPORTING!

CREATIVE TEAM:

Director   Dara Malina (Director '15 )

Dramaturg  Stephen Christensen (Dramaturgy ’15)

Set Design  Sara Sciabbarassi 

Light Design  Jennifer Reiser

Costume Design  Annie Simon

Sound Design   Harald Stojan


CAST OF PLAYERS

Nella  Anna Young

Dannyboy    Christopher White

Mizzbizz    Toni Ann DeNoble*

Franz    David Gould

Jo   Max Schloner

Ip   Tess Howsam

Bea   Ava Kelley

Elf   Nicko Libowitz

*Appearing Courtesy of Actors' Equity Association


DONOR LEVELS:

$25.00

Dannyboy's danke

-  A BIG THANK YOU FROM US TO YOU ON SOCIAL MEDIA!


$40.00

Bea's bedankt

-  A BIG THANK YOU FROM US TO YOU ON SOCIAL MEDIA!

- AND A BIGGER THANK YOU IN PRINT, IN OUR PROGRAM!


$65.00

Fondest regards from Franz

-  A BIG THANK YOU FROM US TO YOU ON SOCIAL MEDIA!

- AND A BIGGER THANK YOU IN PRINT, IN OUR PROGRAM!

- ANNNNNND EXCLUSIVE RESERVED SEATING FOR THE SHOW OF YOUR CHOICE via SCRAPLANDPLAY@GMAIL.COM


$100.00

Mizzbizzszzs's Merci

-  A BIG THANK YOU FROM US TO YOU ON SOCIAL MEDIA!

- AND A BIGGER THANK YOU IN PRINT, IN OUR PROGRAM!

- ANNNNNND EXCLUSIVE RESERVED SEATING FOR THE SHOW OF YOUR CHOICE via SCRAPLANDPLAY@GMAIL.COM

- PLUS:  A COMPLIMENTARY BEVERAGE OF YOUR CHOICE AT THE SIGNATURE THEATRE LOBBY BAR!!!!

story:
What Is Weird! True Hollywood Tales?

"Weird! True Hollywood Tales" is a live biography multimedia show in Austin, Texas. Part Behind The Music/E! True Hollywood Story/Unsolved Mysteries, the show's focus is on fascinating biographies of celebrities  who met with an untimely and/or mysterious end. Weird! True Hollywood Tales is curated & hosted by stand up comedian Lashonda Lester with biographies being presented by your favorite Austin and national touring stand up comedians. There are six episodes in Season 1.

The Impact

The show has already generated a small buzz among not only comedy fans, but fans of film, music, television and pop culture in general.

http://austin.culturemap.com/newsdetail/10-29-1...

http://www.austin360.com/blogs/content/shared-g...

http://www.austinchronicle.com/blogs/arts/2012-...


At first when people hear that the show is being produced and hosted by a comedian, immediately they think that we're making fun of dead celebrities (which is so not the case). If I had to sum up the description of Weird! True Hollywood Tales in one word, it would be edutainment. The audience always comes away with knowledge and a new appreciation for the biographies we profile. Each show, our guests receive a download card good for an eBook I put together filled with resources about the topics discussed and a poster.


       So far I have produced 3 live episodes of the show;

  • Rock & Roll Is Dead...Literally -  October 31, 2011 
  • Thug Heaven Vol. 1 -  January 22, 2012
  • Hollyweirdland! - February 23, 2012
 

What We Need & What You Get

Advertising and marketing. As the old saying goes, a horrible thing happens when you don't advertise...NOTHING. We need money to market Weird! True Hollywood Tales properly so that we can build a core audience and present this awesome show to more than 20 people. I've been  funding this show 100% out of my own pocket. It's expensive producing a quality production, in addition to advertising. In return for your support, I have come up with some pretty creative perks that I hope you will like.

Other Ways You Can Help
If you have any ideas about how you can help, email me. I'd be delighted to hear from you. Please share our IndieGogo page with someone you think may enjoy this project or pass along our website, Facebook page or YouTube channel. Thank you for taking the time to check out our fundraiser.
story_txt:
What Is Weird! True Hollywood Tales?"Weird! True Hollywood Tales" is a live biography multimedia show in Austin, Texas. Part Behind The Music/E! True Hollywood Story/Unsolved Mysteries, the show's focus is on fascinating biographies of celebrities  who met with an untimely and/or mysterious end. Weird! True Hollywood Tales is curated & hosted by stand up comedian Lashonda Lester with biographies being presented by your favorite Austin and national touring stand up comedians. There are six episodes in Season 1.The ImpactThe show has already generated a small buzz among not only comedy fans, but fans of film, music, television and pop culture in general. http://austin.culturemap.com/newsdetail/10-29-1...http://www.austin360.com/blogs/content/shared-g...http://www.austinchronicle.com/blogs/arts/2012-...At first when people hear that the show is being produced and hosted by a comedian, immediately they think that we're making fun of dead celebrities (which is so not the case). If I had to sum up the description of Weird! True Hollywood Tales in one word, it would be edutainment. The audience always comes away with knowledge and a new appreciation for the biographies we profile. Each show, our guests receive a download card good for an eBook I put 
together filled with resources about the topics discussed and a poster.       So far I have produced 3 live episodes of the show;Rock & Roll Is Dead...Literally -  October 31, 2011 

Thug Heaven Vol. 1 -  January 22, 2012 


Hollyweirdland! - February 23, 2012

 What We Need & What You GetAdvertising and marketing. As the old saying goes, a horrible thing happens when you don't advertise...NOTHING. We need money to market Weird! True Hollywood Tales properly so that we 
can build a core audience and present this awesome show to more than 20 
people. I've been  funding this show 100% out of my own pocket. It's expensive producing a quality production, in addition to advertising. In return for your support, I have come up with some pretty creative perks that I hope you will like. Other Ways You Can HelpIf you have any ideas about how you can help, email me. I'd be delighted to hear from you. Please share our IndieGogo page with someone you think may enjoy 
this project or pass along our website, Facebook page or YouTube 
channel. Thank you for taking the time to check out our fundraiser.

story:
Here at the Cradle Theatre Company, we strive to honor the classics as we forge ahead into bold new territory. Our Baltimore branch aims to bring young and emerging theater artists together in a professional setting where they will put on a production and develop creatively with their peers. We strive to introduce new generations and new audiences to our work and foster a sense of artistic community here in Baltimore. This summer the Cradle Theatre Company presents William Shakespeare's:

MACBETH

Directed by Laura Hawes

August 4th-14th

In this post-apocalyptic production, King Duncan’s command over Scotland destabilizes after a devastating chemical war turned the Scottish heaths into a toxic wasteland. As resources become strained, desperation and ambition prompt thanes like Macbeth to catch the nearest way to the Scottish throne.

In order to bring this vision to life, we need your help! We are asking for $500 to help cover some of the upfront costs. This money will be used to book rehearsal space, costume our actors, acquire safe weapons, craft props, build set pieces, and purchase lighting instruments. While it doesn’t seem like much, this money would give young designers and choreographers the opportunity and tools they need to execute their vision.  

As a company we believe in the importance of fostering a sense of community here in Baltimore and giving emerging theater makers the opportunity to create and share their art. We put on productions that bring the classics to life and excite younger audiences. If you want to support the work we do, please contribute to this campaign! Over the coming weeks we’ll be keeping you up to date with production stills, new costume pieces or choreographed fights, and thank you videos from the cast and crew! Join us as we turn fair to foul this summer!
